fields.headline: A great Grimes
fields.standfirst:
Peter Grimes
*****
Glyndebourne
fields.trailText:
Peter Grimes
*****
Glyndebourne
fields.body:
Trevor Nunn's production of Peter Grimes was deemed one of Glyndebourne's finest when it first appeared in 1992. It remains a towering achievement, it's subtlety and force deriving from Nunn's willingness to exploit a multiplicity of theatrical styles to underpin the painful ambiguity of Britten's opera.

The community which destroys Grimes is observed with the unflinching, naturalistic voracity of Ibsen or Zola. Grimes himself, astonishingly played by Anthony Dean Griffey, is a shambling animal, pitiable and moving, yet capable of terrifying brutality. Vocally, Griffey combines the lyricism of Peter Pears with the roaring heft of Jon Vickers to give what is perhaps the finest interpretation of the role to date.

The rest of it is equally ambivalent, equally strong. Vivian Tierney's beautifully sung Ellen is at once a compassionate, tragic heroine and the embodiment of ineffectual bourgeois liberalism. Steven Page's Balstrode, younger than most, is worldly wise, yet forcefully hectoring.

There's not a weak link among the ghastly denizens of The Borough, each one of whom is superlatively characterised. Mark Wigglesworth, conducting the LPO, matches Nunn's vision turn for turn, swinging between pungent clarity and heart-stopping textural beauty to give the performance of a lifetime.

fields.headline: Strength in numbers
fields.standfirst:
Networking is not about social climbing. It's about sharing ideas and fostering teamwork. And it's not just individuals who benefit, as companies are realising. Kate Hilpern reports

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Networking is not about social climbing. It's about sharing ideas and fostering teamwork. And it's not just individuals who benefit, as companies are realising.
fields.body:
If you want to get ahead, get together. That's the verdict of a growing number of office workers, who are recognising that they don't necessarily need to go on an external course to develop their skills and maximise their career. Building networks within the office - formal or informal - can be just as effective in providing a forum for self-development.

Despite having rather negative connotations of over-ambitious social climbers, networking is the new buzzword among the support staff of many larger employers. A growing number of companies are actively encouraging support staff to take time out to utilise a variety of professional associations, ranging from the specialist (such as the British Society of Medical Secretaries) to the general such as PA Network). So impressed are some employers with the results that they are creating their own networks in-house. According to Hilton Catt and Patricia Scudamore, authors of The Power of Networking, in a further decade these internal secretarial networks will have changed the face of support work completely.

"Networking isn't just about the stereotype of social climbing. It's about getting contacts, becoming knowledgeable about the latest changes in the profession, raising the profile of your role, and ensuring you're getting the best chances of training and promotion - in other words reaching your full potential," explains Catt. "Not surprisingly, employers have realised that creating their own formal networks means creating the very best secretaries around."

So why now? According to Professor Alan Smithers, researcher in employment issues at the University of Liverpool, "With layers of middle management disappearing and with the downsizing of companies, office support roles are no longer perceived as merely an 'extra wife' to a manager. Rather, they are recognised as roles which include overseeing information technology, training, marketing, personnel and managing small projects."

Lisa Barnes, secretary co-ordinator at KPMG, thinks the large numbers of secretaries at work is a reason. "In our Manchester office alone, we now have 57. So we decided to set up a system in which we meet up every six weeks to discuss issues affecting both the company and our jobs, and to learn from each other as to the best ways of dealing with them. It raises morale and has had a very positive effect on staff retention," she says.

In addition, KPMG organises occasional meetings with client support staff to boost client relations and ensure that its employees keep up to date on the latest movements in the secretarial world. "We also have 'Oceans of Opportunities' days, where all support functions set out stalls, almost like a bazaar," says David Chadwick, communications officer for the London office. "It's invaluable for raising awareness of what the different departments do - thereby creating better links - and also offers otherwise hidden opportunities for changing careers, essential in a climate where secretaries are increasingly moving into roles such as HR and marketing."

Dr Jane Sturges, research fellow at Birkbeck college in London, has found that with fewer management levels and often less money available, traditional incentives such as bonuses and extra annual leave are being replaced by increased responsibility and opportunities for building on skills. "Networking is seen as a kind of perk for secretaries," she explains. "They know their job won't be for life anymore so they want more transferable rewards."

At the forefront of the trend for internal secretarial networks is pharmaceutical giant Glaxo Wellcome, whose network is entitled, rather grandly, "Creating the Secretary of the Future" (CSF). "A group of secretaries - of which there are 450 within the company - got together two years ago to discuss growing discontent," explains Denise Healy, who has given up her job as a PA to become the network's co-ordinator. "We realised it was due to changes in technology and in our role, changes that we didn't feel we could keep up with unless we all pulled together. We designed a detailed questionnaire asking for the particular solutions secretaries had in mind and asked volunteers to canvass opinions in their area. That led to the decision to create a forum with five projects: a measure of competencies that secretaries could work towards and continually improve on; self-development which allows them to be more pro-active in gaining skills they need; a website with continually updated news; a communications network; and secretarial seminars."

Lesa Cheshire, a secretary at Glaxo Wellcome, claims the network has changed her working life. "Two years ago, we were just getting on with our jobs and could have been working anywhere. But now, people care about us - what we're doing and how we're doing it. Because the network gets a huge amount of support and sponsorship from board level, and projects such as the competency measures have been developed to directly relate to our appraisals, all our managers are deeply involved too."

Backing from the top is one of the reasons that Chris Towler, director of global regulatory policy, intelligence and education, believes the programme is so successful. "If anyone is going to be belittled in an organisation, it's the support staff. So it's very easy for their network to be seen as little more than a workplace women's gossip group unless it has the name of the MD associated with it. In any case, network objectives need to work alongside company objectives."

The other reason the network works, adds Healy, is because it's run by and for the secretaries. "We want support from the big guys, but we don't want them to run the show."

CSF held its first seminar earlier this month. "We've had odd lectures before but this is the first time we have run a whole day devoted to speakers, workshops and stands," says one secretary, browsing the latest training opportunities in IT before rushing off to the medical terminology accreditation stall. "I worked here for six years before I knew a thing about a single one of our pharmaceutical products," she confesses. "But now CSF has regular talks about them and I've become really interested in our latest inventions and am considering training in a more specialised medical area of the business."

"Are you going to the 'Dealing with Difficult People' workshop of the 'Self-Motivation to Succeed' seminar?" a PA interrupts. It is packed. "Let's start with the difficulties," the presenter says, to which the secretaries shout in unison, "The know-alls?" "What about the ones who start every sentence with, 'I don't mean to be negative but . . .'" says one PA. "And the ones who never say thank you?" pipes up another. Creating the list seems to be therapeutic in itself. "The day inspired me in many ways," says secretary Jacqui Williams. "But above all, it was nice to have an opportunity to really get to know the people I work with."

And this is the hidden benefit that employers are recognising, that beyond all the management gabble there is a great deal of benefit if staff simply know and get on with each other. Pharmaceuticals giant Unilever even tries to recruit compatible people with the express intention that they will have a good chance of getting along. "Employees report that working in a sociable networked environment stimulates creativity because it fosters teamwork, information-sharing and a spirit of openness to new ideas," says a spokesperson. "But they also report that nothing else comes close when it comes to making their work enjoyable."

fields.headline: Standard Life voters reject windfalls
fields.standfirst: Ballot result is expected to deliver a crushing blow to the carpetbaggers
fields.trailText: Standard Life policyholders have turned their backs on windfalls of £5,000 by rejecting demutalisation. When the result of the ballot is announced tomorrow it is expected to deliver a crushing blow to the carpetbaggers.
fields.body:
Standard Life policyholders have turned their backs on windfalls of £5,000 by rejecting demutalisation. When the result of the ballot is announced tomorrow it is expected to deliver a crushing blow to the carpetbaggers.

Early indications are that the vote in favour of conversion will be barely above 50%, far below the 75% needed to force Standard Life to float on the stockmarket.

The result is a powerful victory for Standard Life after earlier predictions that policyholders would opt for windfalls in the same way as the 62% of Bradford & Bingley building society members who decided in favour of demutualisation last year.

Some early polls had indicated that up to 80% of Standard Life members would vote for conversion.

Around 1.1m (48%) of Standard Life's 2.3m policyholders are understood to have voted in the ballot, a higher turnout than in most other demutualisation votes.

Postal voting closed on Friday, but the final outcome will not be known until tomorrow afternoon, when members attending a special general meeting can cast their votes.

It is believed that the count, supervised by the Electoral Reform Society, is extremely close around the 50% level.

Whether the carpetbaggers - led by the Monaco-based fund manager, Fred Woollard - obtain 50% of the votes cast will be crucial for the future of Standard Life.

Mr Woollard has threatened to attack Standard Life again next year with resolutions to fill the board with rebel directors if he achieves a majority vote but does not hit the 75% target.

Last night Mr Woollard was refusing to concede defeat, although he accepts that he has not broken the 75% barrier. Instead he lashed out at Standard Life's conduct during the campaign.

"Standard Life has outspent us by at least 100 to one. It's been a grossly unfair campaign," he said.

Mr Woollard himself stands to gain around £150,000 from windfalls if Standard Life floated, but confirmed his pledge to abandon campaigning if the vote falls below 50%.

Standard Life is refusing to comment on the voting figures ahead of tomorrow's meeting in Edinburgh.

A spokesman said that even if just over 50% vote for demutualisation, "it will still be a mandate for us to remain as a mutual."

He also dismissed suggestions that the company was considering paying out a special "mutual victory" bonus to policyholders.

The result, if confirmed tomorrow, will delight MPs who have vigorously supported Standard Life. More than 70 MPs, including the former social security minister, Frank Field, signed an early day motion backing the board.

Several hundred Standard Life members are expected to attend tomorrow's meeting at Edinburgh's international convention centre, but their votes are not expected to sway the results of the ballot.

fields.headline: Freeserve sale talks break down
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Talks which could have led to Britain's biggest internet service provider, Freeserve, being bought by German rival T-Online have broken down, it emerged at the weekend.
fields.body:
Talks which could have led to Britain's biggest internet service provider, Freeserve, being bought by German rival T-Online have broken down, it emerged at the weekend.

Freeserve is expected to issue a joint statement today with parent company Dixons, which owns 80% of the group, confirming that discussions have terminated.

Insiders said alternative conversations with cable company NTL were still going on but were unlikely to reach any conclusion in the near future.

The announcement will leave Freeserve management facing awkward questions when the company announces its full-year results tomorrow, when it had been expected to present a deal. It is also likely to have a damaging effect on Freeserve shares on a day when the entire net sector is braced for another battering.

The deal would have seen Dixons taking cash and shares in the combined net group.

Insiders said the cessation of talks had been amicable but centered on "cultural differences" between the two firms. The German business had also been concerned that Freeserve management might quit once the deal was done and their share options cashed.

"The two sides obviously had very long talks and remain on good terms," said one source close to the negotiations.

"For T-Online, matters were complicated by the fact that this was very soon after their flotation and they were already under enormous pressure. It was too much to achieve in too short a time."

The statement from Dixons will be the first public words on the fate of Freeserve since the admission in May that it was reviewing its options for the future of the net group. Freeserve is at present valued at around £4.5bn, although reports suggest the business could be sold for up to £6bn.

An acquisition of Freeserve by NTL would accelerate the cable firm's attempt to make itself the leader in Britain for telephony, pay-television and broadband internet access.

The company - which is 25% owned by France Telecom and in which Microsoft has a minor stake - has proven an agressive competitor to companies such as BT and BSkyB.

Question marks, however, hang over the level of debt already weighing on NTL, and some observers suggest that its plans actually stop short of a full takeover.

fields.headline: Musical youths
fields.standfirst:
Scott Walker's Meltdown: Turnage, Kurtág, Berio
****
Queen Elizabeth Hall
fields.trailText:
Scott Walker's Meltdown: Turnage, Kurtág, Berio
****
Queen Elizabeth Hall
fields.body:
Mark-Anthony Turnage's Evening Songs is a suite of three movements derived from piano pieces written for his young sons. The third piece, Still Sleeping, was premiered two years ago by the Ealing Youth Orchestra and Mark Gooding. Gooding was again in charge, this time of the Harrow Young Musicians Philharmonic, in the British premiere of the complete work as part of Scott Walker's Meltdown at the South Bank.

The two new pieces, Almost Dreaming and In the Half Light, are much more than beguiling reveries. The first defines a world of musical ambiguity, as fragmented melodies shimmer, disappear and resurface. Belying its title, the searing string lines of In the Half Light are intensely, almost violently, immediate.

For the most part, Still Sleeping is a rapt lullaby, but the sleeper's serenity is rudely interrupted by a ferocious outburst before a tranquil coda. The young players sounded particularly at ease with this last piece, but their performances throughout were confidently projected.

The second part of the concert was a self-sufficient recital by viola player Kim Kashkashian and percussionist Robyn Schulkowsky. Their selection from sets of tiny pieces by Kurtág created a 15-minute micro-drama of changing relationships between soloist and accompanist. Berio's Naturale, with its inserts of recordings of a Sicilian folk singer, was opulently large-scale by comparison.

fields.headline: Amazon chief shrugs off slide
fields.standfirst:
'There is now an irrational under-exuberance for the potential of the internet'
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Hi tech stocks and dot.com companies have been hit by "irrational under-exuberance" which underestimates the huge potential of the internet, according to the founder of Amazon.com, Jeff Bezos. Amazon's shares plunged 20% on Friday - threatening to drag down the whole sector.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in Seattle and David Teather
fields.body:
Hi tech stocks and dot.com companies have been hit by "irrational under-exuberance" which underestimates the huge potential of the internet, according to the founder of Amazon.com, Jeff Bezos. Amazon's shares plunged 20% on Friday - threatening to drag down the whole sector.

While admitting that there were some "bad business plans coming to market in 1999", Mr Bezos told the Guardian: "There is now an irrational under-exuberance for the potential of the internet" - a counter to the Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's much-quoted view of soaring stock markets.

"The internet really is a big deal. I don't think its been over hyped," Mr Bezos said.

Dealers will hope that Mr Bezos's words will soothe investors' fears over a shake-out in internet stocks. The plunge in Amazon.com was caused by two separate warnings from respected Wall Street analysts over the long term prospects of the online retailer.

Despite his bullish predictions, Mr Bezos was quick to point out that many other dot.coms were in trouble - and their predicament was likely to halt Amazon's buying binge. He brushed off concerns about his company's share price, pointing out the stock had risen from $1.50 three years ago. "There have been many many days when the stock has gone up 20% in a day as well as down."

In 1999, Amazon lost $390m (£260m) on sales of $1.6bn. It is expected to have revenues of $3bn this year. Amazon, which began selling books online in 1995, is seen as one of the strongest internet businesses. A question mark over its health could have a punishing effect on other online stocks.

Amazon's downward drift dragged other US shares lower, including the online auctioneer, Ebay - which lost 7% of its value - and Yahoo, which slid $6 to $125. Amazon shares have now fallen from a high of $107 at the end of last year to just $33.

The Techmark, Britain's hi-tech index - devised to give investors a clear picture of the fastest-growing sector of the market - has recently given shareholders only a better idea of what to avoid.

The index hit 5,743 at the beginning of March but sank to 2,864 by the end of May. A modest recovery in the past month - it now stands at 3,442 - is likely to be arrested by the latest set of concerns surrounding Amazon.

Sentiment in the UK has been dented by the high profile failure of Boo.com and the gloom over Lastminute.com. Shares in Lastminute have rallied recently to 197.5p but are still just over half their issue price of 380p.

The most damaging note on Amazon was struck by investment bank Lehman Brothers which advised investors to steer clear of a new bond issue.

Earlier this year, the online store was forced to make job cuts for the first time, sacking 2% of its total workforce of 7,500. The company says that its US book business is profitable, although it is still spending to develop book sites in Europe and other retail services.

The plunge in Amazon.com was caused by two separate warnings from respected Wall Street analysts over the long term prospects of the online retailer. Despite his bullish predictions, Mr Bezos was quick to point out that many other dot.coms were in trouble - and their predicament was likely to halt Amazon's buying binge. He brushed off concerns about his company's share price, pointing out the stock had risen from $1.50 three years ago. "There have been many many days when the stock has gone up 20% in a day as well as down." In 1999, Amazon lost $390m (£260m) on sales of $1.6bn. It is expected to have revenues of $3bn this year. Amazon, which began selling books online in 1995, is seen as one of the strongest internet businesses. A question mark over its health could have a punishing effect on other online stocks. Amazon's downward drift dragged other US shares lower, including the online auctioneer, Ebay - which lost 7% of its value - and Yahoo, which slid $6 to $125. Amazon shares have now fallen from a high of $107 at the end of last year to just $33. The Techmark, Britain's hi-tech index - devised to give investors a clear picture of the fastest-growing sector of the market - has recently given shareholders only a better idea of what to avoid. The index hit 5,743 at the beginning of March but sank to 2,864 by the end of May. A modest recovery in the past month - it now stands at 3,442 - is likely to be arrested by the latest set of concerns surrounding Amazon. Sentiment in the UK has been dented by the high profile failure of Boo.com and the gloom over Lastminute.com. Shares in Lastminute have rallied recently to 197.5p but are still just over half their issue price of 380p. The most damaging note on Amazon was struck by investment bank Lehman Brothers which advised investors to steer clear of a new bond issue. Earlier this year, the online store was forced to make job cuts for the first time, sacking 2% of its total workforce of 7,500. The company says that its US book business is profitable, although it is still spending to develop book sites in Europe and other retail services.

webTitle: Get out that puncture repair kit . . .

fields.headline: Get out that puncture repair kit . . .
fields.standfirst:
Good for you, environmentally sound and getting safer - soon cycling could be the only free way to get to work. Esther Addley on pedal power

Transport in Britain: special report

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Good for you, environmentally sound and getting safer - soon cycling could be the only free way to get to work. Esther Addley on pedal power
fields.body:
It's a terrifying white knuckle ride, a stomach-churning rollercoaster of exhilarating speed and jaw-clenching fear. Some punters rave about it, coming back for more every day; others spill out of their seat when it's all over, shaking and sick and swearing never to do it ever again.

No, not a new attraction at Chessington, but the daily bicycle ride to work. Much as we would all like to pedal along hedgerow-lined lanes to the office with the wind in our hair and the sun on our backs, for those brave souls who attempt the daily commute on two wheels, the experience is usually more petrifying than pastoral. Dodging buses and irate taxi-drivers with no more protection than a flimsy helmet and a coffee filter over the face requires a particular ecological dedication - or a kamikaze death wish.

All this may be about to change, however, with the launch last week of the national cycle network, a 5,000-mile system of dedicated cycle routes around the country that sponsor Sustrans hopes will encourage more of us to get on our bikes before we get onto that office filing. We'll get fitter, may get to work faster, and will certainly feel smugger than our colleagues taking the bus or strap-hanging on the Tube.

Certainly more extensive safe networks for cyclists are to be welcomed, even by those who never quite made it off stabilisers to pass the cycling proficiency test. Fewer people driving to work means more room for the rest of us, right? But before you dismiss the idea of getting out of your comfy car, it is worth considering that pedal power may soon be the only free way of getting to work. The reason? Congestion charges - effectively a tax on those choosing to drive into city centres, and believed to be an inevitability in London at least within the next few years. Ken Livingstone has already declared an intention to "get congestion charges right" in order to cut traffic.

The new mayor will be heartened by a study last week by the RAC Foundation, which found that more than a quarter of motorists would swap four wheels for two if congestion charges were introduced. At present a striking 71% of all commuter journeys are by car, but the pump and the puncture repair kit look set to become more familiar sights in the office if employees have to pay to drive there.

If this all sounds like good news for employers - healthier workers, lower taxi bills and more room on the road for the MD's chauffeur - they should think again. The RAC Foundation believes bosses have been freewheeling on the issue of employee cycling for too long, and have a responsibility to provide facilities for those who choose to commute by bike, including secure parking for cycles, shower facilities, and incentives for those who choose to cycle rather than use the company car.

One company singled out for particular praise by Sustrans is computer giant Hewlett-Packard, which designed its new Bristol headquarters around the needs of cyclists. Attractive sheltered bike spaces are situated at the front of the building - not tucked around the back under some leaky corrugated iron - and showers and changing facilities are provided as soon as you enter the building.

"We are making efforts to minimise the effects of almost continuous traffic congestion on our people and our business," says Simon Forsyth, the company's environmental specialist. "We are trying to be part of the solution rather than part of the problem."

If this all sounds a bit touchy-feely and tree-hugging for your boss, you might want to wave some figures under her nose. The Confederation of British Industry estimates that congestion costs the UK economy £15bn to £20bn a year, with the volume of traffic set to double by 2005. Now that really is terrifying.

For more information on making the workplace more cycle-friendly, call Sustrans on 0117 929 0888.

fields.headline: How to win at losing
fields.standfirst: Our sportsmen do it all the time. Take some tips from the pros and learn to handle defeat at work
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Our sportsmen do it all the time. Take some tips from the pros and learn to handle defeat at work.
fields.body:
After England's exit from Euro2000, the onset of Wimbledon gives Brits another chance to hone their skills in the one field we excel at - being a good loser.

Coming last in sport is not quite as exquisitely painful an experience as losing out in your job, though. If your team fails to score there is always a fountain to urinate in. Peeing in the office water dispenser is hardly the approved way of letting off frustration when you fail to land that pay-rise at work. And giving the gang from IT a good kicking will probably lead to the sack, if not a custodial sentence.

So how to handle the gut-wrenching moment when you fail to deliver in the win-win stakes? How to turn "lose" into a spin success? Perhaps we can take some tips from the more celebrity losers, after all. Try, for instance:

The Oscar loser's delight

For facial expression techniques when that key job goes to someone else or the sales pitch turns pear-shaped look no further than Oscars night. They expect to win, they would kill to win. And yet when the camera zooms into close-up as another name is announced, they punch the air and gurgle with delight as though their preferred choice had been selected.

Key tips
Rehearse the smile for weeks before to avoid the faux-rictus look. Be the first to rush up and congratulate the colleague who did get the job/sale. Don't let anyone hear you retching in the toilet afterwards

The footballer's gape

In the world of football the stiff upper lip is dead. As in industry, commitment is all on the pitch, and the steely grin of indifference is taken as a sign of weakness. When you lose out in the style of any British goalie, the technique is to stare in disbelief. 'Whaaaaaat?' should be your war-cry before you scour the vicinity for someone else to blame. Claim dirty tricks on behalf of the person who did get the job/sale you wanted and go off with your suit jacket or shirt pulled up over your head, kicking over waste bins en route. Tears or a defiant finger are also recommended.

Key tips
It can help to apologise for the tantrum later, just to prove you are a reliable employee and not just a spoilt five-year-old brat. Explain that the winning meant a lot to you and that you will up your performance next time. (Or get Kevin Keegan to do the apologies for you)

The architect's waffle

When Sir Norman Foster explained patiently to the press that the Millennium Bridge was far from being a failure and that, anyway, it wasn't his fault, he did us all a service in terms of technique.

When confronted by a "lose" at work make a few ethereal quotes about how success and fail can never be measured in layman's terms. Then say that you only learn through the faults that show up. And that it was your colleague's responsibility in the first place.

Key tips
A look of confidence is vital for this type of performance. Stick one hand in a pocket and smile as though moving through life without a care in the world. Imply you are on a higher plane of thinking than mere mortals and that - even if you did make excuses - they wouldn't understand them, anyway.

The political vanishing act

Politicians and their entourages have acquired a new technique when the whiff of 'lose' is in the air: they vanish from sight for a week or so. 'Going underground' is a valuable technique because it relieves you of the prospect of too much stage-managed indifference.

You may only be able to check out of the workplace for the odd day's paid holiday, but you can achieve the same effect by keeping a low profile for a month or so. This means that, by the time you join in the swing of things again, the rest of the office have forgotten your shame and embarrassment.

Low-profiles are easy to maintain in the modern workplace. Lower your chair a little to make yourself hidden behind you PC screen, arrive early and leave a little later each day, and stop attending unnecessary meetings. With luck no-one will bother you while you lick your wounds.

Key tips
The best time to emerge is shortly after someone else has had and equal or greater lose than your own. This will either dwarf and/or delete the memory of your 'lose', and you may even find yourself able to make a public show of commiserating with your colleague.

fields.headline: Willie Nelson
fields.standfirst:
Willie Nelson
***
Fairfield Halls, Croydon
fields.trailText:
Willie Nelson
***
Fairfield Halls, Croydon
fields.body:
Willie Nelson has been making records for over 40 years, tackling everything from western swing to pop standards, and he managed to squeeze most of them into this rambling show. He ambled onstage in jeans and trainers, twin ponytails tumbling down his back from under the red bandana. With his trademark battered acoustic guitar, he's still nurturing his persona as the ancient bard of country music.

He seemed to be pacing himself, though at 67 I guess he's entitled to. While he played virtually every song anybody could think of from his back catalogue, he tended to play them in memory-jogging snippets, as if to confirm that he was indeed the real Willie Nelson, but not wishing to go into too much detail. It seemed that barely 15 minutes had passed, and we'd already heard Whiskey River, Stay a Little Longer, Crazy, Ain't It Funny How Time Slips Away, Help Me Make It Through the Night and Blue Eyes Crying in the Rain.

With the aid of his trusty Family Band, featuring his sister Bobbie at the piano, Willie has devised his own idiosyncratic performing style. The band play an elastic, free-form swing, giving Nelson room for his Spanish-flavoured guitar solos and letting him slip in and out of songs at will, cueing the band by sticking a finger up in the air. Instead of a drumkit, they have Paul English using wire brushes to play a solitary snare drum. His continual shifts between a straight 4/4 beat and limping dotted rhythms can be baffling, but they give Nelson the flexibility he is looking for.

Nelson seemed to have saved his strongest performances for a handful of songs, like the melancholy I Never Cared for You or the beautiful Healing Hands of Time. Townes Van Zandt's Pancho and Lefty never sounded more mysteriously evocative. Nelson once duetted with Neil Young on a song called Are There Any More Real Cowboys? Well, there's at least one.

&#149: Willie Nelson plays the Hammersmith Apollo, London W6 (020-7416 6080), tonight.

fields.headline: Yorkshire tamed by HarveyYorkshire
fields.standfirst: Gloucestershire 211 bt Yorkshire 160 by 51 runs
fields.trailText: A free-thinking New Zealander is rather more rare as is a mesmerising Australian. Together they are responsible for much of the chemistry that make Gloucestershire such a remarkable one-day side.
fields.byline: Norman Harris at the County Ground
fields.body:
An eccentric Englishman - even two eccentric Englishmen - isn't too unusual. A free-thinking New Zealander is rather more rare as is a mesmerising Australian. Altogether they are responsible for much of the chemistry that make Gloucestershire such a remarkable one-day side - as they demonstrated yet again in this conclusive National League win over Yorkshire.

The New Zealander, John Bracewell, is the former Kiwi off-spinner, now Gloucestershire coach. He was pleased to inherit one of the eccentrics, Jack Russell, and to hire the other, Kim Barnett. The midweek NatWest game at Worcester had seen both of these characters enjoy the sort of success that should have won the tie.

On a potentially awkward wicket, Barnett confounded the usually devilish accuracy and movement of Glenn McGrath, while Russell came in early and batted most of the innings for 84.

Gloucestershire's innings yesterday was almost a replay, and the opening overs among the most vivid of the match. Young Matthew Hoggard made a dreadful start with the ball: three wides in one over, one of which went for four. He was rested after just two overs.

No doubt the Barnett method had something to do with that: the stance which first shows the bowler all three stumps, before bewildering footwork takes him across the crease and allows the left foot to go almost at right angles into the cover drive.

Barnett, who will be 40 next month, could also manage to get his left foot in position for a legside hit before getting the other in position for an off-side shot.

'One of the reasons we got him,' explains Bracewell, 'is because he's such a good batsman on bad wickets - and we've got a few of those. And his technique is very effective against bowlers who have never bowled to him before - like Glenn McGrath the other day. And while younger players may not copy him, they get to think about different strategies to combat bowlers.' At the fall of Barnett - bowled by a shooter from the 'skiddy' Craig White - Russell again came in at No 3 to ply his strange trade. For a long time he didn't do much more than nudge singles.

But his great quality is clearly his adhesive ability. Gloucestershire don't like being five or more wickets down before the halfway point. And although yesterday their later batsmen perished rather too rapidly, they could afford these losses. On a slow pitch, 211 - surprisingly their best of the season - was to prove a rather good total.

Yorkshire lost a wicket to the first ball of their innings and with the bowler, Mike Smith, going on to take three for 20 in his nine overs, they never really got going. Even Darren Lehmann fell to frustration. With all the bowlers in the groove, backed by well-organised fielding, the home side almost had the look of a machine.

However one could not quite use that term in describing the mesmeric Harvey. The first ball of his return was a Harvey special: delivered from a medium-pacer's action, it is a top-spinner, coming out of the back of the hand and going into a higher parabola before dipping towards the base of the stumps. It utterly defeated and bowled the well-set David Byas. And the next ball did exactly the same thing to James Middlebrook. After that Yorkshire subsided very quickly.

fields.headline: Replays still catch TV out
fields.trailText: Cricket was never big on research and development - and if there is a new thirst for R & D it is all down to television.
fields.body:
Cricket was never big on research and development - and if there is a new thirst for R & D it is all down to television.

It is television money, for example, on which the development of the recently proclaimed Hawk-Eye monitor is relying. If the funding is forthcoming, next summer could see the use on television of the sophisticated technology - based on missile-tracking systems - that will show exactly where the ball would have gone had it not struck the pad.

Also television-led is the idea to use electronic contact points to show precisely when a bail has lost contact with the stumps and is therefore 'off'. Matched to a film frame, that will be key for tight run-outs and stumpings.

Television, too, has inspired the company behind the speed gun to develop a spin, or torque factor. 'It relates to curvature in the air, but we'll have to work out a new term,' say the South African company.

But what television doesn't seem able to do is to provide conclusive evidence for those much-discussed low catches that may have brushed the turf.

The slower the replay the harder it seems to form a clear view. Channel 4's production company, Sunset+Vine, say they already employ 26 cameras, and it's not apparent what more can be done.

'We will be looking at this, but maybe you can have too much technology,' says the company's boss, Jeff Foulser. 'It's almost nice to have a few grey areas.'

Finding a photo of him wasn't easy, and the indistinct image does do not print terribly well... Yet the little-known Lanville Harrigan (pictured above) rubs shoulders with such as Sir Garfield Sobers and Sir Vivian Richards as one of 21 West Indies cricketers on stamps that celebrate Thursday's big game - the hundredth Lord's Test, and the fiftieth anniversary of the West Indies' famous first win in England.

In producing the special issue for the Caribbean islands, the Worthing firm Stamp Publicity invited each of the nine territories to name two players. The smallest island, St Vincent, duly named four. And Monserrat named two non-natives, Jamaica's George Headley and Alf Valentine.

As for Anguilla's Harrigan, his government describes his 'big moment' as playing for Anguilla in an annual Leeward Islands tournament in 1984. He can, it is said, 'call himself an international after selection in 1994 for Canada B'.

No matter, Lanville is now up there with the greats. Up there, indeed, with the only Englishman to appear on a stamp, W.G.Grace, as well as two Australians, Sir Donald Bradman and Victor Trumper.

Lord's themselves are paying their own tribute to great players. Early in the Test, eight players will be honoured for 'outstanding achievements' this century. The names are yet to be announced, but Lord's has revealed that two of an original 10, Sir Donald Bradman and Glenn McGrath, are unavailable.

Also unable to make the hundredth Lord's Test is the Queen. Evidently the royal schedule didn't permit it, which in some ways is just as well. An appearance at tea on the fourth day was once traditional, but these days the Monarch might have to risk a wasted journey.

webTitle: Reassuring return of the family man

fields.headline: Reassuring return of the family man
fields.standfirst: Graham Thorpe is back in the one-day squad. He's needed in the Test side, too
fields.trailText: Vic Marks: Graham Thorpe is back in the one-day squad. He's needed in the Test side, too.
fields.body:
They reinstated him as swiftly as they decently could. At the beginning of July, Graham Thorpe will be back in the England set-up, from which he chose to excuse himself by withdrawing his availability for the South African tour last August, as a member of the one-day squad. They may like to have him in the side for Thursday's second Test as well, but I doubt whether the selectors can justify that. Thorpe himself would be surprised to find himself among the names chosen for the Lord's Test, which are announced this morning.

Thorpe has always been the strongest advocate of the central contract system; now in the short term he may be a victim of it. The selectors are surely duty-bound to give one more chance to their chosen men, however fragile they may look. Even if their instincts are beginning to waver, they have to persist with Mark Ramprakash and Graeme Hick a little longer. Thorpe could replace Nick Knight (non-contracted) but this would be harsh on the man who top-scored in both English innings at Edgbaston (albeit with 26 and 34). And there's always Michael Vaughan (contracted) to consider. Even so, it's a question of when rather than if Thorpe returns to the Test scene. I'll be surprised if he's not there at Old Trafford for the third Test.

Thorpe won't and can't complain about his absence so far this summer. 'There's no bitterness about that. Maybe if I had blazed a few hundreds at the start of the season I would have been there for the first Test.' But he didn't. He started the season slowly, a victim of moist and mischievous pitches and his own rustiness after the first winter lay-off that he had experienced in 10 years, which have been consumed by three A tours and seven senior tours. 'But,' he adds, 'there are no regrets either.'

'I could see the consequences of pulling out of the winter tour. I knew the central contracts were coming up. I knew that by pulling out I might not play for England again. But I had to weigh up my priorities, balancing the needs of my family [he now has two children aged one and three] and my career. As the season progressed I had to ask myself, "Am I looking forward to the day we step onto the plane for South Africa. Am I looking forward to the tour and the cricket?".'

In all honesty he could not give an unequivocal 'Yes' to those questions. So he decided to take a rest and withdrew. He was in good company. Graham Gooch, who turned down an Ashes tour, Ian Botham, Geoff Boycott and Ray Illingworth have all taken winters out. None the less, some viewed his withdrawal as an act of treachery. He would have been criticised more heavily if he had grumped his way around South Africa, pining for home for three-and-a-half months.

'The hardest part was telling Nasser,' he says. 'We've been mates for years and we've been through a lot together, good times and bad [remember that match-winning 288-run partnership against the Aussies at Birmingham in 1997; there's no time and space to chronicle the lows just now]. Nasser did not try to dissuade me. He knows me well enough to realise that it would have been a waste of time.'

Clearly his best mates regard him as 'obstinate'. David Lloyd famously labelled him 'surly' in his book, although quickly left an apologetic message on the Thorpe answerphone once the 'surly' headlines appeared. But Thorpe says he likes touring. 'I may not be the most outgoing of men, but I enjoy the company of my team-mates, enjoy new places.'

Yet he can be difficult - or single-minded depending on your standpoint. Before the World Cup he didn't turn up to an official dinner at Canterbury and was fined. He just about acknowledges that his absence that night was a mistake. By the way, this is done with a smile.There's no sign of surliness at all. Passing team-mates suggest with a wink that he must be launching a charm offensive. Actually, Thorpe, quiet-spoken and private though he may be, is no grumpier than any other English cricketer and he may well have a healthier sense of perspective than most of them.

He has been one of the more reassuring sights - amid modest competition - coming out to bat in a crisis for England. He's not guaranteed to score runs, but he always seems to give himself a decent chance of doing so. Thorpe thinks more in terms of opportunities, than burdens. He showed that in his first Test when he scored a century against the Australians in 1993 and at Exmouth, where I met him, he recognised these same qualities in two youngsters who had just been batting for Devon against Surrey in the NatWest. David Lye and Matt Wood, 40 years between them, had just added 100 together. 'They didn't worry about failing. I think that's how I felt in my first Test. I hope I'll have the same positive approach if I play Test cricket again.'

So Thorpe is less likely to be shackled by the pressures of Test cricket. Whenever possible, he likes to take the initiative, to take the attack to the bowlers. He's noticed how Steve Waugh often does the same; racing to 20 by taking the gamble of hitting a few early boundaries and then consolidating. Curiously, he plays a more restricted role in one-day cricket for Surrey and for England, when he resumes his one-day career. He is seen as a 'finisher', the man who stays in, picks up ones and twos, who spurns too many big shots and whose duty is to be there at the end of a run chase. There may be times when he yearns to go for the extravagant boundary but says he gains equal satisfaction from seeing it through to the end.

An in-form Thorpe is probably England's best middle-order batsman in Test cricket as well. Having seen the current lot mesmerised by Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, whom they now never expect to deliver a hittable ball, the selectors must pine for a refreshed and uncomplicated Thorpe to stiffen the middle order. But they don't want to be seen to panic either. So all the Edgbaston batsmen are likely to be retained for one more Test, to be given the chance to atone. Ed Giddins may not be so lucky though he was at his most potent when England last played at Lord's.

David Lloyd famously labelled him 'surly' in his book, although quickly left an apologetic message on the Thorpe answerphone once the 'surly' headlines appeared. But Thorpe says he likes touring. 'I may not be the most outgoing of men, but I enjoy the company of my team-mates, enjoy new places.' Yet he can be difficult - or single-minded depending on your standpoint. Before the World Cup he didn't turn up to an official dinner at Canterbury and was fined. He just about acknowledges that his absence that night was a mistake. By the way, this is done with a smile.There's no sign of surliness at all. Passing team-mates suggest with a wink that he must be launching a charm offensive. Actually, Thorpe, quiet-spoken and private though he may be, is no grumpier than any other English cricketer and he may well have a healthier sense of perspective than most of them. He has been one of the more reassuring sights - amid modest competition - coming out to bat in a crisis for England. He's not guaranteed to score runs, but he always seems to give himself a decent chance of doing so. Thorpe thinks more in terms of opportunities, than burdens. He showed that in his first Test when he scored a century against the Australians in 1993 and at Exmouth, where I met him, he recognised these same qualities in two youngsters who had just been batting for Devon against Surrey in the NatWest. David Lye and Matt Wood, 40 years between them, had just added 100 together. 'They didn't worry about failing. I think that's how I felt in my first Test. I hope I'll have the same positive approach if I play Test cricket again.' So Thorpe is less likely to be shackled by the pressures of Test cricket. Whenever possible, he likes to take the initiative, to take the attack to the bowlers. He's noticed how Steve Waugh often does the same; racing to 20 by taking the gamble of hitting a few early boundaries and then consolidating. Curiously, he plays a more restricted role in one-day cricket for Surrey and for England, when he resumes his one-day career. He is seen as a 'finisher', the man who stays in, picks up ones and twos, who spurns too many big shots and whose duty is to be there at the end of a run chase. There may be times when he yearns to go for the extravagant boundary but says he gains equal satisfaction from seeing it through to the end. An in-form Thorpe is probably England's best middle-order batsman in Test cricket as well. Having seen the current lot mesmerised by Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose, whom they now never expect to deliver a hittable ball, the selectors must pine for a refreshed and uncomplicated Thorpe to stiffen the middle order. But they don't want to be seen to panic either. So all the Edgbaston batsmen are likely to be retained for one more Test, to be given the chance to atone. Ed Giddins may not be so lucky though he was at his most potent when England last played at Lord's.

fields.headline: Player of the week
fields.trailText: James Ralph, Shropshire - his only previous taste of the big time was somewhat bitter: a pair for Worcestershire against South Africa A.
fields.body:
His only previous taste of the big time was somewhat bitter: a pair for Worcestershire against South Africa A.

Ralph's career embraces a single season with the county, club cricket in Australia, Kidderminster in the Birmingham league and Shropshire in the Minor Counties.

Work has always fitted around cricket, and his current job is in house removals. So a bonus of £350 from playing cricket and winning a NatWest man of the match award was extremely gratifying. Thanks to him, Ralph's side made a spirited reply to Somerset's 262.

Having survived the mid-innings return of Andy Caddick, and facing an unlikely run-rate, Ralph opted for his natural game. He passed 50 with two sweep-slogs for six, and when the last over started he was on 87.

Four balls took him to his hundred, the last with a stroke he describes as 'the worst of the innings - down the track, inside edge for four'. Shropshire fell only 27 runs short, and will not argue with their hero when says he is keeping the award cheque for himself.

fields.headline: Hick cruises to a century
fields.trailText: In its own right this was an important match since Worcestershire and Somerset are the top two teams in the first division of the National League. But there were intriguing games within the game as well.
fields.body:
In its own right this was an important match since Worcestershire and Somerset are the top two teams in the first division of the National League. But there were intriguing games within the game as well.

When Andrew Caddick was bowling to Graeme Hick on a typically bouncy Taunton surface the cricket was of the highest calibre - two quality performers testing one another out; the subsequent duel between Keith Parsons and David Leatherdale was perhaps less entrancing. And there was the chance to compare and contrast two of the brightest young cricketers in the coun try, Marcus Trescothick and Vikram Solanki.

Or there would have been if Solanki had not edged the first ball of the match, delivered by Caddick, towards second slip, where Trescothick briefly juggled it before completing the catch. Round one to Trescothick, whom West Country folk believe to be extremely unlucky not to have made the one day squad for the forthcoming triangular series (he's the highest run-scorer in the National League this year), where he might have joined - or replaced - Solanki.

Thereafter there were two games going on out there. When Hick was batting, all was serene, the pitch benign and runs flowed smoothly from his bat. When anyone else was on strike it all looked rather trickier. Hick scored 101 out of Worcestershire's total of 222-8 which was competitive enough since Glenn McGrath, who averages 4.8 with the ball in this competition was fit and well and prowling in the pavilion. How they must pine for Hick to show the same authority on Thursday at Lord's.

He gave Caddick due respect. As usual, Somerset bowled their England fast bowler straight through; there were four maidens in his spell and plenty of steep bounce.

Hick was cagey, recognising that there would be easy pickings later on. Initially the much-improved Steffan Jones, who soon disposed of an out-of-touch Elliott Wil son, also demanded careful attention.

But once the opening bowlers had been seen off the run-rate soared. There were not too many extravagant stokes from the Hick bat. Simple orthodoxy was enough. Parsons and Jarvis were glided effortlessly past the right hand of mid-on. If the ball was short, which was too often the case he pulled with awesome power and certainty. He rarely hit the field as he cruised to his century in 107 balls. It came as something of a surprise when he finally missed an attempted pull against Jarvis in the 42nd over, but by then he had done the damage.

There were other significant contributions, albeit in a minor key, for the visitors. David Leatherdale was a useful ally for Hick in a 58-run partnership until he became the first of two victims in two balls for Parsons. Kadeer Ali, a 17-year-old making his one-day debut, revealed some wristy promise until he was bowled around his legs by Ian Blackwell. And at the end, the ageless Steven Rhodes, the ultimate old pro, scampered and struck the ball to good effect as he has done for the last fifteen years.

For Somerset, Jarvis suffered the most and in the field they fell below their recent high standards; there were more misfields than normal and every significant shy at the stumps missed them. Mind you, this is not the first Somerset side to be mesmerised by Hick at his best.

webTitle: Cronje can fix himself a fortune

fields.headline: Cronje can fix himself a fortune
fields.trailText: A modern Greek tragedy has been played out in front of our eyes in Cape Town. A heroic figure seemingly blessed with all the appropriate virtues and with a long and illustrious career stretching out in front of him has been felled by his own fatal flaws.
fields.body:
A modern Greek tragedy has been played out in front of our eyes in Cape Town. A heroic figure seemingly blessed with all the appropriate virtues and with a long and illustrious career stretching out in front of him has been felled by his own fatal flaws. Hansie Cronje is now a broken man, full of self-loathing, a victim of hubris.

He is now painfully acknowledging those flaws. Initially we were told that Satan had taken over, a notion that appeared to shed Cronje himself of much responsibility for his wrongdoings. He's been a bit more specific while giving evidence to the King Commission. He admitted to an 'unfortunate love of money', before explaining 'I am not an alcoholic and I have never been addicted to nicotine, but I understand that there are times when you give in to temptation.' Moreover, like many who have risen rapidly to the top he must have felt impregnable, untouchable. He could beat the system and in his own mind was capable of rewriting history, of justifying what he was doing until it all became public knowledge.

Now there is no way back. He'll never play seriously again. He could have coached or managed South African teams, English county sides, international sides and have been well rewarded - by most people's standards - for doing so. Had he accepted Glamorgan's offer to coach them 18 months ago he might not be in disgrace now. Instead all those fine performances for his country have been eroded. At best he might just be remembered with gratitude but only as the man, whose example and whose eventual open testimony (we presume) helped to rid the game of the stain of match-fixing.

There is no money left in the game for Cronje. But there may be money to be made, if he can bear it, in the off-shoots of his personal tragedy. I'm still sufficiently short of cynicism to imagine Cronje wanting to profit from his predicament, but then I never believed that he could entwine himself with dodgy bookmakers and punters in the first place.

The Observer spoke to Max Clifford, the agent who has piloted many media targets - from politicians' mistresses, to multiple-birth mothers to Geoffrey Boycott - through the trained telescopic sights of Fleet Street, and he is sure that Cronje could make a lot of money.

'It depends, of course, on what he is prepared to say but although I am not an expert on the game myself, everything I hear suggests that there are still more names to be named and stories to be uncovered,' he said. 'Hansie Cronje is seen as the man who has destroyed the credibility of international cricket. He is big news.

'At the same time editors would not want to be seen to be paying him vast amounts of money because, basically, he has admitted to being a crook. But there is the defence of criminal immunity in South Africa and the fact that he has not been convicted of anything at present. Editors will also argue public interest in revealing what has happened to the sport.

'The interest, I suggest, is basically the British market. For his revelatory story in a British newspaper alone I'd say the value is £100,000. On top of that you could have a fast-turnaround book deal and it may make more sense to do that first and serialise the text in a newspaper. He would need to come up with two or three new stories and find one or two so far unknown names to give that increased value. There is no doubt in my mind, properly handled, that he could make at least £500,000 out of his story. But it could be very much more.'

And what about film rights? 'No I don't think so.' said Clifford. 'The Americans just don't understand the game, but an untapped market, bearing in mind the betting scandal story - is India and Bollywood. But the key to all this are the ingredients. If he comes up with something new then there is a lot of money to be made.'

Surely not. A few months ago all those noughts would have excited him. Now his life has been publicly shredded. We presume he has been open with us. Surely he does not want to go through all that again however much he's paid. He has suffered and like most tragic figures. Once fallen they provoke not only our loathing, but our sympathy also. It would make a good book though......

Ali Bacher has admitted for the first time that Cronje did tell him about an offer to throw a match.

The United Cricket Board boss said in his testimony last week to the King Commission that he became aware of the offer, which was rejected, only in April this year.

Cronje told the commission that he had told Bacher several times about the offer to throw a one-day match against India.

Bacher has now admitted to the Citizen newspaper that Cronje did tell him about the offer but also assured him he had not done anything about it.

He said: 'I did engage in a fleeting conversation with Hansie which probably lasted no more than five to 10 seconds. There was, however, no mention of countries or amounts involved at any stage. I acknowledge, in hindsight, that I should maybe have pursued the matter. But at the time that was totally unthinkable.'

fields.trailText: Jill Griffiths is one of the lucky ones. Her son, Neil, called her in the early hours of the morning, before she had time to see the television news or read a newspaper. There had been a terrible tragedy but he was safe, he told her.
fields.body:
Jill Griffiths is one of the lucky ones. Her son, Neil, called her in the early hours of the morning, before she had time to see the television news or read a newspaper. There had been a terrible tragedy but he was safe, he told her.

She was spared the dreadful wait which other parents across Britain are still enduring as the slow process continues of identifying those who died in an arson attack on an Australian backpackers' hostel.

Since the fire on Friday morning, 15 have been confirmed dead, and there are fears that at least another six bodies also lie inside the Palace Backpackers' hostel in Childers, Queensland. At least six of the dead are British, a further one is thought to be Irish. The consulates of all the countries whose nationals were in the area have now been given a list of 15 names.

Hundreds of UK parents will worry needlessly. Their child will eventually call, from a completely different town, a different hostel.

The Australian authorities are asking all backpackers in the country to phone home immediately and internet cafés in Queensland are allowing foreigners to write a free email to let someone back home know they are safe.

A website has been set up and heartrending messages are posted. The anxiety is tangible, from the German 'mama and papa' begging for information to 'mammy and daddy and Wendy from Llanelli', desperately appealing for Sarah to call. A message from one US mother was typical: 'I just want to hear that you're not in Childers.'

Alexander Downer, Foreign Affairs Minister, was visibly moved on Australian television as he appealed to backpackers: 'For heaven's sake, ring home and tell your families you are all right.'

Telephone lines set up for relatives have been swamped and calls are still coming in.

The family of Sarah Williams, from the Welsh village of Aberfan, and her friend Natalie Morris, from nearby Cefn Coed, now know the two have perished. Their friend, Kelly Symonds, 23, escaped the blaze to tell the emergency services that her young friends had not.

Louise Brewster, 19, and boyfriend Derek Bailey, 22, were luckier. Like many of the young people in Childers they had been earning extra cash picking courgettes and fruit from farms in the area.

They had been turned away from the Palace on Thursday because it was full. They camped nearby instead.

Louise's father, Richard, of Watton-at-Stone, Hertfordshire, had a horrifying 15 minutes on Friday morning. 'We heard about the fire at 7am on the Friday morning and were very worried for about a quarter of an hour until Louise phoned.

'She said she had a lucky escape. She was very composed on the phone, I don't think the shock had hit her.'

Gary Paton, 20, from Milngavie, Glasgow, sobbed as he told his father how his friends had died. His father, Willie, said: 'He phoned me at half past five in the morning just to say that there had been a fire in the hostel where he was staying and that he was okay.

'He just broke down, and then he said "there's 15 dead". Quite a few of his friends were missing and he was just distraught. He was just weeping into the phone.'

Marion Sipavicius, 48, said her daughter, Pamela, 21, from Bathgate near Edinburgh, told her a locked door had to be broken down before she could escape with her friend, Heather Baird, 20. 'She said they were going to continue with the trip, but I think the shock hasn't sunk in yet,' she said.

Heather's mother, 44, also Heather, said her daughter is badly traumatised. 'She still keeps hearing glass breaking and people shouting. I'm a very lucky mother, but there's others that are not so lucky.'

As Australian police named 37-year-old Robert Long as the man they want to question in connection with the fire, The Observer can reveal the dreadful safety record of Australia's budget accommodation.

The country's politicians have been calling for better fire control systems in backpackers' accommodation since 1981 when nine young travellers died in a fire in Sydney. In 1989 an arsonist killed six, including a British man, again in a Sydney hostel.

Between 1981 and 1997, a total of 47 backpackers have died in fires at hostels across Australia and hundreds of others have survived up to 20 arson attacks.

Survivors of Friday's fire reported hearing no fire alarms but fire commissioner Jeff Wright said the building had smoke detectors and reg ular safety checks. But a spokesman for the Queensland fire authority confirmed to The Observer that building owners could not be forced to install fire alarms.

Yesterday Paul Pearce, the mayor of Waverley in Sydney, said it can take up to 12 months to close an unsafe hostel and it was virtually impossible to prosecute.

'Meantime, you have a possibly unsafe hostel operating in an undesirable area,' he said.

But for backpackers' families the wait goes on. 'I weep to think of them,' said Jill Griffiths, who yesterday received a graphic email from 24-year-old Neil, describing his ordeal.

'He was spending alternate nights between the hostel and an old camper van with his friend. They had been to the beach that day with one of the Welsh girls who was killed.

'He had put out a smouldering fire he had seen in a bin inside the hostel earlier in the evening and then been woken later with thick black smoke filling the dormitory.'

Neil said: 'The smoke filled my mouth. I was just about to lie down and give up when someone grabbed me. I have never feared for my life so much. I was the last one out.'

In February Neil's girlfriend, Nicky Sheen, from Essex, died in a scuba-diving accident at Bondi Beach. He, like many of the young backpackers, experienced the worst side of life in a trip that was supposed to broaden his horizons.

AUG 1981: Nine die in fire at Rembrandt Apartments in King's Cross, Sydney.

SEP 1989: Six travellers killed at Downunder Hostel, King's Cross. Arsonist Gregory Allan Brown sentenced to 18 years for manslaughter.

AUG 1991: 12 die in fire at Palm Grove Hostel, Dungog.

MAR 1993: Arson attack at Ocean View Lodge, Fremantle. 130 backpackers evacuated.

JUNE 1995: Governor-General Bill Hayden urges better fire control systems in hostels.

APR 1996: Nine killed in Kew Cottages fire in Victoria.

AUG 1996: City Heart Hostel in Rockhampton, Queensland, gutted in arson attack. Ten backpackers evacuated.

JAN 1997: 200 flee backpackers' hostel, Melbourne.

JUNE 1997: Backpacker dies in fire at Woolloomooloo.

JAN 2000: Two Dutch backpackers charged after setting fire to door of a Sydney bar.

JUNE 2000: At least 10 die in fire at Palace Backpackers' Hostel, Childers.

webTitle: Why Keegan must go - Ian Ridley after Euro 2000

fields.headline: Keegan must go - now
fields.standfirst:
The time is right for England to look abroad for salvation

England v Germany: a rivalry of two halves

England under Sven - Observer special
fields.trailText: The time is right for England to look abroad for salvation, says Ian Ridley after the Euro 2000 debacle.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan needs more time, we are told by his employers at the Football Association. Like Alan Shearer, it should be more time to spend with his family.

For a watershed moment has arrived in the English game, one that the FA ignores at its and the national team's peril. It must dredge its soul for courage; the courage to thank their personable but inadequate coach then tell him that the unequal struggle is over. And the courage, for the first time, to appoint a foreign replacement. Arsène Wenger does not so much spring to mind as stare us in the face. Give him Gérard Houllier, too, as technical director.

What would it cost to prise them from jobs they prize at Arsenal and Liverpool? Compensation of several millions to their clubs and £2 million pounds each a year perhaps. A package adding up to the market value of Emile Heskey. Hmm. Tough choice, that, as to which might serve England better.

The FA has money coming out of its ears. It must have, to have taken more staff to Euro 2000 than there were players in the squad.

What it patently lacks is the knowledge and expertise, the awareness of trends in the European and World games, that would enable English players to compete once more in those theatres rather than return them humiliated to the repertories of the Premiership where, once they have rediscovered their timing in a month or two, they will be lauded anew - and probably rightly - as talented performers.

Wenger has two more years to serve at Highbury, but one senses that already he is thinking ahead. Japan have tried, and will surely do so again, to tempt him back to the Far East in time for the World Cup of 2002. Last week, he was advanced as a possible coach of Germany though he was quick to rule himself out. For a devoted Anglophile, with a detached fondness for its culture, England could appeal enormously, however.

What the German interest did illustrate was their willingness now to accept that they no longer have the wherewithal to solve their own serious shortcomings. Giovanni Trapattoni is being considered as Erich Ribbeck's replacement as head coach. If the Germans can show such humility, then it is surely not too much to expect of England?

There would undoubtedly be differences - for the better. Wenger would surely bring the pace, passing and movement that characterises his football. Believe it or not, despite the evidence of the past fortnight, English players are also capable of such. Just look at how Ray Parlour developed under him at Arsenal. And despite Wenger's tranquil bearing, derived from his fascination for Zen Buddhism acquired during his management of Grampus 8 of Nagoya, there beats a passion for the game within him that is in harmony with the English.

He has always loved, he once said, the reservoir of spirit and commitment of English teams when, say, 2-0 down. In a similar situation other teams can give up the ghost. Unexpected sides, such as Romania and Spain, may have discovered resilience but it remains an English trump card. The problem is that they lead with it too often. Wenger would simply make better use of the hand dealt.

Then add Houllier to consult over the cards. Last Saturday, after England's win over Germany, he approached me in the bowels of the stadium at Charleroi beaming from ear to ear. He shook my hand warmly, as pleased as any Englishman in the place. He was saddened by what he witnessed at the same venue 72 hours later, and not just because of the result.

Indeed, it has been touching these last few days talking to such people as Raddy Antic and Savo Milosevic who, among many at the tournament, are genuinely sad at the demise of a country and style of play for which they have a true soft spot.

Houllier believes that the supervisor of a country's football should be a native, aware of the nuances of the grass roots. But it has got England nowhere so far. A fresh eye is needed. The leaving of Liverpool would grieve him, and after recently signing a new four-year contract he will be especially reluctant. But it is like asking Miss World to dance. You never know until you take the chance. Rejection is worth the potential reward.

Sadly, there is little faith in this quarter in the FA's ability to be bold and radical. What was their response to the debacle that was their Euro 2000? 'People should not be looking for a quick fix,' said the chief executive Adam Crozier. What, then, were his organisation doing when they appointed Keegan? He has indeed proved that we ain't going to get a quick fix . Meanwhile, the chairman Geoff Thompson is insisting that the current technical director Howard Wilkinson should have more input to the senior side. Pur-lease. It reminds you of the MP who once said that the best way to get hold of Tam Dalyell was to look for a stick and he would be on the wrong end of it.

Wilkinson, the FA seem to need reminding, is the man who, with his tactics and selection in a Wembley friendly when caretaker coach 16 months ago, merely confirmed Wenger's words last week that France are 'five to 10 years' ahead. Then he used the chaos surrounding Glenn Hoddle's departure to jock off the successful Peter Taylor from the under-21 team before leading them to yet another English shambles in the recent European Championship finals.

Like Hoddle before him, Keegan is not thought to warm to Wilkinson and will surely bristle, if only privately, at Thompson's suggestion. Such is the FA. Politics and personality intrude upon progress. By contrast, the key personality traits of Wenger and Houllier are the absence of rampant egos. Teamwork is the thing, as the French system of the Nineties that appointed the then little-known Aime Jacquet and now Roger Lemerre has shown.

'Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it,' wrote the American philosopher George Satanyana. Memories seem short within Lancaster Gate. There were echoes of England's campaign of 1988 this time, in the straight-lines, straitjacketed formation they were squeezed into by Keegan, undone, now as then, by devious foreign johnnies who insist on moving about a bit instead of staying where they should have.

Some will point out that the FA stuck with Bobby Robson then, after he had offered his resignation, and were rewarded with a memorable World Cup in 1990. That relied though on the emergence of Paul Gascoigne and on senior players approaching Robson during the tournament to suggest a change to a sweeper system.

If Keegan does remain coach, such an event could well happen again. Indeed, at the England base in Spa, several players did discuss with him the need for a change of approach to save the team from being outnumbered in midfield. When he did bring on Nick Barmby and Steven Gerrard against Germany at the expense of a striker, albeit the wrong one, England suddenly looked better balanced.

He failed to absorb the lesson, however. Against Romania we again had Emile and the defectives. This time for bad measure we had poor Gareth Southgate looking bemused as Keegan tried to explain to him that he wanted him to go on and stick to Adrian Mutu, Georghe Hagi's replacement, in midfield. It echoed that moment in Norway in 1993 when Nigel Clough tried to make sense of Graham Taylor, whom Keegan is beginning to resemble.

I feel sorry for the players. Southgate, previously so capable for England but so bafflingly overlooked now, could have gone on and done the same sweeping job that he does so well for Aston Villa and a striker withdrawn to midfield to staunch the haem orrhaging, instead of being asked to spill blood chasing lost causes. Ironically, I understand Keegan was contemplating introducing a 3-5-2 starting line-up against Italy in the quarter-final but he hesitated against Romania and was lost.

Keegan said that England simply did not pass the ball well, no matter the tactics or system. How are they supposed to amid a confused pattern of play which sees an often unsupported man with the ball given only a difficult option rather than several easier? With Gerrard injured, he did not have enough midfield alternatives, he added. Why then did he take two strikers, in Robbie Fowler and Kevin Phillips who did not play rather than more versatile players?

Enough already. The anger is starting to well up again. I do not believe that England's players, man for man, are worse than Portugal's or Romania's or that there is insufficient quality in the country. There were enough good players in 1996 and a large majority of them remain, along with a young promising crop, among them Gerrard, Gareth Barry and Joe Gascoigne, sorry Cole.

The worry is that they will flounder in the current stormy sea, rather than bask on the beach of a new, nurturing national team environment. The chances are remote that they and the existing experienced players, who are still needed, will ever be properly empowered by their leader in the way they were by Terry Venables in 1996.

That time, his time may sadly have gone. Keegan's certainly has. He speaks of having 10 weeks to rethink before the World Cup qualifying match against Germany at Wembley on 8 October. The time for English football to escape its denial is shorter than it thinks. Enough of King Kev. Vive le Roi.

webTitle: Zlatko Zahovic - find of the tournament

fields.headline: Zlatko Zahovic - find of the tournament
fields.trailText: He may be moody, argumentative (especially with his team-mates) and for much of last season he was on strike, but there's no doubt that Slovenia striker Zlatko Zahovic, aka ZZ Top, has been the find of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
He may be moody, argumentative (especially with his team-mates) and for much of last season he was on strike, but there's no doubt that Slovenia striker Zlatko Zahovic, aka ZZ Top, has been the find of Euro 2000.

It was a pity he could not manage a goal or two in Slovenia's final Group C game in Arnhem. Not only would that have put Norway out of their misery before their cruel exit after the final whistle, it would have given Slovenia the satisfaction of finishing on level points with Yugoslavia, and put a smile on the face of anyone who backed Zahovic at 100-1 to win the Golden Boot award.

He was never likely to do that unless Slovenia could progress beyond the group stage, but with three goals from his first two games he certainly gave it a go. Bookmakers offering such attractive odds were perhaps ignorant of the fact that Zahovic had scored 10 of his country's 15 goals in qualifying, or that the Olympiakos Piraeus striker is likely to be playing for Fiorentina in Serie A next season.

Zahovic, the 29-year-old former Porto forward, has been interesting several Premiership clubs, but is known to favour warmer climes. 'I want to play somewhere sunny,' he explained. Italy should suit him down to the ground. He has the talent, the volatile tempera ment, and the hairband. And he will probably be picked up for a relative bargain £6 million.

Although paid £1m a year in Athens and idolised by supporters, Zahovic hardly played for his club last season after going on strike in protest at the poor quality of Greek football. After a prolonged stand-off with the club chairman the pair kissed and made up, only to fall out again within weeks. Even his best friends admit Zahovic is something of a prima donna, though his national coach, Srecko Katanec, is too diplomatic to agree.
