webTitle: Spanish eyes on fame at last

fields.headline: Spanish eyes on fame at last
fields.standfirst: There is fresh optimism in the Spanish camp
fields.trailText: 'Here come Spain,' said the commentary for the film of the 1966 World Cup, Goal. 'They never seem to punch their weight at international tournaments.' The Spanish have had their 30-odd years of hurt, too.
fields.body:
Those plummy old-English tones, reading Brian Glanville's beautifully spare script, remain memorable. 'Here come Spain,' said the commentary for the film of the 1966 World Cup, Goal. 'They never seem to punch their weight at international tournaments.'

The Spanish have had their 30-odd years of hurt, too. Like the English, their club game has been so all-embracing and high-achieving as to fuel the feeling that, surely, the national team will win something one of these days. So far, it has been only the European Championship of 1964 and the football tournament of the Olympic Games they hosted in 1992.

Is the team that so thrillingly, astonishingly, overcame Yugoslavia in 96 breathtaking minutes in Bruges in midweek finally the one? If in early evening today, at the same scene of one of the greatest matches ever played they can overcome France - the first team of everybody's second favourite side rather than the reserves of Amsterdam, that is - they will surely sense themselves to be the chosen ones.

Perhaps they do already. 'Psychologically this victory will greatly help them,' Raddy Antic, once of Luton Town, twice manager of Real Madrid and a Yugoslav himself, told me, having regained his breath after that dramatic two-goal, back-from-the-brink finale. 'It is not just in the victory, but in the manner of the victory. Tonight, they grow up, I think.'

There are many reasons advanced for Spain's under-achievement. Antic cites the media pressure, though - chronologically - Italy, Argentina, Germany and Brazil, have overcome it in the modern, mass-market era.

Here, their former striker Julio Salinas: 'There is not the same feeling for the national team. June comes around and everyone will take an interest but it is not the same as in the other big football countries. They would rather Barcelona win the league rather than the national team win a championship.'

For what it is worth, this correspondent's view is that so exciting, so attacking is their domestic game, so well captured by Sky television, that all grow up wanting to be creators rather than defenders; just as in Brazil, goalkeepers have to be mad just to want to be one. In tournaments, particularly in the group stages, the foundation is a niggardly defence, of which the Spanish game is in short supply.

Besides, not all think Spain have fallen so far short. 'The distance has maybe been one minute sometimes,' says Josep Guardiola, deemed man of the match on Wednesday night, though the opinion from this privileged press seat was that the ubiquitous Ivan Helguera just pipped 'Pep'. But then Guardiola has his gold medal from '92, which may not mean much to the British, for whom the politics of sport and football dictate that they do not enter the Olympic Games, but does to the rest of the world.

'Football,' he added, 'is not always black and white. Sometimes it is grey.' Did he mean the Euro 96 quarter-final against England, when a good goal - by no less than Julio Salinas - was ruled offside and should have sent them through? 'Maybe,' he replied.

If nothing else, as with England's though less admirable win over Germany, the display against Yugoslavia has at least won them a nation's indulgence for a little while. This one deserves to. It was indeed a match that had skill and courage and incident, for good and bad, of every kind. At times, a terrible beauty of a game. The complete game. If it was too error-strewn for the purist of a previous era, one can only respond that at such a pace and intensity it was inevitable.

It was almost like watching the best of games from La Liga , not surprising since five of the Yugoslavs used to ply their trade in Spain, and lifted the spirits after Charleroi's dross 24 hours earlier. It had the bonus of sending home a Norway who bring scarcely anything to a major tournament, save redeemingly likeable supporters.

'Un gran partido,' said the Spain coach, Jose Camacho, before adding: 'I will have to think about that,' when asked if it was the most memorable game of his career, though with nine Championships, the Copa Del Rey four times, a Uefa Cup and 81 caps as a player with Real Madrid, his hesitation was understandable. One day perhaps...

The professional in Yugoslavia's canny Vujadin Boskov, a man well-versed in Spanish footballing culture having managed Real Zaragoza, Real Madrid and Sporting Gijon, could not resist lamenting injuries, a red card and and the referee's performance but eventually he conceded that, yes, it had been 'satisfaction to have played those 90 minutes'. He omitted the final six, mind.

These Yugoslavs are hard men - three sent off in three games - and try as you might, you cannot avoid the conclusion that their recent bloody social history has imbued them with a fight that can go beyond the bounds of the physically acceptable. The dismissed, disgraced Slavisa Jokanovic will be missing today against Holland, perhaps the influential Vladimir Jugovic through injury. He is one of seven on a yellow card.

They must now hope that the sinister Sinisa Mihajlovic can galvanise them anew. 'They have four days to recover but I think they have done well already,' says Antic, almost implying that the best may be behind them. 'They cannot keep playing with 10 men and expecting not to give the game away.'

Of Spain, meanwhile, Antic - about to take up the coach's job with Oviedo - believes that they have a wealth of attacking talent and will be buoyant now the burden of expectation has been lifted from them. In addition, they hope to have their talisman Fernando Hierro, one of the truly great Spanish defenders, back after a groin strain. The real France may stand up, but do not bet on a quiet death in the Venice of the North by Spain.

fields.headline: Rijkaard finally gets frank
fields.standfirst: Holland's coach is a nice man - but there is a new edge as his side aims for the big prize
fields.trailText: Simon Kuper: Frank Rijkaard began the interview by offering me a Barclays cigarette. The Dutch coach is a polite and kind man. Former team-mates like Arnold Muhren and Gerald Vanenburg talk about him with something approaching love.
fields.body:
Frank Rijkaard began the interview by offering me a Barclays cigarette. The Dutch coach is a polite and kind man. Former team-mates like Arnold Muhren and Gerald Vanenburg talk about him with something approaching love. Even Johan Cruyff hesitates to criticise him. Rijkaard is a nice guy.

So it was a shock, early in Euro 2000, to see him erupt. He had publicly erupted only once before, at the World Cup of 1990, when as a player he was sent off for spitting at the German Rudi Voller. Outside Holland he is still known chiefly for this most uncharacteristic act, and I hereby apologise for using it as the cover photograph of a book I wrote.

Rijkaard's second eruption came ten days ago at the Dutch camp in Hoenderloo. It is his custom to address press conferences in the slow and simple speech of a kind primary school teacher talking to backward children. This time he exploded.

'When there is a Euro 2000 game on TV, I sometimes walk past my players, and I see them watching with half an eye or playing cards. In the match on TV you see everyone running the fire out of their slippers, but then you see our guys look up briefly at the television set and you hear: "What a bad game!"'

It was a perfect cameo of the Dutch professional footballer. But Rijkaard was not trying to be funny. The man who became Holland's manager as fourth or fifth choice after the last World Cup is no caretaker. He may never have coached a team before, and never have aspired to this job, but he wants to transform Dutch football. And he knows exactly how he wants to do it, because he once transformed himself.

Rijkaard was born 37 years ago in Amsterdam. His father, a gifted black footballer named Herman Rijkaard, had taken the boat from the Dutch West Indian colony of Surinam with his friend and fellow player George Gullit. Both men had married white Dutch women, and settled near one another in Amsterdam. It was years before the great rush of Surinamese immigrants that was to bring the Kluivert, Seedorf and Davids families to Holland, where they would be stuck in ghettoes. The Rijkaards and Gullits were part of a small group of middle-class Surinamese men who were accepted fairly easily into Dutch society. Ruud Gullit says he only discovered he was black when he was ten years old.

He and Rijkaard grew up playing football together on a local square, the Balboaplein, and at the DWS club of Amsterdam. Even as a teenager Gullit was the louder and more confident of the two, but experts such as Johan Cruyff thought Rijkaard the more gifted footballer. He was huge, intelligent, and could do everything with a football.

He joined Ajax, and at 18 made his debut for Holland against Switzerland. Gullit replaced him at half-time, but the Swiss commentator never noticed the switch. Holland lost the match 2-1. The Dutch team, composed of naive youngsters like Gullit, Rijkaard and Marco van Basten, lost often in those days. They failed to qualify for the World Cups of 1982 and 1986 and the European Championship of 1984.

Experts said they would never make it: pretty footballers, but lacking in bite and with a penchant for conceding silly goals. Ajax eventually decided to discard Rijkaard. They offered him to Groningen, a small club in the north of Holland, but Groningen didn't want him. The young man's reputation had been destroyed by the Ajax coach, Aad de Mos, who had said after Ajax had yet again exited the European Cup in the autumn: 'You won't win the war with boys like Rijkaard and (Gerald) Vanenburg.'

The saying has become legendary. Rijkaard told me: 'The question was: how do you deal with it? I looked in the mirror and thought: "Yes, football is about something. It's not just a game for fun." So from that moment on I began to fight, to stand my man, and after every match I could look in the mirror and say, "Good or bad, I did what was within my power".'

This sounds like the pop psychology books that Rijkaard reads. You may mock, but there is no quibbling with the results. De Mos was proved right: Rijkaard never won a war. Instead he won the European Cup twice with AC Milan and once with Ajax, and the European Championship with Holland in 1988. By the time he retired in 1995 he was one of the most respected players in football.

The Dutch team today is an eleven-man version of the young Rijkaard: pretty footballers, who lose when it counts. The one great prize most of them have won was the Champions League with Ajax in 1995, when they were led from the back by a centre-half named Rijkaard who gave them a talking-to at half-time in the final.

Now Rijkaard must motivate them again. Dutch footballers need that. Left to themselves, they tend to elevate good football above winning. Hence the Hoenderloo speech.

But Rijkaard is no Kevin Keegan, no orator. He is a man of detail. 'That's what surprises me most about Frank,' says Dennis Bergkamp, another former team-mate. 'He really knows how to analyse an opponent completely.'

Rijkaard has specific advice to impart. Much of it is on a subject the Dutch traditionally disdain: defending. He gave me a masterclass.

'As a young centre-back at Ajax, I played with Wim Jansen, and of course you learn a huge amount. I made some mistakes, because we Dutchmen want to solve situations by playing football. So we look at the ball, try to judge where it will come. Eight out of ten times it's wonderful if you intercept it. "What vision!" people say. But the other two times the ball goes in behind your back and it's really just a marking error.

'Then came the moment that I joined the squad for the European Championship of 1988 and it became clear that I'd have to play centre-back. One thing was crystal clear to me: if you're centre-back, you first of all have to perform your task.

'What I did was watch the striker very closely. If the ball went to the wing, I would touch him so that I knew if he was going forward or backwards.And then he went forward and I was with him. Very often I was lying in between when someone wanted to shoot, or I gave a little push when someone wanted to head. I mean, it doesn't always go right, but that was the intention. For me it was living proof that that is how you defend.'

Indeed: this most cultured of footballers erased strikers like Gary Lineker and Oleg Protassov from games. It is a shame he finished only third in the voting for player of the tournament, behind his more obvious team-mates Van Basten (scored five goals) and Gullit (wore long Rastafarian hair).

Rijkaard continued: 'After your career you go to matches and you see so many unnecessary goals. Because a person is just looking where the ball is and not his opponent. Well, a ball alone has never scored a goal.'

Throwing yourself in front of the ball, says Rijkaard, might sound mucky but can be the difference between winning and losing. That difference has traditionally been of little interest to the Dutch. Cruyff himself says that Holland in effect won the World Cup of 1974, even though they lost in the final, because everyone remembers their beautiful play.

Rijkaard diagrees. He grew up watching Cruyff, was coached by him at Ajax, quarrelled with him many times, eventually walked out, and landed up at AC Milan. There he became something of an Italian. Even today he is distinguished among the casual Dutch by his tailored Italian suits, and at Euro 2000 press conferences he demonstrates an excellent use of the language. (His English is also excellent, and this tournament he has occasionally assisted his translator, the cricket-loving Dutch press officer Rob de Leede.)

In Italy, as Cruyff notes with a certain wonder, what matters is winning. Rijkaard imbibed that. Why, I asked him, did Holland switch recently from white shorts to the black ones they wore in the 1970s?

'This all sounds a bit airy,' said Rijkaard, 'because it's not about the shorts, but I felt that black emits more power. White: clean, neat and attractive, attractive football. Black is that you throw yourself in front of the ball in the last minute and prevent a goal. It's a feeling. That's why I chose it.'

Until this week, this was all just talk. Only at Euro 2000 is Rijkaard starting to prove himself. For two years beforehand his team played only friendlies. At one point they went 16 months without winning a game, making him Holland's least successful manager since 1951. The leader of the far-left Socialist Party demanded his dismissal.

Rijkaard experimented endlessly, yet began Euro 2000 with a shaky 1-0 win against the Czech Republic. He then dropped Clarence Seedorf, who had also been dropped by Rijkaard's predecessor, Guus Hiddink, after the first match of the World Cup. The first half of Holland's second game, against Denmark, was scoreless and depressing. Then Rijkaard brought on Ronald de Boer for Marc Overmars, and moved Boudewijn Zenden to the left wing. Now Holland were playing with ten of the players who had started the semi-final of the World Cup against Brazil under Hiddink two years ago, nine of them playing in the same positions they had then. Almost instantly the Dutch scored three goals.

In the game against France, a somewhat makeshift team played a recognisable version of Hiddink's system. What, then, has Rijkaard contributed? 'The core was clear even then,' he admits. The style, too, has scarcely changed. The Dutch school - one-touch passing, use of the wings, attack - dates back to the 1960s and was restored by Cruyff when he became manager of Ajax in 1985. Rijkaard, a member of the Dutch footballing establishment, does not question it.

But he aims to add a crucial nuance: defence. This Dutch side is more calculating than most of its predecessors. Frank de Boer sticks behind his defence almost like an Italian sweeper, Ronald de Boer dived to win a crucial penalty against the Czechs, and the keepers have been hitting long punts at Patrick Kluivert's head. So far it has worked: after going 3-2 up against France with an hour to play, Holland slowed down the game and barely gave away a chance - it would have done a good German side proud.

Rijkaard has achieved something else: he has made the Dutch camp perhaps the most harmonious of Euro 2000. The foreign stereotype that the Dutch are about to start eating each other is just that - a foreign stereotype. This week Seedorf told an Italian newspaper that the Dutch press is racist, but even a statement as raw as that failed to split the players into two camps of rival colours, as briefly happened at Euro 96.

'Guus Hiddink tore down that barrier,' Rijkaard told me. 'I have continued his line. Keeping an eye on who sits at which table at meals, seeing who rooms with whom. I made Edgar Davids vice-captain. Nothing to do with colour, just because he was playing excellently and because he lives like an athlete. But those are all details that change things in the group. The relations are now totally equal.'

Rijkaard deserves great credit for this. It is not simply that he is half black and half white, in the same way that as a coach he is part Dutch and part Italian. It is also that he is an impressive character.

Everyone respects him. The black players grew up with his poster on their walls. No one would ever suspect him of pandering to anyone. He may not be a great coach, but there is general agreement that he is a good man.

As we leave his office, he shows me a card bearing a Chinese character that was given him by Chinese journalists. 'It's my name in Chinese,' he says. 'At least I hope it's my name in Chinese. It might be a curse.'

Rijkaard could win Euro 2000 and still be cursed. His compatriots want Holland to attack. Winning alone is not enough. Italy were lauded at home for winning their first three games in cowardly fashion. But as Rijkaard presumably knows, Holland is not Italy. In Holland, the suits, the food and the defenders are all much worse.

'He really knows how to analyse an opponent completely.' Rijkaard has specific advice to impart. Much of it is on a subject the Dutch traditionally disdain: defending. He gave me a masterclass. 'As a young centre-back at Ajax, I played with Wim Jansen, and of course you learn a huge amount. I made some mistakes, because we Dutchmen want to solve situations by playing football. So we look at the ball, try to judge where it will come. Eight out of ten times it's wonderful if you intercept it. "What vision!" people say. But the other two times the ball goes in behind your back and it's really just a marking error. 'Then came the moment that I joined the squad for the European Championship of 1988 and it became clear that I'd have to play centre-back. One thing was crystal clear to me: if you're centre-back, you first of all have to perform your task. 'What I did was watch the striker very closely. If the ball went to the wing, I would touch him so that I knew if he was going forward or backwards.And then he went forward and I was with him. Very often I was lying in between when someone wanted to shoot, or I gave a little push when someone wanted to head. I mean, it doesn't always go right, but that was the intention. For me it was living proof that that is how you defend.' Indeed: this most cultured of footballers erased strikers like Gary Lineker and Oleg Protassov from games. It is a shame he finished only third in the voting for player of the tournament, behind his more obvious team-mates Van Basten (scored five goals) and Gullit (wore long Rastafarian hair). Rijkaard continued: 'After your career you go to matches and you see so many unnecessary goals. Because a person is just looking where the ball is and not his opponent. Well, a ball alone has never scored a goal.' Throwing yourself in front of the ball, says Rijkaard, might sound mucky but can be the difference between winning and losing. That difference has traditionally been of little interest to the Dutch. Cruyff himself says that Holland in effect won the World Cup of 1974, even though they lost in the final, because everyone remembers their beautiful play. Rijkaard diagrees. He grew up watching Cruyff, was coached by him at Ajax, quarrelled with him many times, eventually walked out, and landed up at AC Milan. There he became something of an Italian. Even today he is distinguished among the casual Dutch by his tailored Italian suits, and at Euro 2000 press conferences he demonstrates an excellent use of the language. (His English is also excellent, and this tournament he has occasionally assisted his translator, the cricket-loving Dutch press officer Rob de Leede.) In Italy, as Cruyff notes with a certain wonder, what matters is winning. Rijkaard imbibed that. Why, I asked him, did Holland switch recently from white shorts to the black ones they wore in the 1970s? 'This all sounds a bit airy,' said Rijkaard, 'because it's not about the shorts, but I felt that black emits more power. White: clean, neat and attractive, attractive football. Black is that you throw yourself in front of the ball in the last minute and prevent a goal. It's a feeling. That's why I chose it.' Until this week, this was all just talk. Only at Euro 2000 is Rijkaard starting to prove himself. For two years beforehand his team played only friendlies. At one point they went 16 months without winning a game, making him Holland's least successful manager since 1951. The leader of the far-left Socialist Party demanded his dismissal. Rijkaard experimented endlessly, yet began Euro 2000 with a shaky 1-0 win against the Czech Republic. He then dropped Clarence Seedorf, who had also been dropped by Rijkaard's predecessor, Guus Hiddink, after the first match of the World Cup. The first half of Holland's second game, against Denmark, was scoreless and depressing. Then Rijkaard brought on Ronald de Boer for Marc Overmars, and moved Boudewijn Zenden to the left wing. Now Holland were playing with ten of the players who had started the semi-final of the World Cup against Brazil under Hiddink two years ago, nine of them playing in the same positions they had then. Almost instantly the Dutch scored three goals. In the game against France, a somewhat makeshift team played a recognisable version of Hiddink's system. What, then, has Rijkaard contributed? 'The core was clear even then,' he admits. The style, too, has scarcely changed. The Dutch school - one-touch passing, use of the wings, attack - dates back to the 1960s and was restored by Cruyff when he became manager of Ajax in 1985. Rijkaard, a member of the Dutch footballing establishment, does not question it. But he aims to add a crucial nuance: defence. This Dutch side is more calculating than most of its predecessors. Frank de Boer sticks behind his defence almost like an Italian sweeper, Ronald de Boer dived to win a crucial penalty against the Czechs, and the keepers have been hitting long punts at Patrick Kluivert's head. So far it has worked: after going 3-2 up against France with an hour to play, Holland slowed down the game and barely gave away a chance - it would have done a good German side proud. Rijkaard has achieved something else: he has made the Dutch camp perhaps the most harmonious of Euro 2000. The foreign stereotype that the Dutch are about to start eating each other is just that - a foreign stereotype. This week Seedorf told an Italian newspaper that the Dutch press is racist, but even a statement as raw as that failed to split the players into two camps of rival colours, as briefly happened at Euro 96. 'Guus Hiddink tore down that barrier,' Rijkaard told me. 'I have continued his line. Keeping an eye on who sits at which table at meals, seeing who rooms with whom. I made Edgar Davids vice-captain. Nothing to do with colour, just because he was playing excellently and because he lives like an athlete. But those are all details that change things in the group. The relations are now totally equal.' Rijkaard deserves great credit for this. It is not simply that he is half black and half white, in the same way that as a coach he is part Dutch and part Italian. It is also that he is an impressive character. Everyone respects him. The black players grew up with his poster on their walls. No one would ever suspect him of pandering to anyone. He may not be a great coach, but there is general agreement that he is a good man. As we leave his office, he shows me a card bearing a Chinese character that was given him by Chinese journalists. 'It's my name in Chinese,' he says. 'At least I hope it's my name in Chinese. It might be a curse.' Rijkaard could win Euro 2000 and still be cursed. His compatriots want Holland to attack. Winning alone is not enough. Italy were lauded at home for winning their first three games in cowardly fashion. But as Rijkaard presumably knows, Holland is not Italy. In Holland, the suits, the food and the defenders are all much worse.

fields.headline: Yugoslavia ready to gatecrash hosts
fields.trailText: Revenge is a dish best served cold, as they now say in Belgrade. After two years chilling, Yugoslavia believe the day has finally arrived when Holland suffers.
fields.body:
Revenge is a dish best served cold, as they now say in Belgrade. After two years chilling, Yugoslavia believe the day has finally arrived when Holland suffers.

The confident Dutch team do not seem in the slightest bit bothered by the threat, but it is a real one. Yugoslavia are on a mission and have no doubt that they will win tonight's quarter-final in Rotterdam to make amends for their injury-time defeat in the last 16 of the World Cup finals two years ago.

Yugoslavia, back in the European Championships for the first time since 1988, still respond with a collective shudder when the name of Patrick Kluivert enters conversation. He is the Dutch striker who knocked them out of the World Cup when he struck Holland's winner two minutes into injury time in France 98.

The memories seem even harsher in the mind of Predrag Mijatovic as the Yugoslav and Fiorentina striker missed a penalty in that match. 'I would love to have the opportunity to take another penalty against Holland,' Mijatovic said yesterday after Yugoslavia had made a two-hour journey from their Antwerp training camp to a new base in central Rotterdam. 'The memory of the World Cup game still lives with us - and me especially because of my miss.

'But I know we will beat them this time and make it through to the semi-finals. I have heard the Dutch players talking and they seem to underestimate us.That is a big mistake which we will make them pay_'

Mijatovic's eyes take on a severe shade of black close-up and his steely glare leaves you in no doubt that he is not joking. He explained: 'The Dutch seem to have the advantages of knowing the stadium and their home support, but we have been getting better and better with every game.

'We hear the Dutch comments, we remember the World Cup and we need no more motivation than that. I just hope I have the opportunity to take another penalty. I am 31 and this is only my first European Championship, it may be my last too, and we have come here to try to win the trophy.'

Yugoslav coach Vujadin Boskov is similarly confident even though Mateja Kezman and Slavisa Jokanovic are suspended and there are injury doubts concerning midfielder Vladimir Jugovic and defender Goran Djorovic.

Boskov said: 'We are better than we were when Holland beat us two years ago, but I don't think they have made the same improvement. I will not outline their weaknesses although I have seen things we can exploit in the Dutch side. It will be very difficult, of course, but I know we have better players than them individually.'

Mijatovic is one of Boskov's elite. Free of the injury problems that hindered him during his final season at Real Madrid in 1998-99, he has declared himself fully fit to partner Savo Milosevic in attack tonight.. There is strong talk of them pairing up for Fiorentina next season if the Italian side can find £15million to take former Aston Villa man Milosevic from Real Zaragoza.

'SAVO AND I are great friends on and off the pitch,' Mijatovic added. 'We have played together for a long time and now Savo has shown is qualities with four goals in the tournament so far. I am confident he can score again when we play Holland.'

Not that everything has been straightforward for Yugoslavia. They have met some opposition from Belgians with memories of the war in the Balkans and the Yugoslav national anthem has been booed before matches. Before they departed for Rotterdam, police arrived at their hotel amid reports of masked gunmen on the prowl.

Mijatovic, his temper rising, added: 'There was no problem, I think it was a misunderstanding. Look, we are here to play football and talk about football, nothing else.'

That nothing includes their perceived disciplinary problems. Uefa yesterday fined the Yugoslav FA £48,000 for the poor behaviour of their supporters. They cited their last match against Spain which included: one pitch invasion, one referee struck by a coin, 13 flares lit in stands and one flare thrown on the pitch. The players' behaviour did not help as Uefa pointed to their 12 bookings and three dismissals after only three group games.

Boskov concluded: 'The referees are only human and make mistakes. I've told my players that only the captain is allowed to talk to the referee from now on. Let him get on with that - then he and the rest of them can get on with beating Holland.'

Dirty Yugoslavs...

Booked so far: Mihajlovic, Jokanovic, Jugovic, Drulovic, Nadj, Jokanovic, Stojkovic, Komljenovic, Saveljic, Stankovic

Total - 10 players

Sent off so far: Mihajlovic (second bookable offence), Kezman (dangerous play), Jokanovic (second bookable offence)

Total - 3 players

Not booked yet: Kralj, Dudic, Kovacevic, Mijatovic, Djorovic, Djukic, Milosevic

Total - 7 players

fields.headline: New order down south
fields.trailText: Five of Euro 2000's eight quarter-finalists hail from the Mediterranean, symbolic of a shift in power away from the physical north and towards the stirring, soulful style of the south.
fields.body:
Mustafa Denizli has noticed an intriguing new trend in European football. Five of Euro 2000's eight quarter-finalists hail from the Mediterranean, symbolic of a shift in power away from the physical north and towards the stirring, soulful style of the south. Turkey joined Italy, France, Spain and, as far as he is concerned, best of the lot Portugal.

This was by no means the most seductive show so far from Humberto Coelho's delightful team. Still, they cannot help but impress. Not too long ago they might have allowed themselves to be outscrapped by an increasingly gutsy Turkey, but now they have a work ethic to match their wit. Upon that firm foundation they showed flashes of the dazzle which has won them so many friends in the Low Countries.

The spiritual home of total football warmed to a team capable of expert technique and fluid movement. A shimmy from Figo, a dribble from Conceicao, a surge from Rui Costa, and now they even possess the finishing touch in the shape of the exuberant Nuno Gomes. Johan Cruyff, who has been so critical of the current Dutch incarnation, might even find them pleasing.

Portugal's supremely gifted adventurous proved a hurdle too far for Turkey. Playing with 10 men for more than an hour after Alpay was ordered off - for clouting the melodramatic Fernando Couto - proved too much for a team still finding their feet at the highest level.

To their credit, Turkey showed feisty spirit after the red card, summoning the determination to earn a penalty. Arif blundered. Food for thought for the future.

So, the Euro 2000 odyssey is over. They should not be too disconsolate - this is not a journey's end but a stop-off point. The consolation is that Turkey will benefit from the experience, a blip on their learning curve with an admirably steep trajectory.

Where before Turkey approached contests against Europe's finest with such trepidation a mere two or three goal defeat was the summit of their ambitions, now they genuinely believe they can master every opponent. Holland and Germany were felled by the Turkish sword in the past couple of years. On a momentous night in May Galatasaray Uefa Cup triumph over Arsenal further feathered the cap.

Historic markers have come thick and fast. This European Championship has witnessed their first goal, their first win, their first successfully negotiated group stage in a major tournament. Compared to the blunt battlers who sweated but slipped quietly out Euro 96, they are a more sophisticated unit.

It has been a fascinating progression. The revolution stems from their nadir, an 8-0 thumping doled out by England in the late 80s (an eager apprentice called Hakan Sukur was 15 at the time). Enough is enough, they said. No more ritual humiliations.

Their mission is to constantly improve, and it will be intriguing to see how they develop now their most talented players are beginning to try their luck abroad. Hakan Sukur is bound for Italy, Arif and Tayfun have signed for Real Sociedad, Tugay is at Rangers.

So 15,000 and boisterous Turks came in expectation rather than hope but in the end Portugal stunned them into silence.

The European order might be warming towards the Mediterranean, but, for the time being at least, some countries are hotter than others. Full steam ahead for the Portuguese, who await the winners of that potentially sizzling duel between Spain and France.

webTitle: It's time to hand English football over to the fairer sex

fields.headline: It's time to hand English football over to the fairer sex
fields.trailText: Anyone from Britain (the Dutch use the word interchangeably with 'England') has had a lot of explaining to do here since the riots in Charleroi and Brussels.
fields.body:
Last Sunday two British friends and I were watching Spain-Slovenia on television in an Amsterdam comedy café. The comedians doing the commentary heard us speaking English and broke into a rendition of God Save the Queen .

Then they said in Dutch: 'Now get out.'

They did not say it in a comic spirit. Anyone from Britain (the Dutch use the word interchangeably with 'England') has had a lot of explaining to do here since the riots in Charleroi and Brussels.

The Dutch and Belgians are fed up. It was not that the hooligans did any particular physical damage. They threw a few plastic chairs and broke some windows, leaving the mayor of Charleroi saying he had expected much worse. But they have done even more harm to Britain's image abroad than have the England football team. A thousand British Council exhibitions and tours by Prince Philip will not compensate. The French press no longer calls young Englishmen abroad les rosbifs; now it's les fuckoffs.

There seem to be two options. The first is to ban England from international tournaments, which would solve the problem at a stroke. The second is to muddle on as we have for the past 20 years.

Before the next World Cup, no doubt, there will be more schemes to keep known hooligans at home. No doubt, too, there will be nights of rioting in Osaka or Pyongyang (if the North Koreans are unlucky enough to get any World Cup games) by hooligans previously unknown to the British police.

However, there is a third option. It is drastic and currently illegal. But it would instantly make England the world's favourite visiting team. Only British women should be allowed to attend England matches abroad. Any British man trying to enter the country where the game was being played would be asked the purpose of his visit. If he could show that he was on business or on holiday, he would be admitted. If he then tried to go to the match, he would be expelled.

No longer would the police only be allowed to bar known hooligans, letting the other drunken, tattooed, shirtless characters through. No one likely to cause trouble would even get close. A few exceptions could be made. Males aged under 13 or over 65 would be allowed to attend matches. So would former England players, except those capped only by Graham Taylor, and a few male journalists from the more impressive newspapers. Otherwise, the British section of the crowd would be all-female. The night before an England match would become a carnival in the host city.

The opposition fans would love it (think of Italy-England or France-England). The England players, freed of being abused by yobs, would be galvanised by the stands full of women. The FA's sleepy campaign to entice more females into domestic matches would receive a stimulus. And if admitting only women sounds sexist, what about last century's policy of effectively admitting only men?

The crucial point is that the image of Britain would be instantly transformed. To be the only national team followed predominantly by women would look terrifically modern and cool, and would therefore please Tony Blair. England would at last be seen as making love not war. Think how much the pictures of dancing Brazilian women at World Cup matches have done for Brazil's image in the world. Changing the law to stop freedom of movement within the European Union and allow gender discrimination might be asking a bit much. In that case, simply stop British men entering the stadium.

That must be legal: it is already possible to have women-only bars and men-only clubs. With no matches to go to, British men would quickly give up travelling to tournaments. In any case, the hooligans would soon eschew following England as effeminate.

webTitle: Finns see a chance to fly

fields.headline: Finns see a chance to fly
fields.standfirst: England's demise augurs well for Finland in the World Cup qualifiers
fields.trailText: Reaction in Germany was fierce. 'Ribbeck's resignation was shown live on both major stations which only happens when the Chancellor quits. There is the feeling of a big crisis.'
fields.body:
Confronting the massed media moments after masterminding German football's biggest humiliation in living memory, Erich Ribbeck wore the tormented look of a man in front of a firing squad. Then somebody threw him a last cigarette. Wasn't there some comfort to be drawn from the fact at least England had gone out too? Ribbeck called it the icing on the cake - a bizarre choice of analogy but understandable given his predicament - and his interrogators sniggered.

Reaction in Germany was fierce. 'Ribbeck's resignation was shown live on both major stations which only happens when the Chancellor quits. There is the feeling of a big crisis,' said Suddeutsche Zeitung's Christoph Biermann. 'It is worse than losing to Croatia in France 98. That was a quarter-final. This time we are bottom of a poor group with only one point and one goal, the worst performance since the 1938 World Cup. Everybody is asking what is wrong with German football?

'The debate has turned to the whole structure, and what changes need to be made to bring out young talent like the French system. It will take at least 10 years. During that time I expect similar problems to those England had such as qualifying for World Cups and so on.'

What a hoot for the rest of the world, the sight of two fading old curmudgeons taking solace in the fact the other is just as miserable as they are. England and Germany's demise has been a source of mild amusement.

But no nations are as absorbed by it all as Finland, Greece and Albania. Grouped together with England and Germany for the 2002 World Cup qualifiers, what better boost than the sight of the two favourites in disarray. Suddenly they are feeling upbeat about their chances.

One of Finland's most celebrated football thinkers sees no reason why his country cannot qualify at the expense of one of Europe's limping giants. The former national coach-come-pundit Martti Kuusela, has been in the Low Countries observing with particular interest.

There is a hint of mischief in his voice as he enthuses, 'Why can't we qualify? I have heard the wise people say that the ball is round. There are no more small teams, and if the big countries underestimate Finland they will find we can make a surprise.'

Kuusela will probably be giving tips on his analysis of England and Germany to his friends inside the Finnish FA. So why, in his opinion, did they fail during Euro 2000? fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: 25 June
fields.body:
Keown denial

Martin Keown has hit back at reports that appeared in several newspapers suggesting he had been critical of Kevin Keegan's tactics. The England defender was quoted yesterday as saying: 'I was disturbed to read in a number of newspapers comments attributed to me - but not said by me - suggesting that I was critical of both the England team and the manager, Kevin Keegan.

'I believe that by use of these comments there has been an orchestrated campaign to spin a story suggesting I am critical of the England set-up.

'Nothing could be further from the truth. I... would not do or say anything to give ammunition to those who would attempt to undermine both the manager and the team.'

He had obviously forgotten what he wrote in his own contribution to the press just the day before, in his Daily Telegraph column on Friday.

'The bottom line is that we were inept tactically, we were exposed against teams we should have beaten, we lacked a pattern in our play at times and, ultimately, individual and collective tactical mistakes cost us dearly,' he wrote, adding, 'If you play a passing game, you have to use the right structure.'

Body blow

Some of the English fans arrested by the Belgian police for causing havoc in Brussels the night before England-Germany responded with a humour that was, sadly, untypical. After being wrestled onto the floor, made to lie face down and strapped into sharp-edged plastic handcuffs, a row of bodies suddenly lapsed into a chorus of Always Look on the Bright Side of Life. Their Belgian captors didn't see the funny side, however, and an officer produced his truncheon and went down the line giving each man a tap on the head until they shut up. 'It looked and sounded like someone going up the musical scale on a glockenspiel,' laughed one British security official.

Stewards a success

Amazingly, UEFA's controversial policy of deploying only stewards to maintain order inside match venues, rather than uniformed police, has proved a success. Although there has been trouble in the centres of Brussels and Charleroi, very few nasty incidents have occurred inside grounds. Fears that the only visible peacekeepers being civilians in blue-and-yellow stewards' kit would encourage trouble have proved misplaced. Happily, the hit-and-miss segregation seen at most games has not produced mayhem.

Romanians in ticket probe

The Romanian FA has been asked to explain to Uefa how about 600 England fans suddenly appeared in the Romanian end in Charleroi just before kick-off last Tuesday. 'It should have been impossible, given our strict ticketing arrangements,' said Euro 2000's Richard van der Eijk. 'All the tickets in that end were for Romanians only.' He denied these were ticketless England fans or that there had been an overspill from the three-tier main stand. So did the Romanian FA sell some of their allocation to rival fans? 'We're investigating,' says van der Eijk.

Helpline for 'hooligans'

Not all English fans are thugs, though, and even the Belgian police many of the 921 English fans arrested and/or deported had done nothing wrong except not carry their passport. That's why the Football Supporters Association yesterday launched a campaign to get compensation for anyone wrongly arrested or sent home and ensure they do not appear on future lists of 'hooligans'. Anyone who feels mistreated can ring the FSA on 020 8541 3399 or email details of what happened to them to fsa_euro2000@hotmail.com.

There's only one David Beckham

A survey of every group match at the tournament by Uefa's Technical Study Group (TSG), coordinated by former Scotland boss Andy Roxburgh, head of Uefa's technical department, and including ex-Blackburn manager Roy Hodgson and Liverpool coach Gérard Houllier, has produced a list of the best 50 players at these championships. And, surprise, surprise, only one England player, Manchester United's David Beckham, appears on the list.

The best-represented side in the survey is Holland, with eight players among the top 50, followed by World Cup holders France, Portugal and Italy, each with seven.

Portugal, with the four men - Manuel Rui Costa, Luis Figo, Sergio Conceicao and Paulo Bento - who ran rings around England in their opening match, had the most midfielders.

The top 50 will be whittled down to an all-star squad of 16 after the semi-finals, with the winners being announced by Pele shortly before the final in Rotterdam on 2July.

webTitle: Didier shock as Juve are charged

fields.headline: Didier shock as Juve are charged
fields.trailText: Didier Deschamps, the Chelsea midfielder and World Cup winning captain of France, has his name embarrassingly linked to a long-running Italian drugs investigation.
fields.body:
Didier Deschamps, the Chelsea midfielder and World Cup winning captain of France, has his name embarrassingly linked to a long-running Italian drugs investigation.

Turin magistrate Raffaele Guariniello will publish the result of his judicial inquiry into alleged doping offences by Juventus next week. According to a report in Italian news magazine Panorama , he is accusing them of sporting fraud for having won matches and trophies from 1994-98 through the use of performance-enhancing drugs. Juventus deny all the charges.

Deschamps, who played for Juventus during the whole of the period in question, was asked to give witness statements by Guariniello on three separate occasions. His name appears in evidence on club medical records which show the level of cells in his blood to have been 51.2 per cent of a sample.

Such readings raise the suspicion - but not the proof - that the sportsman concerned has taken EPO, the wonder drug for athletes, most notoriously professional cyclists, that helps them beat fatigue.

Luigi Chiappero, lawyer for Juventus told Panorama that Deschamps had produced a reading of more than 50 per cent. He later told Observer Sport : 'There is nothing inaccurate in the Panorama article .'

Investigators discovered that Angelo di Livio, now with Fiorentina, was the only other Juventus player with a similar reading. Cyclists and skiers found to have such ratios are not allowed to perform by their governing bodies on the grounds their health could be in danger.

EPO, a naturally occurring hormone, increases the number of red corpuscles in the blood and thus the flow of oxygen. 'It has the same effect as blood doping ,' said John Budgett, Chief Medical Officer of the British Olympic Association. 'The vast majority of athletes show levels of 45-47 per cent. It is very rare to see 49 and 50. We do a lot of blood tests and it is incredibly rare to find one higher than 50. You cannot say for certain it is EPO in such cases. A person could have a naturally high reading and dehydration or a spell at altitude could have made it higher. But it is incredibly suspicious.'

Deschamps - and perhaps it is no coincidence - is in the middle of a stand-off with the French media. Why has Deschamps, the usually communicative captain, fallen silent with his world champions favourites to become the first team to follow up global success by adding the European title? For one thing, he is fed up with his place in the team being questioned after a season of indifferent form with Chelsea. Patrick Vieira, of Arsenal, is being touted as his replacement.

But France Football , the magazine that chooses the European Player of the Year, suggests the abnormal blood reading revealed in Italy may be among the reasons, too.

The inquiry was launched after Zdenek Zeman, then coach of Roma, openly accused Juventus two years ago of using drugs, alleging that their former star Gianluca Vialli, a Chelsea player at the time and now Deschamps's boss at Stamford Bridge, and Alessandro Del Piero had both shown unnatural muscle growth.

Vialli vehemently rejected any wrong-doing and threatened to sue. Investigators say five of the 19 different drugs found on the shelves of the Juventus medical room - Bentelan, Flantadin, Deflan, Flebocortid and Solumedrol - contained banned anti- inflammatory substances. Juventus deny giving them to players.

Juventus also refute the inquiry claims that they used anti-depressants and pain-killers not as treatments but for performance-enhancing reasons and prescribed large doses of creatine without consideration for harmful side-effects.

Guariniello, having no proof that EPO was used - none was found on Juventus premises - does, however, accuse them of not taking the necessary precautionary measures when faced with abnormal medical results.

Juventus will go on trial later this year and both Deschamps and Vialli are likely to be among the witnesses in court.

fields.headline: Gomes double blow
fields.standfirst: Portugal are in the semi-finals but this time it's not like watching Brazil
fields.trailText: Portugal became the first team into the semi-finals with a comfortable if unspectacular victory over a Turkish side reduced to 10 men for over an hour.
fields.body:
Portugal became the first team into the semi-finals with a comfortable victory over a Turkish side reduced to 10 men for over an hour, but though it was easy in the end, a somewhat laboured performance took a little of the shine from their new-found reputation as the Brazil of Europe.

This is still the best Portuguese side since 1984 and one eminently worth watching, but one can confidently expect France or Spain to give them a much more searching examination in Brussels on Wednesday. In addition to having defensive mainstay Alpay Ozalan dismissed on the half hour, Turkey were generous enough to miss a penalty at half-time that would have put them back into contention at 1-1.

After humiliating Germany with their reserve team, Portugal showed two changes from the side that beat England in Eindhoven. Costinha and Sergio Conceiçao were preferred to Abel Xavier and Vidigal, the former having made a case for selection with his hat-trick against the Germans, even if he does tend to fill the same right-sided role as Luis Figo.

Figo actually started on the left wing, not that he stays anywhere for long, and was back on the right by the time Portugal put together their first promising passing move after 11 minutes. Figo, Conceiçao and Joao Pinto had a clear overlap as the Turkish defence struggled to get back from a free-kick, but the final ball to Pinto was overhit.

Already it was clear Portugal were not in the sort of dazzling form that so bemused England. Asked his opinion of his quarter-final opponents, Turkey's coach, Mustafa Denizli, said he thought Portugal were the best team in the tournament. If this was a cunning plan to get Humberto Coelho's team to believe their own publicity it worked for most of the first half.

Rui Costa was dispossessed when over-elaborating on the ball, Joao Pinto's shot wastefully wide with better placed colleagues screaming for a pass, and Costinha failed to score at the far post from Figo's corner after the Turkish defence had given him time to trap the ball and look up to place his shot. In fairness Rustu Recber made a fine save, but this was not the pin-sharp Portuguese finishing we had been led to expect.

Hakan Sukur gave Portugal a wake-up call in the 27th minute by beating Fernando Couto to Ogun Temizkanolgu's free-kick for a header that flew inches over Vitor Baia's crossbar, but the incident on which the match turned arrived two minutes later.

Joao Pinto had just received the first caution of the afternoon for a trip on Hakan Unsal, when from the free-kick Couto won a defen sive header against Alpay then collapsed as if poleaxed. Couto had actually collided with a team-mate, but the Dutch referee had spotted Alpay raising a fist in frustration and pushing at the Portuguese defender and produced an immediate red card.

Coach Denizli said afterwards: 'Alpay is not a dirty player, in his 15 previous games he has had no cards at all, not even a yellow. Incidents like that change the course of matches.'

With Turkey down to 10 men the immediate upshot was a descent into vindictiveness and bad temper. Okan Buruk, Couto, Rui Costa and Costinha were all cautioned in quick succession, but just as one of the least distinguished first halves of the competition was drawing to a close the game sprang dramatically to life.

First Portugal took the lead, when a Figo cross from the right was missed by Ogan but accurately met by Nuno Gomes' stooping header. Then in stoppage time Couto brought down Arif Erdem in the penalty area and the referee pointed to the spot.

It appeared a harsh deci sion, since Couto's challenge was mostly shoulder and his foot only made contact with the ball, but it mattered little since Turkey were unable to take advantage. Arif hit his penalty straight and Baia stood his ground to save.

Turkey seemed to decide it was not going to be their day, for all the stuffing went out of them in the second half. Figo danced past a distracted Hakan Unsal on the right to cut the ball back from the byline to leave Gomes the simplest of tap-ins for his second goal, Jorge Costa somehow managed to miss from two feet out from a Figo corner, then Gomes failed to claim-his hat-trick from a similar distance in the 70th minute.

Coelho was not pleased with his side's finishing. 'It was a lucky for us that they missed the penalty. I was pleased with the performance, if not the finishing. We had plenty of chances and only scored two goals.'

fields.headline: Are we missing Miss-a-lot-evic?
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Milosevic can afford to be charming at the moment. After 21 goals in La Liga for Real Zaragoza last season, as well as four so far at Euro 2000, a move to a bigger club is in the offing.
fields.body:
'Savo, a word with the English press?' you ventured hopefully as Euro 2000's top scorer moved towards the Yugoslavs' team bus after the epic match against Spain. The expectation might have been for him to expectorate given his experiences with Aston Villa, but instead he smiled and walked over.

Milosevic can afford to be charming at the moment. After 21 goals in La Liga for Real Zaragoza last season, 24 in 47 for his country, as well as four so far at the tournament, a move to a bigger club is in the offing. Though Real Madrid and Barcelona are not thought to be interested, Valencia are, along with Inter. Back to the Premiership? 'You never know,' he replies.

There were those of us who thought Milosevic a promising talent during his time in England - if not those who called him 'Miss-a-lot-evic' - as a spectacular volleyed goal in Villa's League Cup win over Leeds United at Wembley proved.

The pleas of Villa's manager Brian Little that he was still a young player learning to curb hot-headedness cut little ice with the jeering fans towards whom he spat during a game at Blackburn and soon Savo was off to sunny Spain.

'I had a difficult time in England, but I don't blame anybody,' he says in perfect, deep-voiced English. 'I played three years and 100 games for Aston Villa and don't regret it. It was a great experience and I have used that in Spain. Spanish football is very much like Yugoslav football, tactically and technically, very attacking, and it was easy to adjust.'

Neither is he of the striking type who mouth platitudes about it not mattering who scores as long as the team wins. 'I feel good about being top scorer,' he says. 'Especially as I started the tournament on the bench. I always have confidence in myself and after my season in Spain I have good reason.

'I can always score goals, no matter what some people in Eng land may think. In fact, my object now is to become the record Yugoslavia scorer of all time - I will play until I fall down for my country.'

It has been clear from his performances so far, not just in his tap-in goals and his well-timed run and header against Spain, that he has added much to his game.

His close control has been of the type England could do with in holding the ball up and there was a moment on Wednesday night when he also cleverly got to the byline to set up a chance - right-footed, too. At 26, he has the legs to help out ageing colleagues, which has gone a long way towards taking his team to the quarter-finals despite their being reduced in every group game to 10 men. That fact, and some fiery fans, has earned the Yugoslavs some antipathy, quite without the hostility born of years of warfare.

'I don't like to mix politics and sport,' says Milosevic, 'but we can prove to the world that we are normal people like anybody else and we are trying hard to convince them that there can be better things about the Serbs.'

fields.headline: 'Pulp' friction at Waterstone's
fields.trailText: Novelist Will Self has launched a public attack on the management of the Waterstone's chain of bookshops.
fields.body:
Novelist Will Self has launched a public attack on the management of the Waterstone's chain of bookshops.

The chain's decision to cut back on stocks will lead, he said, to 'cultural impoverishment' and to 'wall-to-wall pulp' in bookshops.

Self championed the cause of Robert Topping, a recently sacked manager of the Deansgate branch in Manchester, on Radio 4's Today programme and accused Waterstone's of undervaluing experienced booksellers.

This week employees of the chain all around Britain have been silently rebelling against new instructions from its owner, HMV Media, which has asked them to get rid of older 'backlist' titles. Managers of at least five major shops have ignored the management edict. The Bookseller magazine reports this week that up to 20 managers have received official warnings over high stock levels.

Self, who rose to fame with his controversial first novels Cock and Bull Story and My Idea of Fun , was delivering his regular Saturday morning radio essay, recorded on Friday, when he spoke out about the decision to fire Topping.

His criticisms of the group's decision to limit the range of books stocked in its outlets are the latest symptom of a battle raging in the publishing and book retail industries. As internet bookselling challenges the traditional high street bookshop, competition within the industry has become intense.

The ideas of Tim Waterstone, founder of the chain, have been copied by rivals in Britain, such as Books Etc and its American owner, Borders , so that coffee shops and spacious interior design are now standard, yet the wide-ranging back catalogue of titles has been discarded.

Tim Waterstone, now elevated to the role of chairman of HMV Media, is believed to be moving behind the scenes to regain direct control of his original bookchain. He recently offered £250 million to buy back his baby.

Unknown authors, as Self was a decade ago, have little chance of making a commercial impact without the support of bookstores.

'I may have quite a high profile now,' Self told The Observer , 'but that is thanks in large part to people like Robert Topping who have arranged event-based selling within their stores. Now that I have a forum each week I decided to use my position to make a point, as much for myself as anything else. A lot of people who work in publishing or in these shops are not able to say what they think because they fear losing their jobs.'

According to former colleagues at the Deansgate branch, Robert Topping is appealing against his sacking. He is also a friend of Tim Waterstone.

fields.headline: Hooked by a Frenchman
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stateside View: It was a Frenchman who got me into this in the first place. Not only that, but he married my daughter.
fields.body:
It was a Frenchman who got me into this in the first place. Not only that, but he married my daughter.

He arrived in late spring of 1994, to attend the wedding of my only other daughter. Knowing that the United States was to host an upcoming soccer competition that apparently was deemed by some significant, I sought to engage my future son-in-law in some small talk.

'So, Yves,' I said, in that horribly false voice one uses towards people to whom one feels the obligation of courtesy, 'How do you think France will fare in that World Cup thing we're having over here in the summer?'

Yves is not only a gentleman and a scholar (and, God love him, several years later, he fell sound asleep at my side during the first half of a particularly tedious Spurs/Everton match at White Hart Lane), but a young man of such congeniality and obvious good character that I would have liked him even if he had not travelled such a great distance for no other purpose than to steal my daughter from under my very nose.

But immediately, he fired me a look of such malice and anger that I took an involuntary step backward. 'Don't speak to me,' he said, 'of this _ this _ Merde! I cannot even bear to say it: this ... World Cup!'

And with that he was gone.

Within minutes, I was approached by the daughter whose fiancé he was. 'Dad!' she said, 'How could you have? Don't you know anything? Now, poor Yves is totally shattered.'

In the hours that followed, I was able to piece together the genesis of my faux pas. It seemed that although there would be 24 countries represented at the World Cup to be hosted by America, France would not be among them, having inexplicably lost home matches against both Israel and Bulgaria the previous autumn.

Like Mitterrand's mistresses, it was something all of France acknowledged, but certainly not a topic they enjoyed hearing discussed by outsiders.

'And of course Yves thinks you were insulting him by asking such a question. He hasn't been here long enough to understand that you really might not have known France failed to qualify.'

'Qualify? _ How was I supposed to know about "qualify"? Three months ago, I would have told you the World Cup was a yacht race!'

And so I started to watch, in '94, and even to attend, hoping to learn what it might be about this sport that could so quickly transform the gracious and elegant Yves Jekyll into the rabid, snarling Mr Hyde. And I did learn, and became, instantly, a fire-breathing Mr Hyde myself.

The wedding of Yves and my daughter was to take place in south-west France at the start of September. Arriving in Bordeaux just a bit ahead of time, with my wife and two other children, I picked up the rental car intended to speed us effortlessly down the coast to our destination in the Aquitaine region.

It was early on a weekday morning, the airport was virtually empty, most of the rental counters were deserted. My wife, having slept not at all on the aeroplane displayed just a hint of impatience.

'What's the delay?' she asked. 'And why is that woman making a telephone call? Is there a problem with the credit card?'

'No, no, not at all,' I said, in the same infuriatingly unctuous tone I'd employed with Yves a few months earlier. 'It's just that Bordeaux aren't playing at home this week, so I've asked her to kindly locate the nearest match we might be able see before the wedding.'

'What are you talking about?'

'A match, dearest. You know: Like at the World Cup.'

'Yes, but the World Cup is over.'

'Absolutely. But the World Cup ends only so the new league seasons can begin.'

'Are you out of your ...'

'Pardon.' The car-rental clerk had put down the phone and was shaking her head sadly. 'I am so very sorry,' she said, as though she'd personally been in charge of arranging dates for the new season's fixtures.

'For the closest, you still must drive more than two 'undred kilo-me-tres in the wrong direction, and this will only bring you to Toulouse, which is very much not worthy of your trouble, for last saison they become, I don't know how...anyway, among les relégués .'

'Ah, sent down,' I said, marvelling at the universal language of the game.

' Tant pis ,' I said. 'More's the pity.'

'For me, no.' The clerk smiled. 'I am Bordeaux. But for your plan, is not possible, I don't think, because there is no match of le Championnat you might see, and to drive all that distance to see only Toulouse in le division deuxième , it would not be a nice thing, and your family..."

Well, almost live, for even I had to admit that Les Violets seemed a bit wilted in the 38-degree heat of the old concrete stadium (very much pre-World Cup refurbishment), located at least 38 miles from the badly infracted heart of the city.

It's all too easy, however, to remember the sight of the tears streaming down my children's faces when I informed them, 'No, godammit, we are not leaving at half-time! I don't care how tired you claim to be.'

As for my wife? Best, I think, if we leave her out of this entirely. Let's just say that when I rose after the match to cheer the lads in purple, and to wave my little flag that said ' Rebondir ensemble' I was very much a party of one.

And from what I'd seen during the 90 minutes that had preceded, I sensed not only that Toulouse and I would not 'go back up together,' I feared that they'd not go back up at all - not even with Roland Courbis as manager.

But that's now history and in order to keep the upper lip stiff, we must look forward. To a France-Holland final?

Let's give the last word to the long-suffering Yves, speaking from his redoubt in Paris's 18th arrondissement: 'I was confident in the French team,' he says, 'and does the match against Holland really count? When I see Marcel Desailly hugging Edgar Davids after the defeat, I assume it does not.

'France are better than in 1998. Same defence but the midfield with Zinedine Zidane and Patrick Vieira, and above all the attack with guys such as Nicolas Anelka, Sylvian Wiltord, David Trezeguet and Thierry Henry is so much more powerful.

'They seem to be a good group, too. The only thing that worries me is that some of them don't know yet where they will be playing next year: Wiltord, Robert Pires, Anelka, Didier Deschamps. We'll see.

'One more thing: have you noticed how happy Anelka looks, compared to when he was in Madrid? They are very good fellows, and Pires, Henry and Vieira often stay up late at night till 2am. in Anelka's room.

'So far, I loved Romania, Portugal, Turkey. I'm also very happy that England and Germany are out.'

webTitle: France prove twice as good as the rest

fields.headline: France prove twice as good as the rest
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: ...on a second string who came of age
fields.body:
Less than 24 hours had elapsed since their first defeat in almost two years and France couldn't have seemed happier. The world champions mooched around their beachside hotel, carefree, calm, and buzzing about the next challenge. Surely losing a match affects morale? Non. Not even the slightest psychological doubts? Shrug. A bit more pressure, then? More nons and shrugs.

It's very difficult to provoke a reaction from a team who feel like they've won when they've lost. Roger Lemerre's men give the impression of having gained a psychological edge over Holland last week in Amsterdam. So fine was the margin between France's usual bench-warmers and a maximum-strength Holland, they are almost more cocksure than ever. They effectively have two teams capable of faring very well indeed in this competition.

Portugal's awesome destruction of Germany showed France are not the only team with a dashing reserve side. But upsetting a bunch of ailing geriatrics at a neutral venue is not the same as taking on Holland at full power in their orange stadium, and for a good hour France gave at least as good as they got. 'That is proof of how strong we are,' says Patrick Vieira, 'proof we have a stronger squad than any other country.'

The understudies seized the moment to give Lemerre some serious selection dilemmas. Vieira's battle of wills against Edgar Davids suggests the Didier Deschamps-Emmanuel Petit axis can no longer be guaranteed. A classy display from a refreshed Christophe Dugarry made many a French judge believe he merits a return ticket into the main selection. Sylvain Wiltord's dynamic running is almost as dizzying as Thierry Henry or Nicolas Anelka.

Naturally, watching from the sidelines was a peculiar occurrence for the stars who fully expect to return to face Spain tonight. Zinedine Zidane chewed his nails. Fabien Barthez fidgeted. Laurent Blanc frowned. There was a strange role reversal going on, the sorcerers studying the apprentices. They were rightly impressed. The line between the experienced heads and progressive hopefuls is diminishing all the time.

Vieira senses how close he is to confirming his graduation from raw potential to trusted performer. 'I feel my status has changed,' he says. 'I notice it by the way the older players look at me. It's normal in this team for older players to help younger play ers, but now with a word or a glance it makes me think I have changed in their eyes. Little by little it gives me more confidence.'

He felt, playing against Davids, a mutual respect which made him feel he belongs at the highest level of international football.

On current form France's second string would beat most of Europe's first choice teams at a breeze. They might have succumbed to Holland in the end but you couldn't help but admire they way they cherished possession, 11 individuals expressing themselves within a fluid team framework.

Without the names that trip off every French fan's tongue, the rest still oozed an arrogance and swagger and joy of playing. (France B unquestionably possess the power to beat England A. The scoreline of France A versus England B hardly bears contemplating.)

A quarter-final against a gutsy Spain side is not the time for too many experiments or risks. This is a match with extra resonance for two returning players, Deschamps and Bixente Lizarazu, who hail from the Basque country.

'I know this team very well,' says the fervent fullback Lizarazu. 'We have already seen the two faces of Spain in this tournament. On the one side they are slow and sluggish like they are struggling to row a boat. On the other they show strong character and flowing football. Their main problem is central defence, where they are not very quick and we can profit.

'They have also had a long season and used up lots of energy to get this far which has to be good for us. The biggest danger for us is their forward players like Raul and Mendieta. They give Spain three options - to play one-twos, to dribble themselves or to shoot. We will have to keep them in their own half.'

Robert Pires, another member of the squad with Spanish connections, believes that France can cope whichever guise their opponents take. 'The main difference between us is that Spain are up and down while we are very consistent. We always play at the same level. We are very quiet and very relaxed. We trust ourselves. That is why we won the World Cup and we haven't changed.'

Tonight Pires will probably be back on the bench, maybe a touch frustrated, but unquestionably dreaming in blue, white and red. Anything less the semi-finals, for a squad so strong they could challenge for the European title twice over, would nothing short of calamitous.

fields.headline: Best fans in the world
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: There's no doubt about it: England has the worst football fans in the world... but it also has the best.
fields.body:
There's no doubt about it: England has the worst football fans in the world. The point was proved once again as 'Britian' and 'Pussy Hunter' and their tattooed chums attempted to take on water cannon with three green plastic chairs. National Disgrace. Bring Them Home. The English Disease. How Much Longer Must We.... The headlines were as predictable as the proposed solutions. Gary Lineker called for passport confiscation on a grand scale. Were such a scheme to be put into operation it would have rid the Championship of its best supporters. The English.

Not all England football fans, perhaps, but English football fans (there is a considerable distinction) who see green plastic chairs not as potential weapons and a chance to attract the TV cameras, but as something to sit on. Passionate, knowledgeable, peaceable supporters happy to sit and drink and talk football with anyone and everyone. Fans who may be pretty relieved that the England team are back home. Their sense of relief would have come from the knowledge that they would no longer have to share the stand with fellow countrymen singing 'No Surrender To The IRA'; no longer have to avoid the Irish bars where the idiots gather to sing the National Anthem and spoil for a fight; no longer have to endure the embarrassment of seeing fat-bellied oafs face down, bloodied and handcuffed in the gutter, asking their captors, the Belgian police, 'Who won the war then?'

England's departure from the tournament has once again led to an immediate and noticeable raising of standards, both on and off the pitch. At every game there are more English (and many Scots too) in attendance than neutrals of any other nationality bar the hosts. Even this weekend there are probably as many English fans in Holland and Belgium as there are Spanish. Stop off for a beer or a coffee in Tilburg, or Breda, or Antwerp, or Ghent, and you'll bump into friendly, knowledgeable English fans who will help you out with tickets, and advice on restaurants and accommodation. It was the same in France 98. You'll even find them at the African Cup of Nations, the Asian Championship... anywhere there's a big football tournament. But this is no real surprise. The English watch football, and love watching football, like no other nation.

No other country in their qualifying predicament could have attracted 70,000 to watch a game against Luxembourg, as England did last year. While Old Trafford, Highbury and Stamford Bridge were packed for Champions League qualifiers, the eventual winners, Real Madrid, played early games in near-empty stadiums. At Euro 2000 fixtures like Norway v Slovenia and Czech Republic v Denmark there were plenty of English fans happy just to be there, to be part of the tournament and enjoying the football and the atmosphere. People who had come to watch the tournament rather than their national team. Yes, England has the worst football fans in the world.

But it also has the best.

webTitle: Public 'should be told truth of NHS rationing'

fields.headline: Public 'should be told truth of NHS rationing'
fields.standfirst: Ministers must be honest about NHS limitations, says think tank.
fields.trailText: Public trust in the NHS will collapse unless the Government admits that healthcare must be rationed, a key report has warned.
fields.byline: Gaby Hinsliff, Chief Political Correspondent, The Observer
fields.body:
Public trust in the NHS will collapse unless the Government admits that healthcare must be rationed, a key report has warned.

An influential thinktank, the Institute for Public Policy Research, says that patients already know the service cannot pay for every drug or operation, and unless Ministers tell the truth about that, a disgruntled public will lose faith in the whole system.

The report will carry serious weight in Whitehall - since the researcher behind it is now a key aide to Health Secretary Alan Milburn.

It warns of a 'confidence gap' over funding, with scepticism over where the money from previous health spending announcements has gone.

It follows anger over news that multiple sclerosis patients will be denied the drug interferon beta on the NHS, after the independent body of experts who vet new treatments decided the evidence did not justify subsidy.

The IPPR paper comprises nearly two years' work led by researcher Jo Lenaghan, who went to the Department of Health to work on Milburn's forthcoming National Plan, before the final draft.

Completed by her successor Liz Kendall and to be published on Tuesday, it concludes that people say the NHS is 'failing' because they have unrealistic expectations of it. 'Politicians must begin to engage the public in a more open and mature debate about the competing demands that will always be made upon the health service and the difficult trade-offs this inevitably brings. This will be crucial to maintaining public support for the NHS in the long run.'

The argument is fleshed out in an IPPR pamphlet by policy expert Bill New, also to be published on Tuesday, urging more 'open and explicit rationing' since 'the public is well aware that the NHS cannot do everything and that comprehensiveness is a compromised principle.

'Greater damage to public confidence would be done by failing clearly to acknowledge this and thus appearing to deceive the public further about what the service is capable of achieving.

'The best way to sustain such institutions is to be brutally honest about what they can and cannot do.'

IPPR focus groups found the public does not want the NHS to pay for new drugs like Propecia - meant to halt baldness in men - and backs restricting the impotence drug Viagra to serious cases.

Respondents approved of the slimming drug Xenical being prescribed where obesity threatens life, but not simply for dieting teenagers. Many wanted limits on cosmetic surgery on the NHS.

Most wanted open public consultation on such issues. 'The quiet muddling through has been going on for too long,' one commented.

Ministers have denied rationing exists, insisting that the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), set up to vet new treatments, only establishes clinical effectiveness.
