webTitle: City of the sea builds on its buccaneering past

fields.headline: City of the sea builds on its buccaneering past
fields.standfirst: The ships have sailed but Bristol's waterfront is still bustling.  Stephen Pritchard finds plenty to praise in the South-West's most engaging city
fields.trailText: The ships have sailed but Bristol's waterfront is still bustling. Stephen Pritchard finds plenty to praise in the South-West's most engaging city.
fields.body:
'For people, not posers,' says the sign over the door to the health club on the quayside. It could serve as a motto for the whole city, for this is Bristol, a town built for real working people from the proceeds of their labour in its port.

But what does a city do when the reason for its very existence has literally sailed away? Handsome Bristol's docks have long been silent, but a buccaneering spirit still lurks there down by the water, playing its part in the city's renaissance. Looking out from Cabot's Tower high above the city centre, a huge roofscape lies below, the river twisting through it like a silver-grey eel. Great ships no longer unload their cargoes here, but the quaysides are far from derelict. Like London and Liverpool, the waterfront is revitalised with bars, internet cafés, floating restaurants, bookshops, galleries and health clubs.

This is a city of constant variety; ancient buildings set against, for the most part, imaginative, modern civic development - the new Broad Quay water feature, for instance (all fountains, weirs, masts and rigging), reminding Bristolians of their city's former reliance on the sea. And some great civic disasters are being set right. Queen Square, crammed with beautiful Georgian houses, had a dual carriageway driven through it by a Sixties planner, but now it is being returned to its former splendour, the road ripped up and grass replacing tarmac.

An astonishing £450 million is being spent on redeveloping a harbourside area to the west of the city centre towards the Anglican cathedral. Called @Bristol, it aims to entertain with a mix of nature, science and art. Explore @Bristol, due to open on 6 July, will show how science and technology affect our lives. Wildscreen @Bristol, opening on 20 July, will focus on the diversity of the natural world with a walk-through botanical house filled with live butterflies and birds and the only Imax cinema in the South-West: an appropriate attraction in a city that is home to the world-famous BBC Wildlife Unit. A planetarium - a giant silver sphere called Imaginarium - is also under construction.

So Bristol is looking forward to the future with confidence, but its past is equally fascinating. The money that poured in off the dockside was ploughed into fine houses and great churches; St Mary Redcliffe, for instance, is a massive perpendicular gem, far richer than the bigger cathedral across the water and considered one of the finest churches in the world.

Clifton must be one of England's most beautiful suburbs. Once a village, it became a highly desirable address in the late eighteenth century when richer Bristolians built fine houses on Clifton Down, up above the noise and bustle of the quayside. It's really rewarding to stroll around. Grand terraces with balconies of decorated wrought iron overlook open green spaces, the dramatic Avon Gorge and the city's best-known icon, the Clifton Suspension Bridge by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, the Victorian engineer who built the Great Western Railway, Temple Meads station and the SS Great Britain, the largest ship of her day, now lying in her original dry dock in the harbour below.

It's difficult to believe, but ships once carried their cargoes right to the door of Bristol's new Hotel du Vin, an imaginative conversion of a series of city-centre warehouses. Mr Reed's Sugar House was built in 1728 when the River Frome flowed past its front door and the hotel's windows, which today overlook the city's central hub, would have looked out on to a sea of masts and rigging. Sugar and tobacco flowed in to Bristol from the Caribbean. Manufactured goods went to Africa and were swapped for slaves for the Caribbean plantations.

When the sugar trade ended, the warehouse moved on to tobacco and eventually birdseed, before lying empty for 11 years. In 1906 its owner put a fine Queen Anne-style façade on its front, and it is that part of the building that now serves as the hotel's bistro.

As its name implies, the Hotel du Vin is serious about its wine list, as are its sister establishments in Winchester and Tunbridge Wells, but equally impressive are the imaginative menus from head chef Eddie Gray. A sweeping modern staircase leads up to the 40 loft-style bedrooms retaining massive wooden beams and iron pillars.

The ships may have sailed, but Bristol retains its air of a city wedded to the sea. Tucked behind Queen Square is a row of eighteenth-century sailors' almshouses that still bear this inscription:

Freed from all storms, the tempest and the rage of billows

Here we spend our age. Our weatherbeaten vessels here repair

And from the merchant's kind and generous care, find habitation here;

No more we put to sea until we launch into Eternity.

And lest our widows, whom we leave behind, should want relief

They too a shelter find. Thus all our anxious cares and sorrows cease

Whilst our kind guardians turn our toils to ease.

May they be with an endless Sabbath blest

Who have afforded unto us this rest.

fields.headline: Travel News
fields.trailText:
Send in the motorway clowns

Clowns, magicians and mechanics have been called in to encourage families to take a break on French motorways this summer.
fields.body:
Send in the motorway clowns

Clowns, magicians and mechanics have been called in to encourage families to take a break on French motorways this summer.

Tired drivers en route to their family's holiday destination can take time out at dozens of entertainment and rest zones. The idea is to persuade drivers to stop more often and rest, to break up motorway monotony and relieve family stress.

At some service stops, including Beaune on the A6 and Volcans d'Auvergne on the A71,children's hostesses look after anyone under 10, giving their parents a break. At other stops there are free tyre pressure checks, mechanics, forest walks, history exhibitions and clowns, as well as cafeterias and picnic tables.

The Société des Autoroutes Paris, Rhin et Rhne provides facilities at laybys and service stations serving 1,800 kilometres of roads from 23 June to 3 September.

'Around 38 per cent of fatal accidents on French roads are caused by tiredness,' said spokesman Alexandre Pauporte. 'We suggest drivers stop every two hours.'

He is expecting about 35 million travellers to stop and enjoy the free entertainment. Traffic streams down French motorways during July and August as the British join the regular French migration to the south. The last weekend in July is given the fearsome title 'the black weekend' and is traditionally the busiest on the roads.

'French motorways do provide very good facilities that encourage you to stop,' said John Kirk, managing director of French self-drive specialist VFB Holidays.

'They are much better than service stations in Britain and there are many more of them.'

He also pointed out that secondary French roads are much less busy and are free - if you have a little extra time.

Information on French motorway rest zones with maps is available on: www.saprr.fr and 09068 244123 (60p per minute).

Skidooing with the reindeer

For years British skiers associated Norway with the cross-country sport, but suddenly downhill skiers are setting their sights on it too.

Ski operators Crystal and Neilson already feature downhill skiing in Norway, and this year Thomson is also adding its first Norwegian resorts - Geilo and Beitostolen - into brochures.

Breakfast by candlelight and skidooing within sight of moose and reindeer are all part of the attraction.

Thomson ski managing director Andy Peters says: 'It's a winter wonderland and particularly popular at Christmas. One of the biggest bonuses is that everyone speaks perfect English.' Thomson will be starting a charter flight to Norway this winter. Overall ski operators say bookings to all destinations are up on last year, when they saw a downward swing in custom.

'It was the millennium factor,' says Peters. Debbie Marshall, managing director of Crystal Holidays, agrees. Like Thomson, she says, Crystal's bookings are well ahead of last year.

Canada is still an extremely popular destination with British skiers, who must expect to pay more than last year for their trip in 2000/01 as the Canadian dollar has strengthened.

But the weak euro has kept prices in continental Europe at around the same levels as last year.

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: A bit of IT and R&R
fields.body:
A bit of IT and R&R

Computer training for some technophobes can involve the torture of sitting with the company boffin in a darkened room and being humiliated into pretending that you know one end of the mouse from the other. While the thought of bringing this process on holiday with you may seem the best way to ruin a good trip, Countrywide aims to take the pain out of the process by combining IT with R&R. Taking place in Bicton, east Devon, or Sparsholt, Winchester, its seven-night Introduction to Computing courses are led by qualified tutors who aim to show anxious students how to bring their skills up to date. After the hard work of four days of tuition, visitors can enjoy guided walks in their areas for two days. Prices start at £369 for seven nights half board, with the tuition and guided tours included. Phone 01942 241432.

Anyone for polo?

The thought of playing polo half a world away may do a lot to help it shake off its image as an unrealistically stuffy game played by this country's aristocrats. Exsus Travel is organising polo holidays to Argentina and will tailor trips so that they can include a short break in Buenos Aires. The main body of the trip, however, will take place on an estancia - an old family-run colonial homestead. An expert instructor holds stick and ball practice each morning followed by a four-chukka game each afternoon. There is a maximum of two students per team so that skills learnt in the morning are put to the test in the game. Hardy players who are early risers can ride out with the cattle herders or those who need a break from all the activity can visit nearby villages or stay by the pool. Prices start at £1,850. Call 020 7292 5050.

Enjoy Aida al fresco

An outdoor concert that necessitates insect repellent rather than an umbrella would make a welcome change given the summer this country is having. If you book now for an outdoor performance of Aida in Verona in August, the anticipation of the sound rising through the heat of the amphitheatre may be enough to sustain you through the weeks of British summer to come. Lakes and Mountains is offering a three-night city break departing Gatwick on 13 August. Accommodation is in the three-star Hotel Mastino, 200 metres from the Roman arena where the concert will take place. Tickets to the performance are included in the price of £445, as is breakfast and scheduled flights. Call 01329 844405.

fields.headline: Freedom's market
fields.standfirst: The UN is launching a campaign to alleviate poverty by regulating the global economy. Nobel laureate Amartya Sen argues that this depends as much on democracy as it does on free markets
fields.trailText: Amartya Sen: Many of the criticisms of globalisation can be rejected, but tackling poverty depends as much on democracy as it does on free markets.
fields.body:
In his essay on The Advancement of Learning, written nearly 400 years ago, Francis Bacon argued that 'the registering and proposing of doubts has a double use'. Aside from its obvious use in helping us to guard 'against errors', doubts can contribute to broadening an investigation. Issues that 'would have been passed by lightly without intervention,' Bacon noted, end up being 'attentively and carefully observed' precisely because of the intervention of doubts.

This second use is very important to bear in mind as we try to assess the critiques of globalisation that have been recently aired in different forms. The importance of these challenges lies, I would argue, not so much in the 'theses' that are presented as simple slogans on posters and placards, but in the 'themes' that they bring forcefully into global discussion. Demonstrations have recently occurred not only at the venues of international financial gatherings (for example, in Seattle where the WTO were to meet), but also, in the form of less organised but intense protests, in different national capitals, all the way from Jakarta and Bangkok to Abidjan and Mexico. These doubts about global economic relations continue to come from different ends of the globe, and there is reason enough to see these doubts about globalisation as a global phenomenon as well. They are, in this sense, 'global doubts' - not just an ad hoc assortment of localised opposition.

However, the significance of this phenomenon does not undermine the economic case for global trade and worldwide use of modern technology and finance. Indeed, that case is, I believe, very strong. And nevertheless, these disputations can have a very positive role in broadening our investigation of economic and financial relations in the world and in forcing attention to issues that could have been otherwise neglected. We have to distinguish the distinct issues involved. Opponents of globalisation may see it as a new folly, but it is neither particularly new, nor, in general, a folly. It is largely an intensification of the processes of interaction involving travel, trade, migration and dissemination of knowledge that have shaped the progress of the world over millennia. A more immediate point is that there is extensive evidence that the global economy has actually brought prosperity to many different areas of the globe. The productive and economic contributions of global integration can scarcely be denied.

However, we also have to recognise the enormous inequalities that exist across the globe and often within each country, and we have to examine the manifest disparities that give these global doubts the political salience they undoubtedly have. What is needed is not a rejection of the positive role of the market mechanism in generating income and wealth, but the important recognition that the market mechanism has to work in a world of many institutions. We need the power and protection of these institutions, provided by democratic practice, civil and human rights, a free and open media, facilities for basic education and health care, economic safety nets, and of course, provisions for women's freedom and rights - a neglected area which is only now beginning to receive the attention it deserves.

Let me give a few quick examples. First, a well-functioning market economy does not obviate the need for democracy and civil and political rights. These rights not only give people more freedom to live the way they would like (without being bossed around), they also allow people to have more voice to demand that their interests not be ignored. The fact that no famine has ever occurred in a democratic country (even in very poor ones) with a free press and regular elections is only one rudimentary illustration of this connection. It is not surprising that the demand for democracy and for civil and political rights became much stronger in East and South East Asia, as the economic crisis of 1997 developed and spread.

The protective power of democracy is particularly needed as and when a country is hit by an economic crisis. There is, of course, no basic conflict between economic globalisation and the fostering of democracies. But quite often global capitalist institutions show a distinct preference for orderly autocracies over the adversarial politics of democratic governance and the activist use of human rights. It is not adequate to concede verbally (as many advocates of basic reliance on the market do) that non-market institutions may be important; it is necessary to make sure that these institutions are strong and can supplement the market mechanism appropriately and adequately.

To take a second issue, the ability of people to participate in the market economy is enormously influenced by social arrangements for education, health care, microcredit, land reform, and other public policies. Furthermore, the sharing of the benefits of the market economy also depends on social institutions. This applies even to very prosperous countries.

Take the deprivation of disadvantaged groups in the United States, for example African Americans. Even though American blacks are typically many times richer, in terms of income per head, than people in the developing world, nevertheless in terms of surviving to mature ages, they tend to fall behind the population of many Third World countries, including substantial parts of China and India. Aside from civic violence, lack of a national medical coverage has a role to play here, and so has the breakdown of inner city education and other social arrangements. The unprecedented economic boom that the American economy has enjoyed has not resolved these problems.

Third, there is now overwhelming evidence that women's empowerment through schooling, employment opportunities, etc, have the most far-reaching effects on the lives of all - men, women and children. It reduces child mortality; it cuts down health hazards of adults arising from low birth weight; it increases the range and effectiveness of public debates; and it is more influential than economic growth in moderating fertility rates. We can see its influence in the halving of the fertility rate of Bangladesh in less than two decades, and in the fact that while some districts of India have quite high fertility rates, others with more gender equity already have fertility rates lower than the United States and Britain. The reach of social institutions that work for gender equity is astonishingly large.

There is also a related point of great importance which John Kenneth Galbraith has made very forcefully. The role of institutions has to be assessed in terms of the 'countervailing power' they exercise over one another. Asymmetric power in one domain can be checked by a different configuration of forces in another domain. Distribution of power in the world relates closely to institutional plurality. This applies even to the institutional basis of world trade and finance, which includes, among other arrangements, such institutions as the World Trade Organisation, the World Bank, the IMF, and so on. It is necessary to re-examine the balance of power in the running of the different institutions that make up the global architecture.

The present institutional architecture was largely set up in the middle Forties, on the basis of the understanding of the needs of the world economy as interpreted in the Bretton Woods Conference held just as the Second World War was coming to an end. The world was, in fact, very different in the Forties, when the bulk of Asia and Africa was still under colonial rule of one kind or another, when the tolerance of insecurity and of poverty was much greater (even the West had just emerged from a massive depression and a very destructive war), and when there was little understanding of the huge global prospects of democracy, economic development and human rights in the world.

Even within the existing global architecture, the substantive policies followed by the principal institutions can make a big difference. For example, the recent changes in the policy priorities of the World Bank (under the leadership of James Wolfensohn), with a much greater involvement with economic security and social development, has been undoubtedly influential. The existing institutions can address the global doubts more fully, and the United Nations can also play a very big role in forcing attention on these concerns.

It is not at all difficult to reject many of the criticisms of globalisation that have recently been made, and it is right that rejectable points should be repulsed. But there is a basic need to recognise that despite the big contributions that a global economy can undoubtedly make to global prosperity, we also have to confront, at the same time, the far-reaching manifestations of inequality between and within nations. The real debate associated with globalisation is, ultimately, not about the efficiency of markets, nor about the importance of modern technology. The debate, rather, is about inequality of power, for which there is much less tolerance now than in the world that emerged at the end of the Second World War.

We cannot, to use Francis Bacon's words, let these broader doubts pass 'lightly without intervention'. The world of Bretton Woods is not the world of today.

 Professor Amartya Sen is Master of Trinity College, Cambridge, and 1998 Nobel Prizewinner for Economics.

Demonstrations have recently occurred not only at the venues of international financial gatherings (for example, in Seattle where the WTO were to meet), but also, in the form of less organised but intense protests, in different national capitals, all the way from Jakarta and Bangkok to Abidjan and Mexico. These doubts about global economic relations continue to come from different ends of the globe, and there is reason enough to see these doubts about globalisation as a global phenomenon as well. They are, in this sense, 'global doubts' - not just an ad hoc assortment of localised opposition. However, the significance of this phenomenon does not undermine the economic case for global trade and worldwide use of modern technology and finance. Indeed, that case is, I believe, very strong. And nevertheless, these disputations can have a very positive role in broadening our investigation of economic and financial relations in the world and in forcing attention to issues that could have been otherwise neglected. We have to distinguish the distinct issues involved. Opponents of globalisation may see it as a new folly, but it is neither particularly new, nor, in general, a folly. It is largely an intensification of the processes of interaction involving travel, trade, migration and dissemination of knowledge that have shaped the progress of the world over millennia. A more immediate point is that there is extensive evidence that the global economy has actually brought prosperity to many different areas of the globe. The productive and economic contributions of global integration can scarcely be denied. However, we also have to recognise the enormous inequalities that exist across the globe and often within each country, and we have to examine the manifest disparities that give these global doubts the political salience they undoubtedly have. What is needed is not a rejection of the positive role of the market mechanism in generating income and wealth, but the important recognition that the market mechanism has to work in a world of many institutions. We need the power and protection of these institutions, provided by democratic practice, civil and human rights, a free and open media, facilities for basic education and health care, economic safety nets, and of course, provisions for women's freedom and rights - a neglected area which is only now beginning to receive the attention it deserves. Let me give a few quick examples. First, a well-functioning market economy does not obviate the need for democracy and civil and political rights. These rights not only give people more freedom to live the way they would like (without being bossed around), they also allow people to have more voice to demand that their interests not be ignored. The fact that no famine has ever occurred in a democratic country (even in very poor ones) with a free press and regular elections is only one rudimentary illustration of this connection. It is not surprising that the demand for democracy and for civil and political rights became much stronger in East and South East Asia, as the economic crisis of 1997 developed and spread. The protective power of democracy is particularly needed as and when a country is hit by an economic crisis. There is, of course, no basic conflict between economic globalisation and the fostering of democracies. But quite often global capitalist institutions show a distinct preference for orderly autocracies over the adversarial politics of democratic governance and the activist use of human rights. It is not adequate to concede verbally (as many advocates of basic reliance on the market do) that non-market institutions may be important; it is necessary to make sure that these institutions are strong and can supplement the market mechanism appropriately and adequately. To take a second issue, the ability of people to participate in the market economy is enormously influenced by social arrangements for education, health care, microcredit, land reform, and other public policies. Furthermore, the sharing of the benefits of the market economy also depends on social institutions. This applies even to very prosperous countries. Take the deprivation of disadvantaged groups in the United States, for example African Americans. Even though American blacks are typically many times richer, in terms of income per head, than people in the developing world, nevertheless in terms of surviving to mature ages, they tend to fall behind the population of many Third World countries, including substantial parts of China and India. Aside from civic violence, lack of a national medical coverage has a role to play here, and so has the breakdown of inner city education and other social arrangements. The unprecedented economic boom that the American economy has enjoyed has not resolved these problems. Third, there is now overwhelming evidence that women's empowerment through schooling, employment opportunities, etc, have the most far-reaching effects on the lives of all - men, women and children. It reduces child mortality; it cuts down health hazards of adults arising from low birth weight; it increases the range and effectiveness of public debates; and it is more influential than economic growth in moderating fertility rates. We can see its influence in the halving of the fertility rate of Bangladesh in less than two decades, and in the fact that while some districts of India have quite high fertility rates, others with more gender equity already have fertility rates lower than the United States and Britain. The reach of social institutions that work for gender equity is astonishingly large. There is also a related point of great importance which John Kenneth Galbraith has made very forcefully. The role of institutions has to be assessed in terms of the 'countervailing power' they exercise over one another. Asymmetric power in one domain can be checked by a different configuration of forces in another domain. Distribution of power in the world relates closely to institutional plurality. This applies even to the institutional basis of world trade and finance, which includes, among other arrangements, such institutions as the World Trade Organisation, the World Bank, the IMF, and so on. It is necessary to re-examine the balance of power in the running of the different institutions that make up the global architecture. The present institutional architecture was largely set up in the middle Forties, on the basis of the understanding of the needs of the world economy as interpreted in the Bretton Woods Conference held just as the Second World War was coming to an end. The world was, in fact, very different in the Forties, when the bulk of Asia and Africa was still under colonial rule of one kind or another, when the tolerance of insecurity and of poverty was much greater (even the West had just emerged from a massive depression and a very destructive war), and when there was little understanding of the huge global prospects of democracy, economic development and human rights in the world. Even within the existing global architecture, the substantive policies followed by the principal institutions can make a big difference. For example, the recent changes in the policy priorities of the World Bank (under the leadership of James Wolfensohn), with a much greater involvement with economic security and social development, has been undoubtedly influential. The existing institutions can address the global doubts more fully, and the United Nations can also play a very big role in forcing attention on these concerns. It is not at all difficult to reject many of the criticisms of globalisation that have recently been made, and it is right that rejectable points should be repulsed. But there is a basic need to recognise that despite the big contributions that a global economy can undoubtedly make to global prosperity, we also have to confront, at the same time, the far-reaching manifestations of inequality between and within nations. The real debate associated with globalisation is, ultimately, not about the efficiency of markets, nor about the importance of modern technology. The debate, rather, is about inequality of power, for which there is much less tolerance now than in the world that emerged at the end of the Second World War. We cannot, to use Francis Bacon's words, let these broader doubts pass 'lightly without intervention'. The world of Bretton Woods is not the world of today.  Professor Amartya Sen is Master of Trinity College, Cambridge, and 1998 Nobel Prizewinner for Economics.

fields.headline: Holland 6 - 1 Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: Follow every kick, tackle and dive from 5:00pm
fields.body:
Holland: van der Sar, Numan, Stam, F. de Boer, Bosvelt, Cocu, Davids, Zenden, Overmars, Bergkamp, Kluivert.
Substitutes: de Goey, Westerveld, Reiziger, Seedorf, van Bronckhorst, Konterman, van Vossen, R. de Boer, van Hooijdonk, Makaay, Winter.

Yugoslavia: Kralj, Komljenovic, Djukic, Mihajlovic, Saveljic, Stojkovic, Govedarica, Jugovic, Drulovic, Mijatovic, Milosevic.
Substitutes: Korac, Cicovic, Dudic, D. Stankovic, J. Stankovic, Bunjevcevic, Kovacevic, Nadj.

Referee: J M Garcia Aranda (Spain)

1 min Sander Westerveld gets his wish and van der Sar starts in goal for Holland. The Yugoslavs have two players suspended, but goal-machine Milosevic is present and correct. Holland kick off in an orange bowl.

2 Zenden has a lock on the left side, and Overmars starts on the right where he has looked out of sorts due to the unaccustomed nature of the position.

4 First test for Bosvelt, chased back by Milosevic. The Dutch right-back looks to have pace to spare. The Dutch move smoothly upfield, and an Overmars dummy opens up a shooting chance for Bergkamp. The Arsenal man strikes a rising drive straight into Mihajlovic's backside.

8 A humdinger of a battle is developing in midfield, with Davids versus the whole of Yugoslavia. It'll be a surprise if the referee doesn't have to take his name at some point in the game. Yugoslavia are absorbing intense early pressure from the home side, but they haven't conceded yet...

10 Kluivert is pulled back centre-left, 40 yards out. Zenden floats in a cross aimed at Stam, but Djukic rises to clear. They are looking pretty solid at the back - Holland may need some magic to unlock what has been a very porous defence.

13 Yugoslavia's turn to attack now, with a free kick from the left touchline. Mihajlovic's delivery swings in an van der Sar judges the flight well to clear. Milosevic was lurking with intent behind the Dutch keeper at the far post, and worryingly for Holland, unmarked.

17 Mijatovic, played in with a quick square ball from Milosevic, finds himself one-on-one with van der Sar 10 yards out. He picks his spot, but unfortunately for Mijatovic, it's the spot occupied by van der Sar. A great save and Yugoslavia should be one-nil up.

19 Holland go close, firstly through Bergkamp, played in by Davids' through ball lofted over the top down the centre-left. His curling shot has far-corner written all over it, but the athletic Kralj makes the save and importantly gets distance on his parry, with Kluivert lurking with bad intentions. Overmars plays it in again for Kluivert to head, but his effort arrows over the bar. A breathless few minutes.

21 Bergkamp seems to be responding to some of the criticism he has received about the quality of his performances in an orange shirt. Again, Davids is the provider, this time a weighted through-ball on the deck. Bergkamp aims for the corner from 20 yards and once more, Kralj is Yugoslavia's saviour.

22 Davids skips past two challenges and with no Bergkamp available to pass to, has a go himself. His rising drive beats Kralj, but just clears the crossbar. Holland have visibly gone up a gear and Yugoslavia are hanging on.

24 GOAL! Holland 1 - 0 Yugoslavia Bergkamp, who seems to be missing chances in front of goal, turn provider, flicking a ball on for Kluivert who needs two touches, one to control it (when it looked beyond him) and the other to poke it past Kralj, well beaten this time. Here we go.

28 The Dutch, buoyed by the goal, are playing with the ball glued to their feet. Yugoslavia need possession and the Dutch are playing passing triangles around them.

31 Jugovic is looking at a long afternoon scrapping with Davids. When he looks like he's won a tackle legitimately, the referee blows up for a foul. The free kick, from a central position 50 yards out, is taken quickly and Numan cuts inside from the left and drives a low shot at Kralj's near post, which the keeper does well to hold.

32 Bergkamp plays a short pass to Overmars in the Yugoslav area. The diminutive winger spins and shoots just over. The crowd want another (Orange) goal.

35 A corner to Holland, from the left. Their first - surprising when you think of the pressure they've put Yugoslavia under. Bergkamp takes, and Kralj gathers with relief over the penalty spot.

36 Zenden, who earlier blasted a clearance into Mijatovic's face, this time plants one right on Milosevic's kisser. Magic sponge time.

37 Komljenovic, a solid defender, looks to be lacking pace. Zenden has skinned him for the third time and if the Barcelona man had a shooting foot, Yugoslavia might consider going home at half time.

38 GOAL!! Holland 2 - 0 Yugoslavia They might not come out for the second half anyway. Davids, who had been quiet for a couple of minutes, picks up the ball in the centre circle and surges forward. one look up and a perfect loft ball finds Kluivert's boot 10 yards out. the ball slides under Kralj and the orange masses go berzerk. Looks like there are a lot more goals where that came from...

43 Again, after scoring Holland are keeping the ball in midfield and stringing together 8, 10 passes. Jaap Stam looks on, bored.

47 Half time: Holland 2 - 0 Yugoslavia. No bookings - just brilliant football

Second half

45 A weary-looking Yugoslavia restart the game. It's going to take a miracle for them to get back into this one - they look outclassed in every department.

47 Holland, on a counter-attack, are breathtaking. Overmars arrows a ball to Zenden in space on the left. He plays it back into Davids in a central position, who plays a one-touch pass to Overmars. The winger pulls the trigger from 20 yards but can only blast the ball over. The Men in Orange look irresistible.

50 Zenden torments Komljenovic too much and gets a knock on the ankle for his trouble. Free kick from the left.

51 GOAL!!! Holland 3 - 0 Yugoslavia The set-piece is floated over and the cross is redelivered from the right. Kluivert (who else?) ghosts in at the near post and bang! the ball is in the roof of the net and Holland, barring an act of God, are in the semi-final.
#

54 GOAL!!!! Holland 4 - 0 Holland Zenden. On the left. Square ball. Kluivert. 10 yards. Bottom corner. Goal. Brilliant. Nuff said.

58 Kluivert takes a knock challenging for a high ball and is clutching his right cheek. Holland win a corner from the left. Kluivert is substituted as a precautionary measure, to an amazing ovation. Roy Maakay comes on in his place. Nothing comes of the corner, but no-one is complaining.

63 Yugoslavia are gamely trying to push forward, but even this team of lost-cause specialists appear overwhelmed against this orange machine. Westerveld is preparing to come on for van de Sar.

65 Overmars and Bergkamp enjoy the space that Makaay creates with is running off the ball. Bergkamp lays the ball off to Overmars on the right of the Yugoslav area, and the Arsenal man's low shot slips wide of the far post with Kralj a spectator. Substitute Westerveld comes on for van der Sar.

69 Davids fouls Milosevic 25 yards out centre-right. Mihajlovic will fancy this one. The four man wall watch his shot bend over them and sail agonisingly wide of the right-hand upright as Westerveld stood rooted to the spot.

71 Substitute Kovacevic on for Drulovic - Yugoslavia now playing with three forwards. His first touch is a header that Westerveld does well to keep out and even better to catch and smother the ball at Milosevic's feet.

73 Yugoslavia attack and the ball is spread left. Overmars bundles over Milosevic near the corner flag. The free kick is easily cleared but the ball is played back in to the far post and Cocu, tracking back, keeps his eye on the ball all the way and his mid-air clearance becomes a horror show as his collides with the post with his ribs. After a while and some magic sponge action, he gets gingerly to his feet.

78 GOAL!!!!! Holland 5 - 0 Yugoslavia Bergkamp, released down the left, keeps the ball well while his team-mates catch up with the play. Dennis looks up and floats the ball to Marc Overmars, 25 yards out centre-right. He chests it and the volley is a sweet as any you will ever see. Kralj does well to get a hand on it, but the power is too great and if they're not too caned, they'll be dancing in the streets of Amsterdam.

81 Almost number six as Bergkamp takes a free kick from the left. It's a low curling cross/shot that fools everyone. Kralj conjures a save more by luck than judgement.

84 They haven't come off the gas at all. Still pressing, looking for number six, Holland are playing increasingly through Bergkamp, who seems to have redefined his role. During this tournament.

88 Dutch possession during this game has been staggering. They must have had over 65% of the ball. There's never been a six-nil during the European Championships. The Dutch have a few minutes to make history.

90 Two extra minutes to be played, and that's the first time I've ever heard the fourth official get a cheer.

91 GOA!!!!!! Holland 6 - 0 Yugoslavia Cocu, from 25 yards, drills the ball into the foot of the right-hand post. The rebound falls kindly for Marc Overmars, who calmly slots the ball home from the left side of the area past a shell-shocked Kralj.

92 GOAL!!!!!!! Holland 6 - 1 Yugoslavia Mijatovic strikes a rising drive past Westerveld onto the crossbar, and Milosevic is there to slot it home from 5 yards. One of the more muted celebrations you're likely to see.

93 Full time: Holland 6 (Six) - 1 Yugoslavia. Truly, truly amazing.

fields.headline: At your service
fields.standfirst: A top concierge reveals all
fields.trailText: A top concierge reveals all
fields.body:
Crowne Plaza Hotel, Brussels

Kerim Ben-Youssef, head concierge

Any famous guests?

We are one of the oldest hotels in Brussels and most of the time we get politicians, Presidents and Nato generals, so we have to be careful about security, but things have been more lively recently. There was an erotica convention with porn stars, and then the Crazy Horse can-can dancers stayed, which was very exciting for the guests: everyone was asking me for their room numbers. It's weird because they all look the same, and have made-up names, but they are normal, nice people.

Isn't there a football tournament at the moment?

Yes, of course there is. Television crews from all over Europe are at the hotel and Gary Lineker from the BBC was here too. I talked to him after the England-Portugal match and I don't think he was very happy because he was drinking whisky. I also got tickets to watch a Euro 2000 match from a VIP suite. Beckenbauer and Cruyff were there, and I wanted to ask them for autographs, but I couldn't do that because everyone would have known that I wasn't a VIP.

Sorry about the Belgian team.

Well, even the creativity of England and the magic touch of Michael Owen didn't save you.

What about a night out?

There are lots of non-touristy things to do, but everybody ends up in the Grand-Place, which dates from the Middle Ages. Place Saint Gery is the place to be, with Irish pubs and restaurants that have bars at the back. Conway's is where the American students go and is a bit of a pick-up place on Thursdays. The largest clubs, with the hottest girls, are Mirarno and Carré, but Le Siècle is quite a fun place. The evening begins with karaoke, and Arabic dancing, then you can have something to eat - the food is not expensive. Then they take away the tables and it becomes a disco. It also has very nice girls. It is actually an important part of our job to check out these places.

What about a day out?

People are surprised that Belgium is so small. Bruges is 45 minutes away and we also have Antwerp, the diamond city, nearby. The cathedral is definitely worth a visit. Brussels is a very green city and we have lots of parks. The Parc de Cinquantenaire was created to celebrate the independence of Belgium and has three museums. The Parc au Brussels has a historic statue - there is always a story attached to the parks.

Crowne Plaza reservations: 0800 890 410

Conway's: 00 32 25 11 26 68

Le Siècle: 00 32 25 13 08 10

fields.trailText: Sarah Ryle reports on why the tourists are staying away.
fields.body:
One heatwave does not a summer make and the crowds who flocked to the coast last weekend are unlikely to revive the long-term decline in British seaside resorts, the holiday industry admits.

Blackpool, Bournemouth and Torquay aside - the big three continue to defy the national pattern - it seems that tourists want much, much more for their buoyant pound than the home front can offer.

'Most people do not take their main holiday in Britain, but more people are taking more holidays in general and this will support the market in this country,' insisted Peter Hampson, director of the British Resorts Association. 'They look for other attractions aside from the beach.'

Others are less optimistic. 'The London market is booming,' said Miles Quest. 'Hotels are very, very busy, but elsewhere they are fighting each other tooth and nail for business.'

The strength of the pound, added to the cooler-than-average weather - last weekend excepted - is another cause for dismay. 'It is widely recognised that the pound is very strong at the moment, while currencies in many of our target markets are very weak,' said the British Tourist Authority. 'This surely affects potential visitors' perceptions of Britain as an affordable destination.

'Britain seems very expensive against other European destinations. This impacts on visitors coming from other parts of Europe, as well as those coming from the US, as the euro has fallen severely against the dollar.'

The industry could do with a buoyant year as latest figures show that 1999 was disappointing: holiday visitors fell by 5 per cent, out of line with the rest of Europe.

This year of all years should mark a revival of the domestic holiday industry because £5 billion of National Lottery money has been spent on attractions ranging from ecology parks to revived canal routes. The first national cycle route, opened last week, was part of the millennium programme.

But many of the projects are not due to open officially until next year. Some of them have responded imaginatively, according to Deidre Livingstone, millennium marketing manager at the BTA.

'It is amazing that people are prepared to pay £3 a head to visit the building sites and watch attractions like the National Botanic Gardens in Wales and the Eden Project in Cornwall taking shape,' she said. 'It is what Australians call sticky-beaking and it seems to be gaining in popularity. It gives people the chance to be nosey.'

She called on other attractions, particularly those in unpopular locations like the Earth Centre in Doncaster, to learn from the Dome's mistakes and offer imaginative promotions to win more visitors.

fields.headline: The waiting game
fields.standfirst: Thousands of holidaymakers were stranded at airports last weekend when an air traffic control computer failed.  Robin Barton offers tips on what to do if your flight is grounded
fields.trailText: Thousands of holidaymakers were stranded at airports last weekend when an air traffic control computer failed. Robin Barton offers tips on what to do if your flight is grounded.
fields.body:
It's the last thing you need before a hard-earned holiday.You've packed your bags, cancelled the milk, left the key with your neighbours, remembered your passport and sweated in car, bus or train to meet your check-in time at the airport. Only to find that, when you get there, your flight has been delayed and you have hours to kill before take-off.

Last weekend holidaymakers across the country found themselves stuck with nowhere to go when a crucial air traffic control computer crashed at the service's West Drayton centre. As temperatures soared, discomfort grew.

Delays can be caused by all sorts of things: hurricanes in the Caribbean, strikes in Spain, bomb scares, wars and hijacks. With air traffic increasing by 5 per cent every year, and persistent problems with an overloaded air traffic control network, it is wise to be prepared for more chaos, especially since July and August are busier months than June.

Last weekend more than 400 flights in and out of Heathrow were cancelled. The previous week a 20-minute glitch caused 12 flights to be stopped, but the effects were felt for days since crews and planes were in the wrong place. EasyJet cancelled its entire weekend's operation, which suggests it was cheaper to keep its fleet on the ground. Flight cancellations are indiscriminate: it doesn't matter if you are Sir Bobby Charlton travelling to a football match in Belgium or William Hague hoping to attend a meeting in Portugal, you too could be forced to set up temporary home in a departure lounge. Here's how to survive.

The airports

Heathrow, at 3,000 acres and 1,250 flights per day, is Europe's largest airport by any criterion, so there will be much more for passengers to do and buy than at other UK airports. In the event of a delay, management may provide extra staff, seating, blankets and water. Children's colouring books are available from information desks at airports run by BAA.

Your rights

There are three main players in the waiting game (airport, airline and tour operator) and no hard and fast rules. The best advice is to buy travel insurance and check that you are covered for delays and cancellations. Another important point to remember is that although you will usually be allowed to go home to wait - even after you have checked in - it is your responsibility to catch your flight, and delays can shorten as well as lengthen.

But there are guidelines: delays of three hours merit a food voucher of £3, and passengers delayed for six hours are entitled to a main meal. If you miss a business meeting or just a day of your holiday, you may be able to claim compensation, but it depends on who is responsible for the delay. For example, airlines are are not liable for bad weather delays, but may themselves demand last weekend's losses back from the Civil Aviation Authority.

The small print in tour operators' brochures will tell you how far they will go to help you. Air2000 and First Choice, for instance, supply refreshment vouchers for delays of more than three hours and will pay for a meal after a longer delay. They can also arrange and fund overnight B&B accommodation if necessary.

Operators who use charter airlines find it difficult to allow customers extra time on holiday since charter flights are booked by the week. However, those who use scheduled airlines may be able to extend their holidays by a day or two.

British Airways Holidays' policy is to deal with individual situations as and when they arise (it has a 24-hour duty office for customer enquiries). Last weekend it dealt with 400 passengers, offering the opportunity to cancel their holiday at no cost or making amendments to schedules to fit in with later scheduled flights, but the company did not pay for any overnight accommodation.

Things to take

Families with very young children should of course take a supply of their necessities, but remember that airports have shops on both sides of the check-in gate selling nappies and baby food. Bring favourite board games, books, a pack of cards or portable computer games.

Things to do

Passing the time should not be too much of a problem at Heathrow . The most important thing to remember is that there is free bus travel within the airport perimeter. Each terminal offers something different, but all are easily accessible by bus, as is the Heathrow visitor centre and the hotels on the main access road.

Terminal 1 has a small golf studio with an electronic golf simulator in which golfers can practise their swing (£10 for 15 minutes). Alternatively the Beauty Centre offers facials, makeovers, manicures and massages and stocks leading brands. Free makeovers are also available from the Mac shop in Terminal 3 , subject to demand. The Hilton Hotel near Terminal 4 offers access to its gym, pool and solarium for £10.

Arcades with a wide range of games machines are located in Terminals 2 and 3 ( Voyager in Terminal 2 and Serendipity and Sega in Terminal 3). Under-sevens should head for the large play area in the Flight Connection Centre (far end of Terminal 1) for climbing frames and soft toys. It is well padded but unsupervised.

The Queen's Building is located between Terminals 1 and 2 and houses the new business centre (open 7am-7pm, Monday to Friday, closed weekends). Unlimited access to the lounge is £20, use of the computers (and the internet) is £4.50 per half hour and there are charges to send faxes or use the photocopier. Call 020 8759 2434 for information.

The business centre is in a quiet area of the airport, but for real tranquillity head outside for the multi-denominational chapel, near Car park 2. Unremarkable from the exterior, it is rather like entering a gloomy spaceship - the dome-shaped underground room has a roughly textured, grey finish and, despite spotlights, it is fairly dark. However, it is definitely relaxing, and there is usually a chaplain on hand for a chat. On the other side of the Garden of Remembrance is a small, bright prayer room. The garden is rather misleadingly named, since there are no green spaces at Heathrow. There is a further prayer area for Muslim travellers in Terminal 3.

The Spectators' Viewing Gallery (020 8745 5259) on the roof of Terminal 2, from which passengers can watch planes take off and land, is also free. A perfect way to kill a few hours is to take a free bus ride to the Heathrow Visitor Centre ( 020 8745 6655). The facilities include a flight simulator (£1 a go) and interactive displays explaining the airport's history and the roles of its employees. If you fancy joining the workforce there is even a job centre.

While facilities at regional airports may not be quite so extensive, many will have other advantages. Stanley Park at Manchester Airport is popular with both staff and passengers, while the city centre itself is just 20 minutes away by car. The airport also offers a children's play area, a business centre with internet and fax machines, beauty salons and hairdressers. In the event of major delays they will supply blankets, colouring books and children's entertainers.

Stansted also has a play area, an internet exchange and the Millennium Lounge, which is open to over-16s from 5.30am to 9.30pm. The entrance charge of £15 covers complimentary drinks from the café and bar, complimentary newspapers, TV and music stations, and workstations with fax, phones, internet and email. Stansted village itself is just a bus ride away.

Things to buy

When it comes to shopping, Heathrow is in a league of its own - definitely have your credit card at the ready. It is claimed that the profusion of upmarket designer shops ( Gucci, Chanel, Hermès and Liberty are all in Terminal 3) is justified by market research into the demographic profile of the Heathrow passenger. Whatever the reason, it means that there are plenty of tax-free bargains on the other side of the check-in barrier: Gucci sunglasses can be picked up for £80 to £100, or you can spend up to £1,000 on a Gucci watch.

Many shops will look after purchases until you return from holiday, so if you have a long wait ahead, why not do some Christmas shopping?

Another option might be to invest in a Walkman or portable mini-disc player at Dixons (Terminals 1-4), all of which will be cheaper than in the High Street. HMV and WH Smith have a wide range of CDs and mini-discs. But to keep the children really quiet, get your hands on a Gameboy (£50) and the new Pokémon game. Try the book shops, where you'll find the latest Harry Potter story, as well as Martin Amis's memoirs. Or send the kids off to the Disney store in Terminal 1.

Whiskies of the World stocks 350 different whiskies, some of which can be tasted (another way to pass the time). Prices range from £8 to £3,500 for a 50-year-old Glenfiddich. The Cigar House and The Caviar House (both stocking pretty much what you'd expect) are also worth a visit, whether you are a connoisseur or not. Don't forget that if you are travelling outside the European Union you can still shop at duty-free prices.

Do not expect a comparable selection of shops at regional airports such as Stansted, Southampton, Edinburgh and Luton. However, all have duty-free shops, newsagents and book shops.

Refreshments and amenities

Free showers and baby-changing facilities are now available at most airports. Restaurants vary enormously. Egon Ronay produces a guide to eating at BAA airports (including Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted, Southampton, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Aberdeen).

Heathrow leads the way. Pret à Manger in Terminal 1 rates highly, as does Harry Ramsden's (fish and chips, £6) and the Parallel 54 cocktail bar in Terminal 3's Food Village. He declines to rate Burger King, but this is a cost effective option (£4.29 for a meal). Chez Gerard and TGI Fridays have both opened outlets in Terminal 3 recently.

Garfunkel's at Gatwick, Bewley's at Southampton, Pizza Hut at Glasgow and Brophy's at Aberdeen also won plaudits, but it is clear that passengers should not arrive with high expectations if they are travelling from a crowded regional airport.

Bottles of water (average £1) are readily available from various outlets, and airports are capable of frequently restocking essential items.

webTitle: Timing of sacking raises assembly questions

fields.headline: Timing of sacking raises assembly questions
fields.trailText: June 25 2000: Rhodri Morgan chose the eve of the biggest event in the Welsh agricultural calendar to announce that he was putting a new person in charge of this sensitive portfolio. Out went the much vilified Christine Gwyther, and in came her deputy, Carwyn Jones, the assembly member for Bridgend.
fields.body:
It was Wales's worst kept secret. But the manner of its confirmation took everyone by surprise. Living up to his reputation as something of a maverick the first secretary Rhodri Morgan chose the eve of the biggest event in the Welsh agricultural calendar to announce that he was putting a new person in charge of this sensitive portfolio.

Out, without ceremony, went the much vilified Christine Gwyther. In came her deputy, Carwyn Jones, the assembly member for Bridgend.

It has left major uncertainties about how Mr Morgan will handle other changes in the Welsh executive in order to stamp his own mark on what in the main has been a cabinet inherited five months ago from former first secretary Alun Michael.

Although Mr Morgan had originally been expected to announce a reshuffle before the summer recess, recent briefings in Cardiff suggested he would wait until the autumn. Education secretaries Rosemary Butler and Tom Middlehurst, both said to be facing the axe, are likely to have a less than relaxing summer break while they wait to learn their fate. It has been rumoured that both will go should Mr Morgan decide to bring pre-16 and post-16 education together under one brief.

The manner of Ms Gwyther's sacking - in a weekend phone call from the first secretary - rounds off what has been a torrid 15 months for the former Pembrokeshire county council development officer since she was plucked from relative obscurity to take charge of the crisis-torn agriculture sector in Wales.

The appointment of a vegetarian to represent the industry at what was then the height of the beef crisis was more than many farmers could stomach and there were immediate demands for her resignation. But some officials who have worked closely with Ms Gwyther believe antipathy towards her was sparked as much by misogyny as by dislike of her eating habits.

In the assembly Ms Gwyther became an easy target for opposition parties keen to flex their muscles against the minority Labour regime. She was censured by assembly members over her failure to deliver on a promised calf processing scheme for Wales but remained in her post. Although she survived two other Tory inspired censure motions her reputation was dealt a further blow when the Department of the Environment in London gave the go ahead for the planting of a GM trial crop in Flintshire in the face of assembly determination to keep Wales a GM free zone.

Mr Jones, a barrister, was appointed by Morgan as deputy secretary for agriculture, environment and local government five months ago and is felt to have done a sound job.

He takes over at a time of falling farmers' incomes and particular concern over a renegotiation of compensation paid to farmers in less favoured areas.

There was concern in some quarters about the timing of the announcement which came less than 24 hours after officials had sent out press notices detailing Ms Gwyther's engagements on the opening day of the Royal Welsh Show at Builth Wells, Powys.

Mike German, Liberal Democrat leader in the assembly, said: "The show is geared around the agriculture secretary, and suddenly with only a few hours' notice everything has got to change. There is a feeling that this could have been handled a bit better."

Plaid Cymru's agriculture spokesman, Rhodri Glyn Thomas, said such a sudden reshuffle could only mean that the Welsh cabinet was in panic and had no strategy in important areas such as agriculture and rural development.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: Figures for HIV infection published last year showed 33.6 million adults and children affected worldwide, with an estimated 1.7 million of those living in Latin America and the Caribbean. These figures are a reminder of the risks of transmission of this disease. HIV can be transmitted through casual unprotected sexual intercourse, the administration of contaminated blood and blood products, and the use of contaminated needles and syringes. As casual intercourse is risky, the use of a condom is advised. Travellers to HIV endemic areas may wish to consider carrying a sterile needle and syringe kit and joining the Blood Care Foundation which can supply screened blood worldwide.

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.trailText: Damascus: Hidden Treasures of the Old City. Brigid Keenan.
fields.body:
Damascus: Hidden Treasures of the Old City

By Brigid Keenan

Photographs by Tim Beddow

Thames and Hudson, £40

One can only hope that Hafez Assad's policy of isolating Syria from the rest of the world has died with him. Damascus, out of sight for so long, has been out of mind too. Hopefully this book will help to begin the rehabilitation of a city in desperate need of restoration. Brigid Keenan writes lucidly about the city's complex history, but Tim Beddow's photographs are the real jewel, providing a fine pictorial portrait of the old city, as well as thematically detailing the treasures within.

webTitle: All passion spent in Bach's fair cities

fields.headline: All passion spent in Bach's fair cities
fields.standfirst: William Montgomery 's magical musical tour turns into a mystery one instead
fields.trailText: William Montgomery 's magical musical tour turns into a mystery one instead.
fields.body:
It was billed as a Bach tour of Weimar and Leipzig to take place during Holy Week. Wow, I thought: some cantatas, a Passion or two - all performed by east German musicians in and around the two cities where Bach spent the most productive years of his career. I leapt at the chance.

In Weimar, we stayed at the Elephant hotel. An inn since the 17th century, the present structure dates from the late Thirties. Its Nazi associations are famous - including the little balcony from which Hitler addressed crowds in the square in front of the hotel. Recently refurbished in a sort of Bauhaus style, and filled with carefully chosen 20th-century art of precisely the kind the Führer would have loathed (and I love), the Nazi associations, while not denied, have been played down. The former Hitler suite has been renamed after a local pop singer who stayed there.

The city of Weimar, since 1998 a Unesco World Heritage site, is itself a jewel box - comparable to Heidelberg for its baroque and classical splendours - and deserves far more than the day and a half we had here. Recognised by most English-speakers chiefly for its associations with the interwar experiment in democ racy - the 'Weimar Republic' - the city was for the two centuries preceding the Nazi regime a cultural centre not only for German-speakers, but for Europe.

The German poets Schiller and Weiland lived here, as did Bach and, intermittently, Mendelssohn, Victor Hugo, Liszt, Tolstoy, and a host of other European intellectuals were frequent visitors, drawn to the city by its most famous resident, Goethe. Later, this tradition of pilgrimage continued with visits from Wagner, Klee, Kandinsky, Nietzsche and Thomas Mann among others. Walter Gropius founded the Bauhaus movement here, and established its first centre at the city's Arts and Crafts school.

Pictures of the Goethe house and garden, along with pictures of the Schiller house, the Anna Amalia library, the Wittumspalais, the church of St Peter and Paul, and the Ducal Vault along with pictures of innumerable other architectural gems promise rich rewards for those who love investigating both magnificent and domestic old buildings. Sadly, these interiors were not included on our tightly planned itinerary. What was included was a visit to the Modern Art Museum - small, but excellent - and a tour of the facilities of the Conference Centre.

Now I like a good Conference Centre as well as the next guy, and as conference centres go this was a humdinger (all in American cherrywood and black upholstery, set in a park with a striking reflecting pool). But I am not sure I would have elected to go there at the cost of visiting the city's more, well, traditional sites.

The odd thing about this press trip, especially given that it had been billed as a Bach Tour, is how determinedly uncultural it was. I had the feeling that it had been organised by the Chamber of Commerce in the hope that this collection of British journalists would write about what a wonderful place these two east German cities would be to hold an annual conference.

Our German hosts were by and large young - too young to have had much life experience under the GDR. Yet our group was old - well, older - and seemed obsessed with quizzing everyone we encountered about the old regime. Interested at first, I began to feel embarrassed by them. The citizens of the 'New Countries', which is how the former East German states refer to themselves, were doing their best to show us how things are; yet we seemed mainly concerned with how they used to be.

Unlike Weimar, Leipzig really can't be recommended to the tourist (although it has a great Conference Centre). The war damage was extensive, and instead of reconstructing what had been a prosperous 19th-century city with a medieval core, the GDR rebuilt it as a Socialist showcase. Time and again our tour guide would take us to an undistinguished building and say 'This is where once stood' so and so. 'Sadly, this building no longer exists' became a much-used refrain.

The most glaring remnant of this period of reconstruction is the strikingly ugly university tower, visible from any point in the city. The brutality of this, and the ghastly Sixties buildings which huddle around it, is emphasised by the memory of the medieval university it replaced.

In Leipzig we stayed at the splendid Hotel Füstenhof, an 18th-century mansion originally the home of a Leipzig banker. Like the Elephant, it is part of the Kempenski group, and in both hotels we had superlative meals (conference organisers take note). In fact, the city has good amenities - restaurants, music, theatre, bars and hotels, and the shopping district, concentrated in traditional 19th-century arcades, is good. I think it would be a lively city in which to live and be a student, when one would have the time really to get to know the place.

And Bach? Sadly, there was no Bach. The closest we came in Weimar was walking past a parking lot where his home used to stand, and being shown the prison where briefly he was a 'guest' of the duke; while in Leipzig we visited the St Nicholas church (as famous now for the involvement of its clergy in the downfall of the GDR as for its Bach associations) and the building site that is the currently-being-refurbished St Thomas church.

 Details of two-night Bach packages in Weimar and Leipzig are available on Kempinski's free reservation number 00-800-426-313-55

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today.
fields.body:
 The South Bank will ring with the sound of panpipes and the air will be scented by an Ethiopian Coffee Ceremony at Celebrating Sanctuary, Coin Street Festival's homage to refugees' contribution to London. 2pm-6pm. Bernie Spain Gardens, Oxo Tower Wharf, London SE1. Free. Phone 020 7401 2255.

 The life of the meadow vole is a difficult one, and The Vole Run at Muncaster Castle, Cumbria, full of 7ft grass and 8ft daisies, aims to show what life is like as one of these creatures. Adults £6, children £4, including admission to all of the castle's attractions. Phone 01229 717614.

 Sample weird and wonderful medieval cures at Wenlock Priory , Much Wenlock, Shropshire. A Dark Ages 'physician' will explain ancient cures. Phone 01952 727466. Adults £2.70, kids £1.40. 10am-6pm.

 Don't avoid the Shrewsbury International Kite and Boomerang Festival just because you don't have a kite; experts will show you how to build one and give tips on taking to the air. Sundorne Recreation Ground, Sundorne, Shrewsbury. Free. 10am-5pm. Phone 01743 363 694.

 Around 200 gardening outlets in the UK are celebrating National Garden Party Weekend . Children's activities, bouncy castles and demonstrations ease the pain of the garden centre visit for youngsters. Phone your local garden centre for details.

 Paint a digital mural just by waving at a wall at Artworks, The Lowry, Salford Quays, Manchester, where technology is used to get creative juices flowing. Phone 0161 876 2020. 10am-5pm. Adults, children £3.75.

 The London Symphony Orchestra aims to introduce children to Shakespeare and classical music in a family concert, 'If Music be the Food of Love', at the Barbican, London. The performance, starting at 3pm, features interpretations of Romeo and Juliet by Tchaikovsky, Berlioz and Prokofiev. Phone 020 7638 8891. Adults £6.50,children £3.

 Celebrate Midsummer with a festival at Hampton Court, Herefordshire. Children can make flower head dresses while adults enjoy theatre and music. Phone 0121 767 4090. Adults £5, Children £3.

 The environmental alphabet will be explained at Mawddach Valley Nature Reserve , Gwynedd, through games and activities which aim to inspire kindness to the environment. Free. Phone 01341 422071. 11am-5pm.

 The Ulster Jazz band will play in the gardens of Mount Stewart, Newtownards, Co Down. Visitors can enjoy the magnificent gardens for the usual admission price to this National Trust property. 3pm-5pm. Adults £3.50, children £1.75. Phone 028 4278 8387.

fields.headline: Cool luxury and hot jazz
fields.standfirst: Mike Bradley  falls for the charms of St Lucia and its music
fields.trailText: Mike Bradley falls for the charms of St Lucia and its music.
fields.body:
Smiles. Smiles are the souvenirs I treasure most from my trip to the small West Indian island of St Lucia. Yes, there was sunshine, sea like blue Champagne and crustaceans in every liqueur known to man, but from the moment the BWIA plane touched down on the surf-fringed airstrip at Hewanorra there began an endless succession of 100-watt, happy smiles, almost all accompanied by a 'Welcome to San Loosha', straight from the heart, that I will never forget.

From Hewanorra a half-hour minibus ride wove giddily round the potholes in the roads to my destination: the luxurious Jalousie Hilton on the west coast of the island. Tucked away beneath the dense coconut palms in its own exclusive bay between the island's famous Pitons - two green peaks thrown up by volcanic activity 40,000 years ago - this was like no hotel I had ever seen before. It describes itself as a 'resort and spa', with guests housed in separate villas, and you really do need recourse to a map to find your way around the 300 acres of this former plantation. To aid you in your travels, a discreet fleet of minibuses cruise the lanes invisibly, materialising magically within 30 seconds of a guest's request.

This is a destination for the true tropical sybarite. There is so much to do - with four restaurants, three bars, tennis courts, swimming pool, beach, golf course and spa centre - that to reveal one's intention to explore the island beyond the gated perimeter is considered at the very least eccentric. What more could you want, the eyes of the puzzled staff seem to say. But it is essential to get out and about, if only to stop yourself from becoming irreversibly accustomed to private plunge-pools and saronged Bond-girl-alikes (usually honeymooning with some smouldering James) by the gallon.

So what do you do? Well, you can drive to the nearby botanical gardens, which boast waterfalls and welcome shade in a climate where the needle barely dips below the 30-degree mark. There you can wander slowly between beds containing several species of spectacular Heliconia whose huge, paddle-shaped leaves shroud strings of bright red bracts which give the shrub its nickname Lobster Claw. Hundreds of hibiscus, oleanders, passion flowers, sky flowers, are all here in abundance, and you can see tiny hummingbirds darting between nutmeg, banana, coconut, breadfruit and mango trees. It's enough to put the more familiar strelitzias to shame.

From there it's a short trip to the sulphur springs, worryingly referred to in tourist itineraries as 'Drive-In Volcano'. You can smell these steaming, spluttering springs a mile away, but they do serve as a reminder of the volcanic history of the island as well as providing the locals with food for monumental superstition. Equestrians can opt to ride Western-style on obedient horse through active banana and coconut plantations on the Mourne Coubaril estate, though beware the falling fruit. The more adventurous - it cannot be stressed enough that you must be very fit for this - can go for long guided walks into the rainforest which covers the higher reaches of the mountains in the centre of the island, where peaceful, isolated communities of Rastafarians practise their 'agricul ture'. Again, botanically this is fascinating territory - all banyans and strange epiphytes and secret waterfalls spilling into rock pools visited by large land-crabs - but be sure to carry water and food as the trek is an arduous one, especially in the heat.

Gastronomic adventures can also be rewarding, though it was initially on the recommendation of the view at sunset that I ventured to the Dasheene Restaurant at Ladera, a 15-minute drive away in the hills. At precisely 6.30pm the huge burning ball of the sun disappeared beneath the horizon, swallowed up in a sea of impossible pinks and blues. The food that followed was delicious if a little contrived - good fresh raw materials such as local crab and prawn whose flavours were restrained or smothered rather than encouraged. When it came to pudding, however, Ladera's Tropical Fruit Creme Brulee out-bruleed any other brulee I have ever encountered.

Bronzed and, despite the brulee, visibly leaner from my extensive amateur forays into an undersea world populated with marine creatures every bit as colourful and exotic as the plant life, it was with a heavy heart that I hung up my air-conditioning remote-control for the last time and headed north for a very different holiday experience in the capital, Castries. This time I travelled by boat, which is a good way to see otherwise inaccessible parts of the coastline and drop in on places such as wealthy Marigot Bay, the location for the first Dr Doolittle film, where numerous stars including Mick Jagger have homes high above the bay.

Castries has a ramshackle charm about it. The elegant town square is now called Derek Walcott Square after St Lucia's most famous, Nobel-winning literary son, though its name has changed over the centuries through successive occupations by the British and the French. There you will find vendors selling crafts, basketwork, T-shirts and all manner of local fast foods - dasheene (a relation of the turnip), fried plantain, peas and rice. The surrounding architecture consists largely of late nineteenth and early twentieth-century wooden buildings built in the French style with intricate fretwork balconies overhanging the pavement. Of special interest on this principally Roman Catholic island is thecathedral, with its apse ceiling painting of five saints with St Lucy at the centre.

Here I stayed in the altogether more American-style surroundings of the Royal St Lucian hotel on Reduit Beach. A more public affair, most rooms look out on an elaborate swimming pool which snakes under bridges and round bends in a complex of pink sun terraces, culminating in a sunken, 'swim-up' bar at the centre for those who like to enjoy their parasolled planter's punches in a semi-submerged state. The beach itself was brochure-perfect: a long white strand punctuated by pink sails and caressed by soft Caribbean surf at the edge of a warm azure sea. Were it not for the allure of the snorkelling, glass-bottom boats, jetskis, waterskiing et al , it would be easy to pass a week under a thatched umbrella there with a sack of novels for company.

What drew me away was the annual St Lucia Jazz Festival. It's really more a case of soul and jazz, in fact, and this year's headliners were Herbie Hancock, Joe Lovano, Joe Sample, Brenda Russell, Spyro Gyra, George Duke and Monty Alexander, supplemented by soul stars Gladys Knight, Lou Rawls and James Ingram. Many of the concerts didn't even begin until midnight, beneath an ivory Caribbean moon, whereas others were staged in the sensuous heat of tropical afternoons on palm-fringed, sandy beaches.

Billed as being 'to jazz what Jamaica's Sunsplash is to reggae', St Lucia Jazz 2000 took place at venues around the island, though the biggest gigs were held at Pigeon Island, just north of Castries. In the capital itself, Cameroonian jazz singer and bass-player Richard Bona's intimate set at the Half Yellow Moon club provided the high-point of the entire festival, and back in Derek Walcott Square local singer Mervyn Wilkinson and venerable St Lucian calypsonian Ronald 'Boo' Hinkson entertained enthusiastic crowds with their own homegrown musical delights.

As the curtain fell on my stay in St Lucia Land of Smiles, I realised I had quickly learned to dance to the music of a different drum. Be it in the guise of jazz pilgrim, shambolic amateur naturalist or just five-star sybarite, I will return.

St Lucia spas

Jalousie Hilton

Not being particularly au fait with these things I opted to go for the Caribbean Massage. This turned out to be a standard massage carried by a Caribbean person and very good it was, too. It lasted approximately 55 minutes and cost US$75. An enjoyable treatment using lavender oil, it certainly relaxed tired muscles and eased tension. I emerged feeling revitalised if pleasantly drowsy.

Royal St Lucian

I've never been keen on cutting my nails, so seeing manicure and pedicure on the menu I went for that, at US$50. True, you do feel mildly guilty as someone else clips and digs and files away, but then they bathe your feet and hands in magical balms and you just want more. As a bloke, I'm not sure about the shiny transparent nail-varnish, though...
