In the capital itself, Cameroonian jazz singer and bass-player Richard Bona's intimate set at the Half Yellow Moon club provided the high-point of the entire festival, and back in Derek Walcott Square local singer Mervyn Wilkinson and venerable St Lucian calypsonian Ronald 'Boo' Hinkson entertained enthusiastic crowds with their own homegrown musical delights. As the curtain fell on my stay in St Lucia Land of Smiles, I realised I had quickly learned to dance to the music of a different drum. Be it in the guise of jazz pilgrim, shambolic amateur naturalist or just five-star sybarite, I will return. St Lucia spas Jalousie Hilton Not being particularly au fait with these things I opted to go for the Caribbean Massage. This turned out to be a standard massage carried by a Caribbean person and very good it was, too. It lasted approximately 55 minutes and cost US$75. An enjoyable treatment using lavender oil, it certainly relaxed tired muscles and eased tension. I emerged feeling revitalised if pleasantly drowsy. Royal St Lucian I've never been keen on cutting my nails, so seeing manicure and pedicure on the menu I went for that, at US$50. True, you do feel mildly guilty as someone else clips and digs and files away, but then they bathe your feet and hands in magical balms and you just want more. As a bloke, I'm not sure about the shiny transparent nail-varnish, though...

webTitle: Shunted on a branch line to nowhere

fields.headline: Shunted on a branch line to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Mike Carter  retraces a rail route of his childhood, in search of the magnificence and power he remembers as an awestruck lad
fields.trailText: Mike Carter retraces a rail route of his childhood, in search of the magnificence and power he remembers as an awestruck lad.
fields.body:
The first thing I did on arrival at Birmingham's New Street station was pay a visit to W.H. Smith's for a pocket book containing locomotive numbers. I couldn't find one. 'Excuse me, do you still sell those little trainspotting books?' I asked the assistant.

'I don't think we sell that type of thing any more,' she said, looking at this 35-year-old man as if I'd just asked for the latest copy of Nuns In Rubber. 'I'll ask my manager.'

'DAVE, DO WE HAVE ANY OF THOSE TRAINSPOTTING BOOKS LEFT?' she shouted from one end of the shop to the other. The bustle stopped and dozens of pairs of eyes bored into me with a mixture of vilification and pity. I looked around for my friend, Tom, who had driven me to the station. He had dropped behind a counter and become engrossed in a magazine for the concrete industry. As a boy, I had been a trainspotter. Now that innocent noun had carved a place for itself as a pejorative and lay somewhere between paedophile and rapist in the nation's collective conscience. I left the shop quickly. Without my book.

A quarter of a century earlier, the station was the focal point of my troubled life. Back then, in the space of 12 months, cancer hollowed out my beloved grandmother, my grandfather died, and my uncle James, who'd had such an influence on me, suffered a fatal stroke. On the way back from James's funeral, my father announced he was leaving my mother. Shortly afterwards, my mother was diagnosed with cancer. Not a particularly good time. I was fat, lonely and miserable, and witnessing an ordered life crumble into chaos and dust.

Every Saturday I would buy a platform ticket and just sit, watching. I fell in love - with the noise, the diesel fumes, the possibility of travel, of getting away, putting distance between myself and a life that had become unfamiliar and full of conflict. Somebody else's life. Somebody else's script.

I saved my pocket money and progressed from platform tickets to tickets to travel. I would pitch up at the ticket office at New Street, empty my pockets and ask how far my money would take me. Often, it was just to Wolverhampton or Stafford, but sometimes I'd get as far as Crewe or Doncaster, with their bustling locomotive works and engine sheds - spotting paradises.

In the summer, I'd purchase a railrover ticket, which gave me unlimited travel for a week. Sometimes I'd be gone for two or three days at a time. I could nearly always end the evening on a train travelling overnight and get some sleep but, on more than one occasion, I had to get my head down in the warm embrace of a waiting room. I had become obsessed.

My parents worried, but they had other things to occupy them. It felt good to get away. To be sitting on a train. Going somewhere, anywhere, as long as it wasn't home, where people shouted and cried and said wild, dangerous things.

One summer's weekend in 1975, aged 11, I undertook a trainspotter's pilgrimage. I headed north to Crewe, home of Crewe Works, one of the largest locomotive works in the world, occupying 365 acres. From Crewe, across the Pennines to Doncaster, to the fabled 'Donny' Works, where generations of trainbuilders had turned out legendary engines. From Doncaster to Darlington, and then on to Shildon, the location then of one of Europe's biggest wagon-building plants but, more importantly, the venue for The Railway Cavalcade, a celebration of 150 years of railways. Shildon was not chosen lightly for the honour of hosting this festival. It was outside the Mason's Arms pub in the town that the first public passenger train departed in 1825 for Stockton on the Stockton and Darlington Railway.

On that Sunday, I sat and watched a procession of trains go by: Stephenson's Rocket, the Flying Scotsman, Mallard, Great Western Castles and Southern Region Bullied Pacifics; a pantheon of steam locomotives. Also on display were contemporary British-built locos, still setting the standard the world over. It was a sublime day, embracing the past, and looking optimistically to the future.

During the following 25 years, my love of trains never diminished, although when I discovered beer and girls the attraction of sitting on a freezing platform lost its allure. Now, curious to see what had happened in the time I'd been away, I under took that same journey. From Birmingham, I headed north on a Virgin train, through the tunnel that leads away from New Street. It felt good to be travelling on a train again, not commuting or on business, but just for the sake of it. Ahead was a cartoon mousehole of bright light, and the infinite possibilities that travel brings.

I found the guard and asked him what working on the modern railways was like. I told him I was writing a piece for The Observer. He stiffened, and told me that he had signed a contract forbidding him from talking to the press. I'd be arrested if Virgin found out what I was doing. He scuttled off, leaving me feeling a little seditious.

The approach to Crewe used to be memorable for spotters. The four tracks fanned out into a vast marshalling yard. There was Crewe Diesel Depot, where you were guaranteed to see dozens and dozens of locomotives.

It was raining when I got to Crewe this time. The marshalling yard had shrunk considerably and in it were columns of vandalised and neglected coaches. At the diesel depot, a dozen locos stood idle. Half of them had broken windscreens or had their side panels ripped off to reveal missing engines - emasculated giants. It was a depressing sight. I stood on the platform in a flurry of wind and water, the overhead cables fizzing and humming. This trip had seemed a good idea at the time, but I was beginning to have regrets. When I used to come to Crewe, I felt part of it. Now, I felt like an outsider. The trains looked like Portakabins on wheels. Each train carried a different livery; a private affair. The staff, in their Virgin Puffa jackets, looked like they'd be more at home serving fries and Whoppers.

The next day I headed for the site of the old British Rail Crewe Works. In 1837 the first station was opened by the Grand Junction Railway Company, but it was not until 1843, when the GJRC decided to site its workshops at Crewe, that the town was born. At its height, the works employed 30,000 people and made some of the finest trains the world has seen. The ubiquitous HSTs that ply their trade all over the country were made at Crewe. During the last 20 years, the works has been run down and what little remained was sold to the private sector. Adtranz, the company which took over, employs around 1,000 people, largely engaged in collision repair or refurbishment. No locomotives are made.

Part of the old works is occupied by a huge Safeway store. In the car park there is a steam tank engine, painted in the supermarket's corporate colours and surrounded by rubber matting for children to play on.

Almost hidden behind Safeway is the Railway Age, a small heritage centre to celebrate 150 years of the railways in Crewe. It would be easy to miss. On one of the sidings is the prototype of the Advanced Passenger Train. During the late Eighties, the APT tilting train was developed at Crewe, at enormous cost to the taxpayer, to achieve greater speeds on the twisting line to Glasgow. Early trials were successful, but there were problems with the tilting mechanism and it was abandoned by a government with no vested interest in the future of trainbuilding. In 2002, Richard Branson's new Pendolino tilting trains will enter service on the West Coast Main Line and run past the rusting museum piece at the Heritage Centre. Virgin has invested £592 million in these trains. The tilting mechanisms are being built by Fiat in Italy, the bogies in Switzerland, and they are being assembled in the old Metro Cammell Works in Birmingham by Alstom, a French company.

I left Crewe heading for Doncaster in a box painted yellow with green sploshes. The seats were made of thin foam and all passengers faced the same way. Just like when you go back to your old school and find the seats and desks ludicrously small, so it is with these local trains. The interior was finished in a dull, utilitarian grey and, with sliding electric doors and no openable windows, the train was like a hermetically sealed tube. It was so quiet and smooth that even the clickety-clack of the wheels on the tracks was annulled.

While changing trains at Sheffield, I talked to one of the men in the uniform of Midland Mainline. He used to work at the vast Tinsley marshalling yard, just outside the Steel City. Now he stands on the station all day 'meeting and greeting, smiling at customers and being as helpful as possible'. 'I am known as a customer services supervisor,' he continued, forcing a grin. 'I can't even go for a piss without some 23-year-old graduate manager asking me where I've been.'

Another customer services operative told me that, when trains run late, it can quickly descend into chaos. 'The different companies' timetables do not connect with each other like they used to,' he said. 'It just becomes a free-for-all, and we are here to apologise for it all.'

At Doncaster, I saw my first trainspotters. I approached, telling them what I was up to. They recoiled, becoming defensive. The media had been brutal towards 'railway enthusiasts', they said, correcting my terminology, and they had no desire to provide further ammunition.

One of my abiding memories of spotting was sitting at Doncaster Station, listening for the shrill sound of the twin Napier engines of a Deltic. Silently, more than 100 tons of metal would creep into view and then erupt furiously in a maelstrom of full-open throttles and crashing coaches, the entire station shaking to its foundations. Seconds later, all that was left was the wind and a red tail light, disappearing bewitchingly into the night. It was magnificent.

Later that night I paid a visit to Doncaster Works. Up until the mid-Eighties, more than 5,000 men were employed there. The last locomotive to be built there, a Class 58, rolled off the production line in 1987. Now there are around 300 men employed there, based in a tiny part of the old site, mostly on contracts to refurbish wagon wheels and respray coaches.

I stood outside the gates that had teemed with life on my last visit. Opposite was the plant public house, now boarded up. I spoke to one of the security guards, patrolling the desolate site.

'It's such a bloody waste,' he said. 'I started here as a crane operator in 1985. There were more than 5,000 here then. I was asked: "How old are you?" I told him I was 26. He replied: "You'll still be working here when you're 65." Two years later, the plant was effectively closed down and I've been working as a security guard ever since. I earn £3.60 an hour, working a 75-hour week to survive.'

That night, in my B&B, I read an article about the 270 Class 66 locomotives that have been ordered, to be operated on British freight workings, by English, Welsh & Scottish Railways, now the sole mover of freight in Britain, Freightliner excepted. The supplier of this massive order? General Motors of Ontario. I also read about the fleet of 30 new Class 67 locomotives. The supplier? Alstom at Valencia, Spain, as sub-contractors for General Motors. It seemed the nation that invented the train was now importing them by the depot load. From Doncaster to York, the home of The National Railway Museum, and until recently, the site of York Railway Works, closed down in 1995. Finally on to Darlington, where I waited for the train to Shildon, the place where the railways began and my journey would end. I waited. And waited. And waited.

After 30 minutes, a station official appeared in an ankle-length greatcoat and military cap. The train had failed. It wasn't coming. No train was coming. One of the features of train operators having to lease rolling stock is that when they break down there is no replacement. It does not make economic sense.

And so it was that I turned up in Shildon, the birthplace of trains, in a minicab. It was howling a gale and the sky was firing a horizontal salvo of frozen bullets. The last time I was in Shildon, at the great Cavalcade, the works employed 3,000 people. The interim history carried a depressingly familiar leitmotif . In 1982, BREL, announced that it intended to close the 150-year-old works, then still one of the most profitable in the country.

Despite petitions from Sedgefield Borough Council, the closure went ahead. Unemployment in the town shot up to nearly 50 per cent, and 355 people were chasing every job vacancy in the area. Businesses folded, shops closed and the value of property plummeted. An entire generation moved away to seek work and never returned.

Schools closed, crime soared and the social and health implications of such disastrous levels of unemployment began to bite savagely. Today Shildon, where it is possible to buy a house for £6,000, is showing signs of a slow recovery.

But if you popped into The Mason's Arms and asked the locals about The Closure, you would still generate emotions of bitter and visceral intensity. In the unrelenting rain, I went to stand at the spot where I watched the trains go by all those years ago. The sidings had been ripped up, and only weeds flourished. I had seen enough and was regretting coming back. I wanted to go home.

At Doncaster, waiting for the train to London, I saw a lad taking numbers and photographs at the end of the platform. I approached him and said hello, difficult enough when you are 35, grubby from four days of travelling, and the recipient of your attentions is a schoolboy. His name was Michael, he was 14, and he came from Liverpool.

I asked him why he went trainspotting. He replied that he liked the power, the speed and the noise. He asked me if I liked writing. I couldn't answer him. I asked him about his photography. He talked about the dusting of snow on the Pennines that morning, and how marvellously the winter sun reflected off it. A dusting. Reflecting winter sun. He was 14!

We talked about trains. Michael told me he loved the old Class 47s, but hates the new Class 66s. 'They're so boring,' he said. I told him how I used to love the old Class 40s, and hated the then new 47s. 'They were so characterless,' I said. We agreed to differ.

After a while, I told Michael how my spotting began when things at home had started to go wrong. He told me he had started spotting three years previously, just about the time his parents had split up.

My train pulled in and I climbed on board. I stood at the door to wave him off. I was tired and jaded and unshaven. His nascent eyes were full of the future; sparkling and beaming. He wished me luck. I said: 'Good luck to you, too.'

fields.headline: ONdigital offers pay-per-feud
fields.standfirst: The battle hots up for football on TV, reports  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: The battle hots up for football on TV, reports Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
England v Germany, Apple v IBM, Pepsi v Coke, Sotheby's v Christie's, Bill Gates v Larry Ellison, Rupert Murdoch v almost everyone: in business as in sport, there's nothing like a dose of genuine animosity to engross the punters and fire up managers for the fray.

Over the past year or so connoisseurs of the genre have been treated to a double-decker feud that centres on the future of two of the subjects dearest to the nation's heart: football and TV.

At one level is the entertaining spat between Carlton and Granada (run by Michael Green and Gerry Robinson whose reciprocal detestation is well documented) over leadership of the consolidating ITV channels. Will Granada scupper Carlton's plan to merge with another media company, Lord Hollick's United News and Media, by making a counter-bid for United - or even Carlton itself?

The question is given added piquancy at a second level by the main antagonists' joint ownership of ONdigital, the digital terrestrial broadcaster and (putatively) interactive service purveyor. 'We're in the front row of the stalls. We're thinking of offering the world's first pay-per-view coverage of a hostile takeover,' jokes ONdigital chief executive Stuart Prebble.

Prebble has cautious grounds for cheerfulness. In its own bruising battle for the growing digital TV market with the industry's arch-scrapper, BSkyB, ONdigital has got the opposition riled. With due deference to the mood of national mourning in the aftermath of England's Euro 2000 defeat, the reason for the optimism is football, where Prebble reckons that in the recent TV rights finals ONdigital scored more goals than anyone else.

True, Sky (to the chagrin of the BBC) walked off with the headline live Premier League rights. This is another important milestone, because although the bandwidth isn't there yet, the day is approaching when the internet will be able to deliver video - 'which will really level the playing field with cable'.

ONdigital is banking that it can persuade subscribers to access the internet via the TV screen. 'We are using the same approach to interactivity as to digital TV - the way we do it, it's easier than you think it is,' says Prebble. 'There's nothing more familiar and less threatening than your TV screen. If we can provide interactivity as a natural, directly related exten sion of TV, like teletext for example, we can have people surfing without knowing it.'

Internet on TV hasn't been a giant success so far. Prebble agrees, but it's early days yet. 'We've had 40 years to become very good at making com pelling TV and only just started with online content.'

Prebble can't remember the last time he was quizzed about the state of his relations with Michael Green. For the record: perfectly good, as also with Charles Allen, who sits on the board for Granada. Prebble ripostes that if the shareholders lacked confidence in the venture's strategy or management they'd hardly have divvied up the £315m ONdigital has just spent on football rights.

Very far from sweetness and light are the gamma rays currently passing between ONdigital and its arch-rival BSkyB - ironically one of its original backers. 'We're a big customer of Sky and we'd like to be treated like that,' protests Prebble of Sky's knocking ads.

The problem goes deeper, however. Prebble complains that Sky's 'abusive' attitude to business partners makes it notoriously hard to do business with. 'You see it at every level. It's as if it's not enough that they succeed, they want their friends to fail too.' He puts it down to Sky's resentment of a successful interloper.

webTitle: Neverending story of meagre profits makes Waterstones a takeover target

fields.headline: Neverending story of meagre profits makes Waterstones a takeover target
fields.trailText: Troubled book retailer Waterstones has been the target of at least three predatory approaches in recent months. Parent company HMV Media is so far resisting selling the chain, despite the fact that its performance will look weak when the firm unveils its yearly results on 11 July.
fields.body:
Troubled book retailer Waterstones has been the target of at least three predatory approaches in recent months. Parent company HMV Media is so far resisting selling the chain, despite the fact that its performance will look weak when the firm unveils its yearly results on 11 July.

Bertelsmann, the German book publisher and retailer, and US bookstore Borders have both had offers for Waterstones rejected by HMV Media, which is jointly owned by EMI and US venture capital firm Advent. However, it is believed that a further US rival, Barnes and Noble, may now be interested. Although HMV Media says its joint owners are 'fully supportive' of the company, it admits that there needs to be an improve ment in the bookseller's performance. It denies rumours that it is prepared to split Waterstones out from the stronger HMV record retailing part of the business.

It also denies that Waterstones will need a further £50 million from the parent shareholders on top of the £550m HMV Media already carries in debt. However, sources close to the retailer say tensions have arisen between EMI and Advent over whether Waterstones should be sold.

The UK-based record company, currently embroiled in its own merger plans with AOL/TimeWarner, is increasingly ambivalent about the bookseller.

EMI holds its extraordinary general meeting tomorrow morning to approve the deal with Warner, despite rumours of a last-minute counter-bid for the company seeping into the market on Friday. EMI issued a statement saying that it had r received neither a counter-bid nor a request from shareholders to postpone tomorrow morning's AGM on the grounds that a further bid for the company would emerge.

webTitle: Why Britain needs to go back to l'école

fields.headline: Why Britain needs to go back to l'école
fields.trailText: From the moment Mary Pierce whacked a winner past Conchita Martinez at Roland Garros, you somehow knew the French were in for a good summer. Even a gruesome Johnny Halliday special performance in front of the Eiffel Tower could not dampen the idea that while Cool Britannia is as hip as a Shackleton recliner, La Belle France is definitely frache.
fields.body:
From the moment Mary Pierce whacked a winner past Conchita Martinez at Roland Garros, you somehow knew the French were in for a good summer. Even a gruesome Johnny Halliday special performance in front of the Eiffel Tower could not dampen the idea that while Cool Britannia is as hip as a Shackleton recliner, La Belle France is definitely frache.

Add to this the spectacle of Euro 2000, where the combined talents of the Arsenal squad - sorry, French national team - dazzled the opposition, and Arsene Wenger pronounced them 'five years ahead in footballing terms of England' (we wish!), and the pile of deals ignited by French companies and it makes you queasier than a bad channel crossing.

France is playing a corporate blinder, too. Vivendi, under the ambitious Jean-Marie Messier, took over Seagram and became the world's second-largest media company. France Télécom bought Orange - though it could be interpreted as a reverse takeover, so high were the premiums for retaining the Orange management. Then there is Publicis buying the proudest name in British advertising, Saatchi and Saatchi, and yogurt maker extraordinaire Danone, with its cheeky bid for Nabisco.

Looking for a common thread to tie Thierry Henry to a fruit purée manufacturer may appear a spurious exercise. But the success of these French team enterprises has a common foundation: training. And in particular relevance to its corporate success, state involvement.

Ten days ago hundreds of thousands of French 18-year-olds were struggling through a Baccalaureate, which included questions such as 'Can the demands of justice be reconciled with the demands of liberty?' Imagine laying such a pearl before the massed ranks of Blunkett's underachievers. The very idea of grappling with a philosophical notion is anathema to benchmarking, yet fits well with the vocational aspects of a broader curriculum. Put that in your beacon school and smoke it, as they say.

The fact that Messier came through the country's egalitarian education system and graduated from the Ecole Polytechnique, is also significant. The rather turgid emphasis the French have on state-funded comprehensive education is reaping the same results as its attention to young footballers. They don't, of course, have lovely photos of a dappled prince in an Eton cloister to put in their newspapers, so they borrow ours. But it seems a small price to pay for excellence in sport and commerce.

There are, of course, other factors in their corporate success - such as the way the French government shamelessly protected its previously nationalised industries, such as the utilities which comprise half of Vivendi, but far from bloating into unwieldy bureaucracies, their sleeping giants are dynamic worldbeaters oddly able to compete in the free market.

So while the French desire to involve the state in education and corporate life is curiously repugnant to our own Thatcherite free market thinking, we cannot deny that it is hugely effective.

To watch French television you would not believe that many products are sold in France which are not mobile phones; their adoration of the prototype French internet, Minitel, has been replaced by a wholehearted embracing of the world wide web. The towering business parks in the outskirts of Antibes are as impressive as anything in California. There is nothing backward about the French attitude to business or international development.

Of course one takes with this what other commentators have correctly identified as a chauvinistic tendency - but then beating the world is one sure-fire way to resist it.

We could, it seems, learn a lot from the French, in football and in business. But for anyone who listened to the highlights of the Halliday concert there is a crumb of comfort - their music is still bloody awful.

fields.headline: Brothers
fields.trailText: Peter Preston: You come out feeling soiled and thinking that the Daily Mail may be right after all
fields.body: Brothers, a marginally dramatic clone of late-night Sky TV's randy holidays exposed, follows five yobs to Greece and stews them there in a pot of vomit, semen, faeces and ouzo. You come out feeling soiled and thinking that the Daily Mail may be right after all. But ritual disgust is beside the point. Martin Dunkerton (of modest Channel 4 fame) thinks that there's box-office gold at the end of this unwiped orifice. If he's right, we can probably forget Euro 2004 as well.

webTitle: FT on a palmtop? Not very portable

fields.headline: FT on a palmtop? Not very portable
fields.trailText: So now we know: after the internet boom, there was not quite internet bust - but a great cooling of hype and expectation. Future somewhat delayed. Which brings us straight to those analysts who, only a couple of years ago, were prophesying the imminent death - maybe within half a decade - of conventional newspapers on conventional newsprint. Demise somewhat postponed.
fields.body:
So now we know: after the internet boom, there was not quite internet bust - but a great cooling of hype and expectation. Future somewhat delayed. Which brings us straight to those analysts who, only a couple of years ago, were prophesying the imminent death - maybe within half a decade - of conventional newspapers on conventional newsprint. Demise somewhat postponed.

No British newspaper has ploughed more millions into the net than the Financial Times. No newspaper, you'd suppose, would see itself closer to the precipice of electronic transition. But Richard Lambert, editor of the FT, firmly believes that 'printed newspapers have a bright future', and argued his case in a notable lecture the other day.

The Lambert reasons to be cheerful? Portability. 'Have you ever tried to download a big feature on to a three-inch palm pilot?' Browsability. 'Flicking your eye across a sheet of newsprint is a much more efficient way of seeing what catches your fancy than doing the same on a screen.' Signposting. 'Newspapers are good at sending signals about how much value to attribute to a piece of information.' Reliability. 'A reliable newspaper is a kind of safety blanket - a point of reference at a fixed point in the day.'

No head in the sand, though. 'I'm well aware that many of these qualities will be replicable on the web in the coming decade. But a good newspaper has other, softer, qualities which will be harder to replicate.' Like 'a character built up over many years which is relevant and attractive to its customers'. The words he keeps using are 'trust' and 'knowledge' (as opposed to raw facts).

Things will change: of course, they'll change. More scoops on the front page, better analysis and comment, less routine information. 'The idea of a newspaper of record will die - in a digital world there are many better ways of keeping records than on piles of fading newsprint'.

But, for Lambert, this isn't an either/or debate. It's a question of finding how both ways fit together - just as, in the FT newsroom, online reporters and print reporters work side by side.

Too calm? Only six months ago, such a prognosis would have seemed benign, going on complacent, in an old industry fearing a harsh new future. It wasn't at all what the dotcom prophets were saying. Now, though, we can sit back and examine the evidence, and the FT, locked in net battle with CNN, Reuters, Dow Jones and a host of niche operators, is a prime place to start. This is the online front line. If print is failing, it will fail here first.

Yet, curiously, there's no sign of failure: just the reverse. The FT's circulation in the May ABCs was up to 461,498 copies a day. If you factor that into the rolling six-month average and compare this year with last year, you have, with one exception, the biggest rise anywhere in our national press, up 18.56 per cent. (The exception, up 27.59 per cent on the same basis, is Sunday Business, which merely bolsters the argument).

Ah! But surely there's a glitch here? Everybody knows that FT growth over years has been abroad: new foreign editions and printing centres round the globe. Lambert himself admits: 'Sales outside the UK have more than doubled in the past five years: they are now much bigger than our sales in the home market'.

True enough, but not the whole truth; 58.69 per cent of the FT's circulation last month went beyond British borders. What's equally significant, however, is that circulation inside the UK was also rising - by more than 13,000 copies on May 1999. The redoubled effort piled into the home edition is paying dividends as well.

And, home or away, the curious dichotomy remains equally valid. Why, in an age of pell-mell internet expansion led by global financial dealings, should this explosion of pink print be so marked? Why, equally, should the Wall Street Journal dream of parking its tanks on the FT 's European lawn? If print is doomed, it must be doomed first in the community of constantly flickering business screens. But not at all. Just the reverse.

Trawl more widely for evidence and perversities continue. The latest analysis of World Press Trends shows daily sales up in 25 countries (out of the 46 surveyed). Sales losses in the EU area have slowed to 0.1 per cent. As China took to the net, newspaper sales there also went up, by 12.7 per cent in a year.

Even Britain, which we tend to dismiss as an unhappy story, doesn't really hop to the clap of doom. Broadsheet sales in May were pretty steady (and up 100,000 a day on May 1990). The decline is in red-top tabloid sales (down more than 300,000 year on year): but you can't attribute much of that to the net.

Associated's Metro freesheets - print scattered around Tube and bus stations - matter far more. Any conclusions, naturally enough, have to be tentative. Business papers boom in good times and shrink in recession. Internet penetration needs the benchmarks of critical mass. The impact on job advertising, of which the FT carries a good deal, is vital to newspaper economics.

Nevertheless: the certainties of the webmasters, which only a year or so ago seemed so irresistible, are (like their share prices) looking less certain now. The evidence doesn't fit, Lambert is keeping calm - and the future is still a blank sheet of paper.

Thousands of youngsters are being packed into overcrowded institutions as a result of overzealous implementation of new sentencing policies.

As a 13-year-old boy was sentenced in London last week to two years' detention for dealing in cocaine, prison reform groups expressed alarm that the increase in young people being sent to jail was undermining the work of the Youth Justice Board, formed in April specifically to tackle the issue of youth custody.

Campaign groups have warned Home Secretary Jack Straw that new detention and training orders for young offenders are being used inappropriately by magistrates. Under the new sentences, young criminals spend half their time in custody and the other half in the community in an attempt to ease their resettlement into society.

But campaigners say that the 'one-punishment-fits-all' approach means that people who would normally not have been sent to prison find themselves behind bars.

Among the worst victims of the new orders are mothers under the age of 18, who are being sent to prison and separated from their babies. Reform groups have expressed alarm that a legal loophole allows the babies of these young girls to be taken into care - a denial, they claim, of basic human rights.

The Howard League for Penal Reform is investigating several cases of girls under the age of 18 who have had their children taken from them, a practice that has long been outlawed for adult women prisoners. These are understood to include a number of Roma refugee girls, who are often given tougher sentences for minor offences such as shoplifting than their white British counterparts.

'New problems are arising which have never been an issue before,' said Frances Crook, director of the Howard League. 'It is quite appalling that girls are being placed in custody and having their babies taken away, something that would be quite unlawful for adults.'

Thousands of youngsters are being held in overcrowded conditions, sometimes hundreds of miles from their homes. Figures obtained by The Observer show that a total of 2,177 places are available at juvenile institutions while only 1,803 are occupied. Despite this, three young offender institutions - Northallerton in North Yorkshire, Glen Parva in Leicestershire and Portland in Dorset - are seriously overcrowded. Northallerton, with a design capacity of 152 prisoners, currently holds 246.

The Howard League is compiling a dossier on institutional abuse at Portland which will be presented to Prison Service director general Martin Narey later this year.

A recent Home Office report into the impact of custodial sentences on young people showed that even short sentences have a devastating effect by immersing them in criminal culture. This often encouraged lesser offenders to go on to commit more serious crimes.

One young woman told the researchers: 'You're just going to get back to the way it was before, aren't you? In here I can say, "Oh I'm not going to do this, I'm not going to do that." But when I get out I'm going to do it all again.'

fields.headline: All at sea
fields.standfirst: From Nigella Lawson's cod and chips to Nobu's new-style sashimi, the following 40 pages are full of food from the seas. We start, of course, with the catch. Here, Andrew Smith heads out into the treacherous waters of the North Atlantic in search of the fish that feeds the world
fields.trailText: From Nigella Lawson's cod and chips to Nobu's new-style sashimi, the following 40 pages are full of food from the seas. We start, of course, with the catch. Here, Andrew Smith heads out into the treacherous waters of the North Atlantic in search of the fish that feeds the world.
fields.body:
I'd watched a crew member yank a rope and the deck of the small Icelandic trawler suddenly explode with movement and colour. Now most of the fish had disappeared down a hatch into the bowels of the ship, leaving a dozen stragglers gasping behind.

I had to ask what some of them were. There was an ocean perch or 'redfish', bug-eyed and Day-Glo orange - too ugly for the skittish British, but beloved of Germans. There was a handsome, yard-long coley, shaded grey like a salmon, and a flat, spiky skate, hard-blinking its recessed eyes in a way which I found inexplicably moving. But my eye was drawn to one of the cod, a big one, four feet in length and perhaps the same in years. The other fish were lying still, but this one wasn't. It was struggling, flicking its powerful tail and refusing to give up. In repose, it was beautiful - dark at the spine, with a delicate silver thread running down its side amid dancing amber-green specks. I realised with amazement that I'd never seen a live one before, only steaks and fillets.

We recognise the cod as ubiquitous, yet few of us know just how entwined we are with it. In the Middle Ages, the revelation that its salted flesh would keep over time and distance shrank the world of our forbears as profoundly as the invention of the aeroplane, television and the internet have our own. It became a strategic resource and for three centuries the fortunes of Atlantic nations and the world they rampaged across and subjugated were shaped by it.

In fact, the longer you look at this ranging, roving determined survivor, the more you come to see it as one of nature's chosen species, a talisman to whom our future is linked as assuredly as our past. For scientists are now coming to see that, quite apart from being a valuable food source, the cod is one of the most sensitive barometers we have as to the health of the planet. It is entirely possible that if it goes, we go too. And for reasons we don't fully understand, it's going. Fast. On the morning I left for Iceland, the Today programme on Radio 4 reported that this year's British catch was shaping up to be 'the worst in living memory' and I can still hear announcer James Naughtie's voice in my head as the big cod on the deck, summoning one last effort, flips itself up towards a gap in the ship's outer rail, but falls agonisingly short of its target. It crashes back down, defeated and finally accepting of its fate, before sliding passively into the hold and destiny on a supermarket shelf. 'And scientists are saying that it's not going to get any better,' Naughtie had said. 'In fact, it may get worse.' That was one of the lucky ones, then.

In 1989, the United Nations estimated the combined cost of subsidising the world's fishing fleet at $92 billion. In the early 90s, the European Union was spending an annual $580 million. This can't go on. Iceland is said to be the only nation left on earth whose fishing industry is expected to make a significant contribution to the national economy. It guards its waters and fish stocks jealously, yet even here there are problems. As my plane touches down, a fierce row is erupting over a proposed reduction in quotas for next year, where an increase had been anticipated. This is not the only surprise that will be greeting me this week.

The Westman Islands jut monumentally out of the sea off the southern coast of Iceland. The Vikings named them after the Irishmen (the west men) who they enslaved and deposited there. Since then, they have been sacked by Turks and terrorised by the live volcano which last erupted in the 1970s. Living here has long been something of a balancing act.

The midsummer sun was shining benignly when I arrived at around midnight on a Sunday, but I was worried. The day before, I'd gone fly fishing on a bleak and windy Icelandic lake with some local fish merchants and a couple of English buyers who happened to be visiting at the same time. People here follow weather forecasts with an avidity that we don't at home and everyone knew that storms were predicted for the next couple of days. I kept being asked the same question - 'Have you been out before?' - to which I would mumble, 'Oh, you know, ferries and things...' and watch as the questioner's eyes ignited with amusement. Even the girl sitting next to me on the 25-minute flight did it. Sleep was elusive that night.

The sun was still shining early the next morning, but as I set about locating my boat in the remarkably pretty, cliff-framed harbour, the sky clouded over and a fine drizzle began. Anyone who's seen The Omen will remember something similar happening when one of the priests gets trapped in a park with Satan; and I fully expected to hear a thunderclap in the distance as I shook the hand of Helgi, my initially laconic captain. I braced myself for the inevitable question, which duly came in the course of the following exchange.

'Have you been out before?'

'Well, you know, sort of. Ferries. And things.'

'Then you will be sick, I think.'

Which was at least direct. It seemed to be getting colder and windier all the time. One of the Englishman I'd met on the lake, Keith Brown of the Grimsby-based Sealord company, later informed me that a fish-factory owner he was with glanced out to sea that day and confidently predicted that we would not be sailing in such conditions. Worse, my ship, the Danski Pétur , turned out to be one of the smallest in the harbour; 27 metres long, 150 tonnes, its decks crowded with nets, chains, booms and rusty, lethal-looking machinery. In the North Atlantic regions, fishermen have the highest fatality rate of any type of worker. A few years ago, one of the crew on this boat had his arm ripped off at the shoulder. I drop off my bags and repair to a safe café while the crew ready the boat.

I am reading a remarkable book called Cod: A Biography of the Fish that Changed the World, by an American writer named Mark Kurlansky. He tells the story of the letter a group of Bristol merchants wrote to Christopher Columbus, as he basked in his 'discovery' of America, reminding him that they'd already been there. And the Frenchman Jacques Cartier, who claimed Newfoundland for France, untroubled by the presence of 1,000 Basque fishing boats anchored there. Like the Bristolians, the Basques hadn't wanted to give away the whereabouts of the secret fishing grounds which had made them rich. Both the Bretons and the English had tried to follow them, but had failed. According to Kurlansky, Sir Walter Raleigh averred in 1595 that if the 50 Newfoundland cod-fishing ships based in Plymouth should ever be lost, 'It would be the greatest blow ever given to England.'

Cod also made possible the American Revolution, allowing the New England colon- ies to become prosperous and independent. Cod swim with their mouths wide open and will swallow anything that is put in front of them. Once hooked, they refuse to fight, merely trailing obediently to the surface. To the early fishermen, they must have seemed like gifts from the gods and only in the 1890s did this gift come to seem anything other than boundless, as the invention of the steam engine and trawling led to the near-depletion of North Sea stocks within a decade. The first British-built, steel-hulled trawlers arrived in Icelandic waters in 1905 and some experts contend that they, too, would have been laid waste but for the intervention of the First World War.

After the Second World War, on-board freezer technology and high-powered diesel engines capable of dragging huge nets along the sea floor meant that nowhere was safe. The resultant overfishing has been an issue in all areas of the North Atlantic ever since and the cause of two 'Cod Wars' between Britain and Iceland. As it turns out this may be the least of our problems.

The Danski Pétur is almost bizarrely cramped. The bridge is crowded with instruments, the steps to the tiny mess are steep and difficult to squeeze down, and the cabins confront you like dank, dark coffins. To get to my own bunk, I have to stumble through the area where tonnes of freshly caught fish are gutted and sent on a conveyor belt to the hold. Everything smells strongly of blood, sweat and diesel, including the quilt on my own tiny bunk at the front of the ship. I'm contemplating the fact that this will be my home for the next four or five days when a sudden lurch knocks me from my feet. Somewhere just above my head, there is a roar, swiftly followed by a crash and a deathly hiss, as ocean fizzes across the deck, simultaneously sweeping away any constructive use for my stomach over the next 24 hours.

I climb to the bridge as fast as my leaden, unsteady legs will take me. We've left the harbour and met a wall of churning, foamy white sea. The boat is shuddering and tilting laterally through at least 110 degrees, while the bow is flung into the air by a succession of irregular waves, then dropped into almost vertical dives. Surf ploughs almost to the base of the bridge: to step outside would be suicide. There is nowhere to escape to, no fresh air to breathe, nothing to do but try to contain my growing queasiness. It feels as though tennis-ball-sized bearings in my skull and abdomen are being manipulated from the outside by a powerful magnet.

At the helm, Helgi smiles ruefully, perhaps sensing my increasingly strained attempt to hide my discomfort. 'This is a difficult boat to work,' he says, 'too much roll.' It was built in 1971, but rebuilt in 1988, when a new deck and bigger bridge were added. As a consequence, it is top-heavy and vulnerable to even a modest swell. He wouldn't be worried unless the waves hit 15ft, though, which is about twice what they are right now. And the southwesterly winds will help us travel more quickly to our destination. For the first time it strikes me: for all our technological advancement, this is still what you have to do if you want to catch fish. Later, I will see this as something to celebrate, but such generosity of spirit escapes me at present.

I'm in a bind now. I'd bought a supply of seasickness pills in the harbour, but, not wanting to cheat on an experience whose full horror I then had no way of comprehending, I'd decided not to take them. Now I want to - badly! - but every time I take one, it comes straight back up. I go to my cabin with the aim of retreating into slumber while the ocean bombs the hull not feet from my head and I am being alternately pitched into the wall and the rail of my bunk. A couple of times, I wake from dreams of staring into a precipice to find myself rolling across an almost vertical mattress. Only afterwards do I appreciate just how bad the night is.

The worst thing is the affront to dignity, the feeling of being a helpless child again in the company of eight capable grown-ups: something no man likes to feel unless it's part of a service he's purchased with Luncheon Vouchers. And like a child, I am assuming that the way things are is the way they will remain.

They don't. Most of Tuesday is spent travelling, with the sea gradually easing and my guts beginning to function again. I'm in the mess with the crew, chatting and watching videos of Eddie Murphy films I've never heard of, when I become aware that the roll of the Pétur has subsided to a gentle sway. Helgi's voice comes over the Tannoy and the men smile at each other wearily. It's 11 in the evening, we've travelled 200 miles north to the sandbanks off the Western Fjords and we're going to drop the net.

The water is utterly still, shrouded in mist, dotted with gulls. With the help of a pair of strong hydraulic booms fore and aft, two netmen feed the long net down a recess at the back of the boat. Once it's out, the pair of computer-controlled 'trawl doors', which look like massive cast-iron shields, are dropped in order to maintain an optimum spread and angle of trawl. In the bridge, Helgi is examining a range of sonar equipment. He has detected a high degree of movement underneath us and thinks it might be cod pursuing krill. Now he will move slowly back and forth along the bank for two or three hours, monitoring the net closely; because at 36 fathoms, these are shallow, treacherous waters, haunted by dozens of jagged wrecks - £15,000 worth of net can easily snag, tear and be lost, even by a vigilant captain.

The contrast with what has gone before could scarcely be more profound. Today, we're gliding across a pool of shimmering black satin, watching silver-blue reflections of cloud and sky flicker playfully across its surface. As we near the edge of the banks, huge swells rise and fall like liquid Brecon valleys, tossing and softly catching the boat as it falls. Standing at the front, Leonardo DiCaprio-like, I understand the elderly Monet's predilection for painting water for the first time. I am also sorely tempted to echo DiCaprio's 'king of the world' cry from Titanic but think better of it. They might still carry planks on these things.

We'd dropped the nets twice before, but that was when we were further south and the weather was bad, so we hadn't caught much. This time, the sensors in Helgi's net tell him that we're getting lucky. He summons the crew, who smile and laugh as they reel in a net containing 8-10 tonnes of fish, most of it cod. The seemingly endless haul is emptied on to a section of deck in stages, then passed into the processing area down below. There, it will be gutted and packed into crates of ice. Often, these men come out and catch nothing, so this is a cause for celebration and everyone seems to relax.

The gutting must be done immediately, so while Helgi conducts another trawl, the men begin what is for them a laborious process. I've decided to pitch in and am surprised to find myself instantly possessed by the ghost of Charlie Chaplin. Johann the cook demonstrates how to cut into the fleshly bridge between the gills, then slit the belly, grab the innards and cleanly sever the tendon which holds them in place. I am tutored in removing the liver, placing it in one chute while flinging the guts down another, and introducing the carcass to a slow-moving conveyor belt.

He makes it look easy and graceful and I'm doing OK, I think, until Hilmar, the first mate, comes to work opposite me, at which point I go to pieces and my new crewmates find themselves dodging knives and flying fish remains in previously unimaginable quantities. This could explain why, every now and then, a splash of bloody, fishy water hits the back of my head as someone hurls a big beast into the tank that feeds the conveying machine.

The worst bit, though, is taking off the orange plastic mac worn during this process and having a little dribble of stinking gunk run down your neck. As so often in life, the splashes are easy to deal with, it's the trickles that mess you up. I decide that I know enough about gutting for the time being.

Fourteen hours of intense labour later, we have a hold containing 30 tonnes of fish. Helgi is quietly satisfied: it's been a good day, made better by the fact that an old mate who's skippering a nearby trawler twice the size of this one has only bagged six tonnes. Helgi used to run a boat like that and shows me a picture of the old one in a registry of Icelandic fishing boats; 'the one that got away' of fishing legend.

But like most fishermen, he and his crew work for a share of the catch, with the first 25 per cent deducted by the owner for costs and the crew taking 35 per cent of what remains, distributed in increments based on seniority.

The Danski Pétur is compact and powerful, with a small crew to share the profits: Helgi makes better money now than he did then. They also get to keep the livers, which are worth £25 per kilo and will pay for a group holiday (with wives) to Rio in October. These guys do all right.

Helgi's been at sea for 35 years, since he was 12. There are far fewer fish now, he tells me, and he must use all his accumulated wiles to catch them. The Westman Isles boats are gradually disappearing, at a rate of one or two every year. 'When I get to 50,' he tells me, 'I would like to give it up and find something else.' It's the gambler's oath. He has no idea of what he might do instead and would have trouble settling into the routine of most jobs after riding the unpredictable seas for so long. His son, Agust, is on the boat, and a son-in-law, Johann, makes an articulate, able chief engineer.

In other waters, such a man might dream of owning his own boat, but a boat is worth nothing without 'quota' - a licence to catch an agreed amount of fish per year - and this is expensive and mostly acquired through inheritance or politicking. In the words of Johann the engineer, 'If you want to impress a girl for a date, you don't show her your nice car, you tell her you've got a quota.' It's a kind of feudal system, where fishing families of many generations have no automatic right to fish.

The Icelandic quota system, which is similar to the one operated by the EU, was introduced as a crisis measure. Fishermen don't like it. The man from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) in the UK explains some of the problems in working any system that involves fishing, which boil down to the fact that there are many different types in many different areas and everyone wants the restrictions they all agree are necessary to apply somewhere else. These are the original not-in-my-backyarders and it is easy to find yourself listening to one tell you that there are still plenty of fish - the problem is the seismic soundings of oil companies, which scare the creatures away and disrupt their spawning habits.

Either way, the so-called 'box' around Ireland was closed completely for three months this spring and the Grand Banks off Newfoundland, once home to the richest cod stocks on earth, have just been reopened after a hiatus of four years. Scientists agree that overfishing has been a major factor in bringing this about. More chilling, though, is the report recently produced by MAFF researchers which claims that cod are failing to reproduce in the North Sea because water temperatures are rising. During the 90s, they say, average temperatures rose from 7.75 C to 8 C, which is in line with man-made global warming. If this theory is correct, the Atlantic cod is trying to tell us something and we don't seem to be listening.

I'll be honest with you: I was relieved to get back into port and dry land, though I was sorry to say goodbye to Helgi and his men, who would get an afternoon off, prior to heading out to sea again the next day. A week later, I still think of them every time I can't finish my tea because my stomach's shrunk or someone moves away from me on the Tube because I smell of cod intestine.

One of the remedies for overfishing favoured by Mark Kurlansky is to restrict numbers of days at sea rather than size of catch per vessel, which would favour small boats over behemoths with high overheads. This seems a good idea, but Porgrimur Leifsson, the owner of the sparkling fish factory where the Pétur 's cod will be processed for Waitrose, doesn't think it will happen. 'In a few years, there will be no more boats like the Danski Pétur ,' he tells me as he drives me away in search of a warm shower and the sanctuary of another life back on terra firma. I think there's a trace of regret in his voice, but it's probably just my imagination.

Somewhere just above my head, there is a roar, swiftly followed by a crash and a deathly hiss, as ocean fizzes across the deck, simultaneously sweeping away any constructive use for my stomach over the next 24 hours. I climb to the bridge as fast as my leaden, unsteady legs will take me. We've left the harbour and met a wall of churning, foamy white sea. The boat is shuddering and tilting laterally through at least 110 degrees, while the bow is flung into the air by a succession of irregular waves, then dropped into almost vertical dives. Surf ploughs almost to the base of the bridge: to step outside would be suicide. There is nowhere to escape to, no fresh air to breathe, nothing to do but try to contain my growing queasiness. It feels as though tennis-ball-sized bearings in my skull and abdomen are being manipulated from the outside by a powerful magnet. At the helm, Helgi smiles ruefully, perhaps sensing my increasingly strained attempt to hide my discomfort. 'This is a difficult boat to work,' he says, 'too much roll.' It was built in 1971, but rebuilt in 1988, when a new deck and bigger bridge were added. As a consequence, it is top-heavy and vulnerable to even a modest swell. He wouldn't be worried unless the waves hit 15ft, though, which is about twice what they are right now. And the southwesterly winds will help us travel more quickly to our destination. For the first time it strikes me: for all our technological advancement, this is still what you have to do if you want to catch fish. Later, I will see this as something to celebrate, but such generosity of spirit escapes me at present. I'm in a bind now. I'd bought a supply of seasickness pills in the harbour, but, not wanting to cheat on an experience whose full horror I then had no way of comprehending, I'd decided not to take them. Now I want to - badly! - but every time I take one, it comes straight back up. I go to my cabin with the aim of retreating into slumber while the ocean bombs the hull not feet from my head and I am being alternately pitched into the wall and the rail of my bunk. A couple of times, I wake from dreams of staring into a precipice to find myself rolling across an almost vertical mattress. Only afterwards do I appreciate just how bad the night is. The worst thing is the affront to dignity, the feeling of being a helpless child again in the company of eight capable grown-ups: something no man likes to feel unless it's part of a service he's purchased with Luncheon Vouchers. And like a child, I am assuming that the way things are is the way they will remain. They don't. Most of Tuesday is spent travelling, with the sea gradually easing and my guts beginning to function again. I'm in the mess with the crew, chatting and watching videos of Eddie Murphy films I've never heard of, when I become aware that the roll of the Pétur has subsided to a gentle sway. Helgi's voice comes over the Tannoy and the men smile at each other wearily. It's 11 in the evening, we've travelled 200 miles north to the sandbanks off the Western Fjords and we're going to drop the net. The water is utterly still, shrouded in mist, dotted with gulls. With the help of a pair of strong hydraulic booms fore and aft, two netmen feed the long net down a recess at the back of the boat. Once it's out, the pair of computer-controlled 'trawl doors', which look like massive cast-iron shields, are dropped in order to maintain an optimum spread and angle of trawl. In the bridge, Helgi is examining a range of sonar equipment. He has detected a high degree of movement underneath us and thinks it might be cod pursuing krill. Now he will move slowly back and forth along the bank for two or three hours, monitoring the net closely; because at 36 fathoms, these are shallow, treacherous waters, haunted by dozens of jagged wrecks - £15,000 worth of net can easily snag, tear and be lost, even by a vigilant captain. The contrast with what has gone before could scarcely be more profound. Today, we're gliding across a pool of shimmering black satin, watching silver-blue reflections of cloud and sky flicker playfully across its surface. As we near the edge of the banks, huge swells rise and fall like liquid Brecon valleys, tossing and softly catching the boat as it falls. Standing at the front, Leonardo DiCaprio-like, I understand the elderly Monet's predilection for painting water for the first time. I am also sorely tempted to echo DiCaprio's 'king of the world' cry from Titanic but think better of it. They might still carry planks on these things. We'd dropped the nets twice before, but that was when we were further south and the weather was bad, so we hadn't caught much. This time, the sensors in Helgi's net tell him that we're getting lucky. He summons the crew, who smile and laugh as they reel in a net containing 8-10 tonnes of fish, most of it cod. The seemingly endless haul is emptied on to a section of deck in stages, then passed into the processing area down below. There, it will be gutted and packed into crates of ice. Often, these men come out and catch nothing, so this is a cause for celebration and everyone seems to relax. The gutting must be done immediately, so while Helgi conducts another trawl, the men begin what is for them a laborious process. I've decided to pitch in and am surprised to find myself instantly possessed by the ghost of Charlie Chaplin. Johann the cook demonstrates how to cut into the fleshly bridge between the gills, then slit the belly, grab the innards and cleanly sever the tendon which holds them in place. I am tutored in removing the liver, placing it in one chute while flinging the guts down another, and introducing the carcass to a slow-moving conveyor belt. He makes it look easy and graceful and I'm doing OK, I think, until Hilmar, the first mate, comes to work opposite me, at which point I go to pieces and my new crewmates find themselves dodging knives and flying fish remains in previously unimaginable quantities. This could explain why, every now and then, a splash of bloody, fishy water hits the back of my head as someone hurls a big beast into the tank that feeds the conveying machine. The worst bit, though, is taking off the orange plastic mac worn during this process and having a little dribble of stinking gunk run down your neck. As so often in life, the splashes are easy to deal with, it's the trickles that mess you up. I decide that I know enough about gutting for the time being. Fourteen hours of intense labour later, we have a hold containing 30 tonnes of fish. Helgi is quietly satisfied: it's been a good day, made better by the fact that an old mate who's skippering a nearby trawler twice the size of this one has only bagged six tonnes. Helgi used to run a boat like that and shows me a picture of the old one in a registry of Icelandic fishing boats; 'the one that got away' of fishing legend. But like most fishermen, he and his crew work for a share of the catch, with the first 25 per cent deducted by the owner for costs and the crew taking 35 per cent of what remains, distributed in increments based on seniority. The Danski Pétur is compact and powerful, with a small crew to share the profits: Helgi makes better money now than he did then. They also get to keep the livers, which are worth £25 per kilo and will pay for a group holiday (with wives) to Rio in October. These guys do all right. Helgi's been at sea for 35 years, since he was 12. There are far fewer fish now, he tells me, and he must use all his accumulated wiles to catch them. The Westman Isles boats are gradually disappearing, at a rate of one or two every year. 'When I get to 50,' he tells me, 'I would like to give it up and find something else.' It's the gambler's oath. He has no idea of what he might do instead and would have trouble settling into the routine of most jobs after riding the unpredictable seas for so long. His son, Agust, is on the boat, and a son-in-law, Johann, makes an articulate, able chief engineer. In other waters, such a man might dream of owning his own boat, but a boat is worth nothing without 'quota' - a licence to catch an agreed amount of fish per year - and this is expensive and mostly acquired through inheritance or politicking. In the words of Johann the engineer, 'If you want to impress a girl for a date, you don't show her your nice car, you tell her you've got a quota.' It's a kind of feudal system, where fishing families of many generations have no automatic right to fish. The Icelandic quota system, which is similar to the one operated by the EU, was introduced as a crisis measure. Fishermen don't like it. The man from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (MAFF) in the UK explains some of the problems in working any system that involves fishing, which boil down to the fact that there are many different types in many different areas and everyone wants the restrictions they all agree are necessary to apply somewhere else. These are the original not-in-my-backyarders and it is easy to find yourself listening to one tell you that there are still plenty of fish - the problem is the seismic soundings of oil companies, which scare the creatures away and disrupt their spawning habits. Either way, the so-called 'box' around Ireland was closed completely for three months this spring and the Grand Banks off Newfoundland, once home to the richest cod stocks on earth, have just been reopened after a hiatus of four years. Scientists agree that overfishing has been a major factor in bringing this about. More chilling, though, is the report recently produced by MAFF researchers which claims that cod are failing to reproduce in the North Sea because water temperatures are rising. During the 90s, they say, average temperatures rose from 7.75 C to 8 C, which is in line with man-made global warming. If this theory is correct, the Atlantic cod is trying to tell us something and we don't seem to be listening. I'll be honest with you: I was relieved to get back into port and dry land, though I was sorry to say goodbye to Helgi and his men, who would get an afternoon off, prior to heading out to sea again the next day. A week later, I still think of them every time I can't finish my tea because my stomach's shrunk or someone moves away from me on the Tube because I smell of cod intestine. One of the remedies for overfishing favoured by Mark Kurlansky is to restrict numbers of days at sea rather than size of catch per vessel, which would favour small boats over behemoths with high overheads. This seems a good idea, but Porgrimur Leifsson, the owner of the sparkling fish factory where the Pétur 's cod will be processed for Waitrose, doesn't think it will happen. 'In a few years, there will be no more boats like the Danski Pétur ,' he tells me as he drives me away in search of a warm shower and the sanctuary of another life back on terra firma. I think there's a trace of regret in his voice, but it's probably just my imagination.

webTitle: Alan Smith: Early guidance the difference

fields.headline: Early guidance the difference between them and us
fields.standfirst: Insular England need to take coaching seriously
fields.trailText: Insular England need to take coaching seriously, says Crystal Palace boss Alan Smith
fields.body:
Anyone who has been reading this column over the past season will know that I was not surprised to see England fail at Euro 2000, and I suspect that was a feeling held by many others.

England are way behind other European countries in so many areas. It is an inescapable conclusion when you talk to foreign coaches and players that England do not produce players or coaches of the highest quality because we are too insular and place too little emphasis on proper coaching qualifications.

Whatever people may think of Kevin Keegan's ability as a manager, there is little dispute that he selected the best 22 players available, perhaps with one or two exceptions.

We are patently short of technically-gifted players for several reasons. Players do not produce themselves - they need help from coaches who are, after all, developers of talent. Yet we have never held coaching in the same high regard as it enjoys on the continent.

It was only when the FA set up their technical department under Howard Wilkinson and the subsequent introduction of the Youth Academies three years ago that we actually had a properly structured system to match those of Holland and France.

Those countries have had these systems in place for 20 years or so, have been reaping rewards for some time, and are now the two outstanding sides in Europe.

From the age of eight, young players are coached in a well-structured environment that places an emphasis on technique, intelligence and all-round ability. Full-sized pitches and 11-a-side games are banned until the age of 12, so that players can learn close control the way they used to do here 30 or 40 years ago, when kids could still play in the street or in playgrounds.

In this sense, perhaps, we have suffered from having improved facilities just as the Germans feel they are now too affluent as a nation to produce enough hungry young players.

When I was in Germany for a coaching seminar this year, there was great concern about the dearth of young talent.

I would suggest the picture is not so bleak for England, if only because we now have a system in place to encourage good technique. But I think the earliest we might see the benefits will be at the 2004 European Championship, or the World Cup two years later.

What we must learn to do, from schoolboy football right through to Premiership and international level, is to play the ball on the ground. Coaches from France, Italy, Holland, Spain, Yugoslavia, Portugal, Romania and Turkey would all agree that the only time the ball should be played in the air is from the goalkeeper's kicks and from crosses in the attacking third of the pitch. Yet in England we are still suffering the hangover from 20 years or so of the long-ball game advocated by the former FA coaching director Charles Hughes. Players still try to get the ball forward as quickly as possible, bypassing midfield and hitting speculative passes into space, which may win games but does nothing to improve technique or take us towards those magical buzzwords of all continental coaches: rotation and movement.

Admittedly we have not had a midfield player to compare with the likes of Zinedine Zidane or Rui Costa since Paul Gascoigne, but then we underestimate that area of the field.

I know of no clubs in England who have specialist coaching sessions with midfielders the way they do with goalkeepers, forwards or the defence. Yet it is common practice in Europe to work on midfield play at least twice a week.

The best European sides also initiate moves from the back but we do not have central defenders who are comfortable on the ball, with the exception of Gareth Southgate and Tony Adams, who is sadly coming to the end of his career.

Hopefully the changes of the past few years will start to kick in before too long, so we can produce more high quality coaches who help to develop better players. If we can continue to improve we may start to see that rotation and movement shown in the France and Holland match last week - a marvellous example of what it should all be about.

webTitle: We're not fit to play football

fields.headline: We're not fit to play football
fields.standfirst: It's not surprising we got knocked out of Euro 2000. We're too indolent, fat and we don't do PE
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson: It's not surprising we got knocked out of Euro 2000. We're too indolent, fat and we don't do PE.
fields.body:
I can't say, up till now, I've evinced much interest in sport but for various reasons of my own I've taken strange comfort in Euro 2000. The mindless distraction that football offers, I've found, has a lot to be said for it. And perhaps it is presumptuous even to have the thought, let alone express it, given my own resolute unathleticism, but I was amazed at our own messy incompetence on the field. An amateur eye cannot help but make the innocent comparison with other seemingly so much better prepared, more skilful teams.

There are always theories as to why England is just so bad at sport these days - and so many of these hinge on psychological readings. Surely it has something more to do with what I was writing about last week: namely our gross dwindling into flabby lethargy. Simply, we are not a fit nation. Yes, I know I've seen what David Beckham can do and even a relatively geriatric Shearer; clearly the England team itself isn't fat and unhealthy. But the odd genius isn't enough, and wouldn't be enough in any field. Strong teams, like strong armies, depend on a healthy and disciplined population. This maybe is our problem. The pool simply isn't big enough.

And in a week when the Government has been shining an anxious light on the problems of the adolescent thin - as Dea Birkett pointed out in the Guardian a couple of days ago - the lack of willingness to do anything about under-age fat seems even more striking. Go to any school playground these days and look at the pupils: our failure to come up with sufficient numbers of able-bodied athletes would hardly surprise.

Perhaps, like the issue of fat itself, this is a class issue. Easy enough for people to worry about the problems of the anorexic middle-class - and although I know anorexia isn't exclusively a middle-class phenomenon, it is still the case that it is more prevalent in relatively affluent, would-be high-achieving and sheltered families - while the problems of the underclass are all but ignored by those with power, with a voice. So not only do we make this a self-perpetuating difficulty, but there is an added poignancy here: for sport has always been the way that the underprivileged have got out of the ghetto. Now we're happy to lock them up in the prison of their own increasing girth.

But how do you help people whose poor diet reduces them to non-citizens? For it does seem, ironically, that the fatter people get, the more invisible they become. How patronising, how censorious it would be to start telling people what they could or could not feed their families. But clearly there is a problem, and as clearly we're doing nothing about it.

This isn't just about the educational system's inability to provide adequate physical exercise, though the Major government's sale of playing fields for easy profit can hardly have helped. And the overloading of the school syllabus so that there's hardly any room for play, for games, is a further contributing factor to this markedly physical malaise. Then there is the mess of the system itself: a child can no longer assume there will be a place for him or her at a nearby school, at walking distance from home.

But, to address the first and most salient point, if schools don't feel it is within their remit or capabilities to keep their pupils fit, the problem is going to get worse. And yes, we may mind that neither the England cricket or football teams can equip themselves ably on the field, but that should never be the chief concern. The increasing number of overweight and grossly unhealthy teenagers should be a matter of public outcry. In this context, all this hand-wringing over skinniness, for all that it genuinely appals, seems almost obscene.

Organised games are wrongly identified with perpetuating the spirit and mores of empire. Yes, there is some small element of truth in the assumption: PE was first built into the school curriculum at the turn of the last century by a Colonel Fox of the War Office because the huge numbers of deaths and casualties in the Boer War were felt, in part, to be due to a hugely unfit working class. And, it was feared, unless we did something to improve 'the health and discipline of the masses' we would never be able to raise a competent army. But keeping a population fit doesn't have to be equated with training people to be ammunition-fodder or for instilling in the masses the virtues of obedience and order.

Nor is it about body-fascism. International sporting events are always troubling, or I find them so; that mixture between nationalism and the cult of physical perfection has, as we know, vexing implications to say the least. But there must be a way in which we can encourage our young to be fit without adopting unwanted ideologies.

It's true I feel somewhat hypocritical extolling the benefits of PE; I, after all, did once have a games report which read: 'Nigella has no inclination to move whatsoever.' I would have been exultant to have been educated within a system that banished competitive games or at least marginalised them. But then, we shouldn't strive for an educational system for which pupils are grateful, but for one that equips them to live as fully and as fruitfully as possible.

For the one thing we learn as we get older is that education is not about what you do at school, but at what it enables you to cope with once you've left it long behind.
