webTitle: Why Harry Potter doesn't cast a spell over me

fields.headline: Why Harry Potter doesn't cast a spell over me
fields.standfirst:
JK Rowling's new blockbuster will be a monster hit worldwide. But just how good is the Harry Potter series?
Wise words or muddled muggledom? Have your say
fields.trailText: J.K. Rowling's new blockbuster will be a monster hit worldwide. But just how good is the Harry Potter series?
fields.body:
Stay home on Saturday week. The nation's high streets will be mobbed by parents and children stampeding to obtain not the latest faddish toy or computer game or movie spin-off merchandise, but a book. You know, one of those old-fashioned things, pre-audiobooks and e-novels, with lots of words printed on crisp white pages snugly bound between hard covers.

In any other circumstances, this would be cause for stunned rejoicing. The book is not dead, long live the book, etc. But, frankly, it depends on the book. If people were fighting to buy Seamus Heaney's sizzling translation of Beowulf, or David Cairns's riproaring biography of Berlioz, or even my own action-packed life of Shakespeare, I would naturally be uncorking champagne and running jaunty standards up the nation's literary flagpoles.

But it's not. Harry Potter and the Doom Spell Tournament is less a book than a phenomenon. A marketing phenomenon. Haven't Bloomsbury sold enough copies of J.K. Rowlings's three volumes so far without resorting to advance hype worthy of a Wonderbra? Have they no faith in their product's ability to sell on its merits?

Anticipation has been carefully heightened by shrouding the plot in secrecy, beyond the tantalising titbit that one of the characters dies. No review copies have been sent out. The author has given no interviews. After publication a private train will carry her around the country (a privilege once accorded that other noted author, Edward Heath) to sign copies. Come on, guys, why not just sell it as a book rather than hype it like a Spice Girls CD?

Maybe, in truth, because it isn't a very good one. I brave the wrath of millions by daring to say so, but it really doesn't take a high-minded killjoy to worry what these books are doing to the literary taste of millions of potential young readers. Bloomsbury's stock value has trebled since Potter joined its list. As its marketing men think up catchy new sales ploys for the remaining three volumes, they hide behind such worthy, apparently unassailable slogans as 'Anything that gets children reading has to be A Good Thing'.

Call me a super-Muggle, but I beg to differ. As a workout for the brain, reading (or being read) Harry Potter is an activity marginally less testing than watching Neighbour s. And that, at least, is vaguely about real life. These are one-dimensional children's books, Disney cartoons written in words, no more.

It is an interesting paradox that the more popular (or bestselling) an adult book, viz a Barbara Cartland or Jeffrey Archer, the less likely it is to be considered literature, while the popularity of a children's book sees big literary claims being made on its behalf. In the case of Harry Potter the mere suggestion is plain embarrassing.

I would be highly unlikely to have read any of J.K. Rowling's series for children had I not been required (and paid) to read the third instalment, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban , as a judge of this year's Whitbread book awards. I duly found myself amazed.

Eager to see what all the fuss was about, I had looked forward to enjoying a magical ride through some thrillingly original fantasy world, on a par with such children's classics as Alice in Wonderland, Treasure Island or Peter Pan, which gently question the values of the adult world from a child's point of view. Instead I found myself struggling to finish a tedious, clunkily written version of Billy Bunter on broomsticks.

Several of the Whitbread judges agreed with me. Compared with Jacqueline Wilson's The Illustrated Mum , a slice of real contemporary life which credits its young readers with some interest in the complex world around them, the Potter saga was essentially patronising, very conservative, highly derivative, dispiritingly nostalgic for a bygone Britain which only ever existed at Greyfriars and St Trinian's. And we were, after all, judging an award for writing, not for marketing.

As others leaked my own remarks in the supposed secrecy of the Whitbread judging room, I have few qualms in revealing that Wilson deservedly looked like beating Rowling to the children's book award - thus becoming eligible for Book of the Year - until the majority voting system was suddenly changed in mid-meeting. As most judges' second choice, Potter squeaked home, thus entering the final round for the £20,000 overall prize

Whitbread's global rules had also been altered in advance this year, to make the victorious children's book eligible for Book of the Year alongside the winning works of fiction, biography and poetry. All our antennae were thus alerted to another potential marketing coup for Harry Potter. But it wasn't that which moved me to a protest that made unlikely headlines the next day. It was astonishment that anyone could even begin to hold Rowling's work in the same regard as Heaney's or Cairns's. I was not prepared to lend my name to such faux-naif folly, and said so. All populist hell broke loose.

At my most embattled (but before I was called a 'pompous prat' on television), I was alarmed to hear two of the celebrity judges, Jerry Hall and Imogen Stubbs, testifying how much their chil dren enjoyed being read Potter. Were their children, I snorted, to be allowed to choose the Book of the Year? 'You should be reading them Beowulf,' I snapped testily. 'It's much the same sort of stuff, heroes taking on dragons and all that, but the language is far more exciting.' To their credit, Hall and Stubbs politely agreed with me, promised to read their children Heaney, and wound up helping him carry the day. Just.

By that weekend the nation seemed to be suffering a collective nervous breakdown, as the Sunday papers debated whether we are a Beowulf Britain or a Harry Potter Britain. We are, of course, neither. We are a country with dramatically declining standards of literacy, increasingly dragged down to the lowest common denominator by the purveyors of all forms of mindless mass entertainment. The success of the Potter books is just another dispiriting proof of the Murdoch-led dumbing down of all our lives, or what Hensher called 'the infantilisation of adult culture'.

Having gritted my teeth and struggled through the first two before passing sentence, I remain dumbstruck at their huge popularity. The first three books have sold 21 million copies in the US and a further seven million in Britain and the English speaking-world.

Good luck, say I, to Joanne Rowling, who with the help of the marketing men has made a fortune already estimated at £15 million, expected to double once Steven Spielberg makes the movies. I warm to the modest way in which she appears to have handled her huge success, sensibly keeping as low a public profile as possible.

She has also, apparently, been persuaded to endure the indignity of hiding behind her initials to spare young male readers the embarrassment of enjoying a book by a woman. And it is not, I suspect, her fault that the Potter mythology misrepresents a middle-class, university-educated writer who chose to leave her Portuguese husband as an abandoned working-class mother toiling away in a Scottish garret.

What I do object to is a pedestrian, ungrammatical prose style which has left me with a headache and a sense of a wasted opportunity. If Rowling is blessed with this magic gift of tapping into young minds, I can only wish she had made better use of it. Her characters, unlike life's, are all black-and-white . Her story-lines are predictable, the suspense minimal, the sentimentality cloying every page. (Did Harry, like so many child-heroes before him, HAVE to be yet another poignant orphan?)

Even more depressing is the feeble cop-out of this resourceful single parent mum, on welfare while writing the first book, in sending her oh so generic, Molesworthian hero to a good old private English boarding school. Why on earth couldn't Hogwarts (the name is indicative of the reach of her imagination) have been a comprehensive, or an embattled secondary modern or a solid old-fashioned grammar - a school of the kind with which most of those millions of young readers can identify?

Why, in the weariest tradition of English children's literature from Tom Brown's Schooldays on, did she have to send Harry to a neo-Dotheboys Hall, complete with such arcane rituals as weirdly named hierarchies and home grown sports with incomprehensible rules? Much of the Potter saga could have been written in the Fifties, as Suzanne Moore has pointed out: 'What child do you know these days who eats rock cakes and talks about galoshes? No wonder they love it in the States.' Ye olde fairy-tale England, with real Tudor beams and a Queen who rides around in a horse-drawn golden coach: that is not just how the rest of the world still sees us, it is how Potterites would have us see ourselves.

These are some of the reasons why I said, during and after the Whitbread judging, that a victory for Harry Potter 'would have sent out a signal to the world, like the monarchy and the Dome, that Britain is a country that refuses to grow up and take itself seriously'. I did not, as reported, further argue that children's books cannot be great literature. Of course they can, if they are well-written, stretch the reader's imagination and open virgin minds to the magical powers of words.

For all the long shadows of its various villains, the world of Harry Potter is essentially a familiar and thus safe one for young readers to roam in. Their thrill at the smell of danger is carefully controlled by the certainty that virtue will prevail - no Roald Dahl-type risks for Rowling - and their minds unstretched by any reflective pauses in the breathless narrative, any encouragement to assess the rights and wrongs of what is going on.

Not that Potter's world offers much scope to moral philosophers. Harry's dead parents were uncomplicatedly good. His wicked uncle and aunt are unequivocally bad, like the super-villain Lord Voldemort. Given their unadorned prose style, these books wind up reading themselves. They are not teaching children the joys of literature any more than they are challenging them to question the supposed certainties of their daily lives.

Children's literature is what it is: the invention of a captivating alternative world in which, at its best, home truths about adult behaviour are glimpsed through the eyes of innocence. Harry Potter offers no such transcendent adventure. He is a children's hero for our culturally impoverished times, rating escapism above enlightenment.

I wish I could hope that Rowling's new volume will prove me wrong, that she has taken her audience captive only to lift them, at the midpoint of her saga, from the banal realms in which they are rooted to a wonderworld where their souls can soar. On the evidence so far, that seems highly unlikely. As Harry approaches puberty - the series is scheduled to cover seven teenage years - he will no doubt turn into a spotty little wizard who eventually gets the girl.

As for the 150,000 adults who paid extra to buy the same books in grown-up dustjackets, to avoid embarrassment when reading them in public (or perhaps even at home), well, get a life. I commend unto you the words of George Walden: 'The Harry Potter books are what they are: tales for children. Unlike Alice in Wonderland , or Just William , or The Simpsons , which can be enjoyed by all ages because they are so finely written and work on so many levels, the Harry Potter books work on just one.'

Volume One begins with the sentence: 'Mr and Mrs Dursley of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much.' Any adult who is not stopped in their tracks by that cutesy 'thank you very much', is presumably a Beano subscriber clutching a comfort blanket. Getting in touch with your inner child is all very well, but reluctance to put away childish things is, as another bestseller long ago suggested, rather more worrisome. One can only pray that, having grown up with Harry Potter, his millions of young fans don't spend the rest of their lives stuck in a scary timewarp. There is, as a grown-up writer once put it, a world elsewhere.

webTitle: Telescope plan may eclipse UK observatories

fields.headline: Telescope plan may eclipse UK observatories
fields.trailText: Britain could be forced to close several of its key astronomical centres to help fund the country's involvement in an ambitious billion-pound project to build a set of massive telescopes in Chile.
fields.body:
Britain could be forced to close several of its key astronomical centres to help fund the country's involvement in an ambitious billion-pound project to build a set of massive telescopes in Chile.

Scientists say the new devices - a giant telescope half the size of the Eiffel Tower, and an array of 64 giant radio detectors - would be the most expensive astronomical instruments ever built and would be used to view the birth of planetary systems, search for other worlds and peer back in time to study the universe shortly after its Big Bang birth.

However at a heated meeting of the Royal Astronomical Society in London last week, researchers were also warned that funding for these telescopes is likely to be provided by the Government at the expense of existing observatories. Threatened projects include Britain's suite of telescopes on La Palma in the Canaries; the Anglo-Australian Telescope in New South Wales; and the radio telescope project, Merlin, which is based at Jodrell Bank, near Manchester.

Dr Ian Corbett, director of science for the Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council (PPARC) said: 'We are going to have to look hard at the continued funding of all these projects.'

The heart of the issue, which threatens to split the UK astronomy community, lies with recent breakthroughs in optics, electronics and engineering. These have allowed scientists to build bigger telescopes capable of peering further into the cosmos. At the same time, costs have spiralled and now Britain can no longer afford to go it alone astronomically.

The only solution, say the majority of astronomers, is for the UK to join the European Southern Observatory - at a £65 million joining fee, plus an annual membership of £12m.

This cash will give Britain access to the consortium's telescopes, including its proposed next generation observatories: Alma (the Atacama Large Millimetre Array) whose 64 radio dishes will have a combined collecting surface of Wembley Stadium's pitch, and Owl (the OverWhelmingly Large telescope). Both will be built in Chile, whose high, dry mountains provide perfect viewing conditions for astronomers.

The Owl telescope, which is still being designed, would have a light-collecting mirror almost 100 metres in diameter. Britain's largest telescope is only just over four metres. 'We are talking about an absolutely stunning leap in scale,' said Dr Adrian Russell, director of the Royal Observatory, Edinburgh.

'The point is that Owl would be useless without the development of adaptive optics,' he added. 'The turbulence of our atmosphere would ruin the images it collected if we had not recently learned how to remove these wobbles and smudges.'

Using Owl, astronomers would gather light from the universe's faintest, remotest objects and transform their knowledge of the heavens. However Britain's Office of Science and Technology, which is reviewing UK science funding, has made it clear that there is a limit to its generosity. Some cutbacks will have to be made to fund the new instruments, threatening existing observatories such as the Anglo-Australian Telescope (AAT).

'The AAT is old and small, but size isn't everything,' said one of its users, Professor John Peacock of the Royal Observatory, Edinburgh. 'A telescope needs good detectors attached to them, and the AAT has the best in the world. It's still a great telescope.'

Professor Phil Charles of Southampton University agreed. 'Huge telescopes are great, but you also need smaller instruments, observatories that can pinpoint likely candidates for closer investigation and which can carry out celestial surveys.'

Nevertheless, Astronomer Royal Sir Martin Rees insisted Britain had to join up for Alma and Owl. 'If we don't, we will fall behind the rest of Europe in a fast-moving science at which we were once world leaders. If we do join, we will be back at the top. It's as simple as that.'

fields.headline: Perfect partners
fields.standfirst: Why red wine with fish can be a marriage made in heaven
fields.trailText: Why red wine with fish can be a marriage made in heaven.
fields.body:
'You see, ze vine verks with both dishes, ze wenison and ze monkfish. Believe me, Mr Atkin, only Riesling can do zis.' I enjoyed my lunch with Erwein Graf Matuschka von Greiffenclau. As well as running Schloss Vollrads, an estate in Germany's Rheingau region, his great passion was food-and-wine matching. For him, Riesling was the most adaptable grape of all.

A few years later, Herr Matuschka shot himself, which proves you should never take these things too seriously. I think of him every time someone tries to tell me what I should and shouldn't drink with food. My feeling is that modern wines go with most dishes.

Where does this leave the fish eater? In better shape than ever, I'd argue. When I started writing about wine 15 years ago, ordering red wine with fish was a no-no, like asking for ketchup in a three-star restaurant. It was white wine or nothing, and usually French white wine at that.

These days we're a lot more relaxed about what we eat and drink. Most of us grab whatever we've got in the fridge or wine rack and slap it, Jamie Oliver style, on the table. Australian Chardonnay with a rack of lamb? Argentine Bonarda with sea bass? No problem, squire. Wine, like food, has been liberated in the last decade, set free from a world of snobbery and pointless prescriptions. If we've lost a little subtlety along the way, it's been a price worth paying.

Knowing my own laissez-faire approach to the subject, I was amused to read Pat Simon's recently published and generally rather sensible Wine Tasters' Logic (Faber & Faber, £9.99). In a short passage on food-and-wine pairings, he lists four sole dishes from the Loire Valley and suggests a different white wine to go with each. These range from a Muscadet to a wine made from Chenin blanc grapes 'grown on oolithic limestone subsoil'. Got that?

Let's simplify things here. Serving wine with fish requires a little, but not too much, thought. Here are some tips:

 Serve light wines with delicate fish such as sole, plaice or trout. Muscadet and Mosel Rieslings are ideal. Don't be frightened of a little sweetness in the latter.

 If the sauce is creamy, choose a grape with pronounced acidity, such as Riesling, Sauvignon blanc, Albariño or Melon de Bourgogne, the Muscadet variety.

 Serve lighter reds or richer whites (Chardonnay, Alsace Pinot Gris, Viognier, Semillon) with meatier fish such as sea bass, turbot or halibut.

 Don't be frightened of red wines, especially if your dish comes with a red-wine sauce. Salmon steaks are very good with red Burgundy. In general, avoid tannic reds, but try Pinot noir, Gamay, Cabernet franc and Rioja. Make sure you chill fruity young reds.

 If you're having herring for dinner, stick to vodka.

 And finally, raise a glass to Herr Matuschka, a man who cared (possibly too much) about what we eat and drink.

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.standfirst: Five wines to drink with fish  by Tim Atkin
fields.trailText: Five wines to drink with fish.
fields.body:
1999 Muscadet sur Lie, Domaine Haut Noëlle (£3.92, Asda). Fresh, zesty, well-made Melon de Bourgogne from Philippe Chon, showing the slight spritz of a good Muscadet sur Lie and a bready, zesty undertone. The sort of wine that comes alive with food. Drink well chilled.

1997 Conde de Valdemar Rioja Crianza (£6.49, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up and selected branches of Thresher and Victoria Wine). A controversial choice, I admit, but Rioja is soft enough to partner fish dishes as long as it's not too oaky. Flavours of bramble and wild strawberry are underpinned by crisp acidity and a touch of vanilla.

1996 Bernkasteler Badstube Riesling Kabinett, von Kesselstatt (£6.99, larger Co-op stores). One of a number of excellent German Rieslings at the Co-op, this is a stylish, intense, almost exotic Mosel Riesling with notes of apple and white peach. The sweetness, refreshing acidity and delicate alcohol are beautifully balanced.

1999 Penfolds Eden Valley Reserve Riesling (£9.99, selected branches of Safeway). Fuller bodied than the Mosel Riesling, but this cool-climate Eden Valley white from the ever-reliable Penfolds is still delicate by Australian standards. It is zesty and concentrated on the palate, with intense lemon-and-lime fruit and super length.

1999 Tesco Beaujolais Villages, Louis Josse (£4.99, Tesco). Another wine that should be shoved in the fridge. This is Gamay at its softest, fruitiest best. A supple, easy-drinking wine with very little tannin and notes of raspberry and banana. Good as an aperitif, too.

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's lobster recipes
fields.standfirst: You've chosen your lobster, but before you can cook it there's the troublesome task of having to play executioner
fields.trailText: You've chosen your lobster, but before you can cook it there's the troublesome task of having to play executioner.
fields.body:
The nearest I get to killing anything is pouring salt on the slugs that regularly turn my garden into the final scene from Peter Greenaway's A Zed and Two Noughts. Even then I use the best Maldon. Cooking mussels doesn't count, as it seems such a blissful way to go: you are piled into a pot with your mates, all pissed on Chardonnay and scattered with herbs. Within seconds of closing the lid someone turns up the fire and you're gone. I can kill mussels without flinching - when I lift the lid and that heady steam billows up, all the shells are gaping at me, as if they died laughing.

The rest of the killing I leave to the professionals. Like most consumers, I am happy to tuck into fish or meat, but I want no blood on my hands, thank you. Many will argue that I do, and of course they have a point; but if I am a crab that has to die, I would rather go at the hands of someone who knows what they are doing than someone who dangles me over the boiling brine then wimps out.

Last week, I ate lobster at a friend's house. It was the finest lobster I have ever eaten, tasting smack-bang of the sea, its flesh as tender as a Chiver's jelly. Of course, we were a scallop's throw from the sea, in Suffolk. I should disclose here that I have never been a lobster fan, filing it 'under-overrated' - along with white asparagus and fillet steak. Once the snow-white flesh has been drowned in the usual brandy and cream glop so beloved of classic French cooking, then you might as well eat be eating school rubbers. But this was the lobster that made me re-open the file.

My host had chosen a different route. She served them naked, hot from the pot, with thin, home-made chips and buckets of wobbling mayonnaise. Explicit instructions were extracted from the cook in that casual, disinterested way in which a professional hacker might get you to divulge your password. I was ready for the kill.

So I am standing in the Saturday-morning queue at the fishmongers and waiting till I get to the window that runs the length of the ice-strewn counter. There is no sign of my prey. Scallops shiver in their shells, oysters are firmly closed and obviously in a grump, mussels tight-lipped at the inevitable. Then I spot him - or is it a her? - in a polystyrene box under the counter. Some say hens are more tender, others disagree. There are five of them, their claws bound with rusty-pink rubber bands. They are struggling to move.

Slowly, as if to reassure their prospective murderers of their freshness, they close the occasional eye or wave a tentacle. They are more exquisitely marked than I had ever really noticed before. A deep blue-black with paler edges, they have cute freckles and rust-coloured bristles. The queue moves slowly along like a chain gang. You get the feeling the lobsters are talking about us, wondering who is going to do the dirty deed. My method is chosen already: I shall put them briefly in the freezer and send them to sleep, and only then will I plunge them into boiling water. The counsel of perfection is that this method may just take the edge of the flavour, but at least I do get to feel better about it.

The woman eighth in front of me points into the box. It suddenly dawns that I should have come earlier; apparently I am not the only one with murder in mind. A lad in a rubber apron picks up her choice, turns him over for her inspection, shrouds him in white paper and pops him in bag. She doesn't look like the sort of person who would be party to the inevitable slaughter that will go on later in her kitchen. But then neither did Rose West.

I am level with the box now, my nose up against the window. I pick my quarry. He is far from the biggest - apparently they can be tough. His legs are intact (crippled lobsters come cheaper). Not an obvious beauty, he seems like the one least likely to be chosen. It occurs to me that this is exactly the way I chose my cat.

I start to feel slightly light-headed and focus on an elderly man ahead who chooses a kipper with more thought than most of us would choose a tie. I look back. I am past the box now and level with some monkfish that have had their heads removed. Monkfish are the only fish with a face. That's why fishmongers decapitate them first - they can smile at you.

Perhaps my lobster should have a name before being boiled and served up with a tomato salad. I start to think of something suitable for such a creature, with its cold eyes and unsmiling lips. I suddenly realise that my supper looks like Ann Widdecombe.

There is only one person in front of me now and they are taking forever. A Dover sole, two sea bass and a shipping order (no pun intended) for tuna steaks for a barbecue. I am once again level with the lobsters' prison but, this time, there is no glass between us. Lenny the lobster has turned round to face me. My dinner is looking at me. He struggles once more to free himself from those rubber bands and I think not of his end in boiling water, but of his journey home, cocooned in plastic, unsure of his place of execution.

But he will be able to watch me make the mayonnaise that will accompany him, and halve the lemon. He will see the water going into the pot, and the salt that will make a home from home. 'Being served, mate?' says a guy with a number-one haircut. 'Errm, no. Uhm, can I have a errr, a ummm...' One last glance and I see my prey has turned his back on me. I swallow. 'Err, a lobster please. Yes, just one. One of the ready-cooked ones.'

Lemon and herb mayonnaise for lobster

2 large, free-range egg yolks

100ml groundnut oil

200ml mild, not too fruity, extra-virgin olive oil

the juice of a large lemon

a small bunch of tarragon

100ml double cream

Put the egg yolks into a large bowl. Sprinkle a pinch of salt over them and stir briefly with a whisk. Add a drop of groundnut oil, no more than half a teaspoon, and whisk it in. Add another and whisk that in, then a few more drops, whisking constantly. Now start to let it run in a trickle, but don't stop whisking. It is good to have help doing this so that one of you can whisk while the other pours. Once you have finished the groundnut oil, start adding the extra-virgin.

At this point you should be able to feel the whisk becoming heavier, a sign that the mayonnaise is thickening. By the time you have almost finished, it should be thick enough to wobble. Once the oil is finished, give it one more really good beating. We will let the mayonnaise down later so it is lighter.

Squeeze the lemons and fold the juice, drop by drop, into the mayonnaise.You will see it lighten in colour as the juice goes in. Now mix in the cream. The mayonnaise will thin a little, but you must stop if it is getting too thin - you want it to be smooth enough to spoon rather than pour over the lobster.

Chop the herbs finely, though not so fine that they look like tea leaves. Fold them into the mayonnaise. Add salt or black pepper if it needs it.

Buttered lobster

I am not sure there is a better way to serve lobster than plainly boiled with lots of melted butter. The problem is that even a lobster straight from the pan will not always melt the butter you put in it, so you should use softened butter, and a little lemon juice. The method below is also extremely useful for making the most of a creature bought freshly cooked. In other words, lobster for wimps.

1 live lobster per person

a generous 50g butter per person

lemons, quartered

Kill the lobster in which ever way you think fit. If, like me, you are unhappy about dispatching it yourself, buy it from a fishmonger you know and trust to sell you one boiled just hours - rather than days - before. Cut the lobster in half lengthways and remove the meat from the body and from inside the claws, saving every bit of juice you can. Keep the two halves of shell. Try to keep the flesh in chunks.

Warm the butter in a shallow pan over a high heat until it starts to froth, then add the lobster meat. Do this quickly, tossing the meat over in the butter till it is hot, then pile it back into the shells. Let the butter in the pan sizzle for a minute or two longer, then pour in any juices you managed to save when you split the lobster. Drizzle it and any odd bits left in the pan over the lobster.

Serve immediately, while the butter is still foaming. Squeeze lemon over as you eat.

Killing your lobster

Those who wish to kill their own lobster, and are obviously braver than I, have a choice of methods. If you have a very large pot, drop your lobsters, one at a time, into boiling water. Fans of this method insist the lobster dies quickly (how would they know?)

Others suggest putting the lobster into cold water and slowly bringing it to the boil. The idea is that he nods off. This sounds like a lingering death. Others still swear by putting theirs into the freezer for an hour where he will apparently go to sleep, but the flesh will not quite freeze. He can then be cooked without suffering any pain.

The RSPCA apparently prefers the knife method, which involves splitting the lobster in half while it is alive. This may well be true, but it is completely beyond this cook. The choice is yours.

fields.headline: Casting a spell
fields.standfirst: Fresh fish and a bill that won't leave you high and dry, Jay Rayner gets caught in Brighton
fields.trailText: Fresh fish and a bill that won't leave you high and dry, Jay Rayner gets caught in Brighton.
fields.body:
Until relatively recently the reputation of fish in Britain suffered because of the company it kept. We assumed that most was fit only for the deep-fat fryer and that because so much of what we ate came out of chip shops, it deserved about as much respect as the people in hairnets cooking the stuff. Things are better now: no new big-ticket restaurant launches without three interesting and wallet-numbingly expensive ways with sea bass or John Dory on its menu.

In London, the Fish! chain has brought a breezy liberalism to fish cookery. Punters get to choose the type of creature they wish to eat, the method of cooking and the sauce to accompany it. Even more encouragingly, the company behind the Green Street Seafood Café in Bath is currently raising investment to launch four combined fish markets and restaurants on sites across the country.

But this is the hip end of the fish business. There is still a resistance to, or snobbery about, anything that smacks of the old way with fish. Which brings us to the Regency Restaurant, on a run-down stretch of the Brighton seafront by Regency Square, which looks like it might be sizing you up with a view to emptying your pockets while you're not looking. The polite thing to say is that the Regency has an air of faded grandeur, but that is to suggest it had any grandeur in the first place and, to be honest, I doubt it did.

At the turn of the century it was a jeweller's, and the window frames possess a pleasing Art Nouveau curve and tuck. But the paintwork is peeling now and in need of a serious brush-up. It became a restaurant at some point in the 30s, has been called the Regency since 1967 and came under the control of the present management 15 years ago. Outside, sandwich boards advertising dishes of the day clutter the pavement, each an attempt to win passing trade from the grasp of their competitor next door, The Melrose, which has also filled the pavement with sandwich boards. The impression is, frankly, a little ragged. When I told friends in Brighton I was going to the Regency for lunch, they raised an eyebrow and said, 'Really? Is it any good?'

And the answer is yes - for what it is, it's great. If you want fish, simply but expertly cooked at a price that won't make you feel like you also bought the fishing boat that landed the ingredients, there's not much to beat it. On a bright Saturday we settled down for a family lunch, Eddie in his highchair and Pat at his side, the better to satisfy our son's increasingly sophisticated palate with bits of our lunch.

I started with grilled sardines, which were perfectly cooked, the skin crisp, the flesh succulent without being dry and coming away from the bones without a single one attached. A Portuguese fisherman would have sucked his teeth in admiration at sardines so admirably dispatched. For the record, Eddie thought they were grand, too. And, at £3.95, so was the bill. Pat's calamari was less spectacular but, at £2.50 for a good plateful, more than serviceable.

For her main course Pat had the lemon sole, generally regarded as the poor relation to the Dover variety. Given that the government has now declared war on elitism, perhaps it is time that we, too, kicked this kind of food snobbery into touch; this was a fine specimen of a sole, simply grilled, which is all you can ask for, and rather a steal at £7.50. It came with big fat chips, and so it should.

My vast crab, like 95 per cent of the fish served here, was caught locally and cost just £8.50. It was sweet, soft and fibrous, and tasted of the sea that was spread out unto the horizon before us. My only gripe is that the mayonnaise tasted more like salad cream. Though our starters took a little while to arrive, the service is generally brisk and cheerfully. Occasionally, the waiters break off from the tiresome business of clearing dishes to hustle passers-by on to empty tables, but that merely serves as a floor show.

There's a sensibly chosen multilingual wine list - a little French, a little Italian, a little New World - most of the bottles on it are priced at just shy of a tenner. Puddings, all at £2.25, are of the depth-charge variety: cheesecake, apple pie, and spotted dick and custard. After all that fishy lightness we agreed that pudding was superfluous to our requirements. Still, it's good to know that somewhere out there is a restaurant that will serve you spotted dick, so that adolescent boys may snigger. All this and a seaview, too.

 The Regency Restaurant, 131 King's Road, Brighton (01273 325 014). Lunch for two including wine and service costs £40. Jay Rayner can be contacted at jay.rayner@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Midsummer dreams
fields.standfirst: From the early-morning smell of new roses to the magic of long, slow dusks, summer's solstice is the peak of the year
fields.trailText: From the early-morning smell of new roses to the magic of long, slow dusks, summer's solstice is the peak of the year.
fields.body:
While the vegetable garden on our heavy, slow-warm soil is still emergent (although the broad beans are picking well and the artichokes have finally hit some sort of stride), the herb garden is certainly at its best, the whole area as fresh as herbs on a white plate. I think that the flowers of ordinary sage are, in their prime, worth their space in any border and the leaves of lovage and fennel are fabulous. But it only really looks good from early May to July, so to have an area solely devoted to herbs is not just a luxury on space but on time as well. We dress its shortcomings in spring with tulips and forget-me-nots, but it is harder to distract from its tiredness after mid-July. I have a tray of Nicotiana sylvestris left and perhaps they will go in there and act as a foil. Certainly there is something herbal, even medicinal, about the resiny scent of tobacco plants at dusk.

We have finished off the paths in the garden, three of which stopped short of their destination since we altered and extended the layout of the Jewel garden. This involved the delivery of a lorry-load of scalpings and a lorry-load of 'redgra' - a powdery, sandy gravel that binds when compacted and wet. Once formed, it makes a hard surface not unlike beaten earth, but it needs very good drainage beneath it if it is not to become a sticky mud in very wet weather. In an ideal world, I would have all the paths grass, because nothing looks better at this time of year. But our soil and climate mean this is utterly impractical, so we are slowly making all our working paths hard, with redgra and brick. In summer it seems an act of vandalism, but I know that come October I will regret not being more radical and doing more while the weather - and ground - is reasonably dry.

Our 64 box balls need cutting, but I have been too busy and too weary - the remnants of a flu bug nipping at my heels. I want them to grow as large as possible and always agonise between cutting them to maintain a good compact form and leaving as much on as possible.

I wonder if it is worth growing strawberries at all. I love a strawberry eaten warm from the garden, but the slugs take half of our crop and I have yet to find a proper deterrent for them. It might make more sense to surrender and to grow a slug-proof crop on the same ground. But is this common sense or defeatism?

The opening of the script for Channel 4's Real Gardens was written along the following lines: 'Welcome to Real Gardens - Monty, this is your chance to say something personal about the season or something you love.' I had all of 10 or 15 seconds to fill. Something personal about midsummer...

Here goes. In 10 seconds I shall say how there is this rolling midsummer fever in my veins, made of light falling through the leaves, made of the smell of the first roses and honeysuckle and musky tobacco plants in the dusk, made of the richness of this earth that astonishes me more every year, made of the thinnest of skies at five in the morning drawn up like a wispy tent by half a dozen larks, made of the patient husbanding of the vegetable garden, bringing food to the table with all the skill I can muster, made of the evenings that stay alive past 10, the sky turning Prussian blue but still lit enough from inside to walk torchless at midnight.

Is that OK? Did it fit? There is more, of course. These are just hints, just pointers. It doesn't work. You get nowhere near it and yet not to attempt to tell everybody is a dereliction of duty. This, if anyone cares, is why I garden. All the sensations, and ancillary emotions towed along with them, bundled into moments of perfection. This is as good as it gets.

Midsummer is not necessarily the high-spot, but there are weeks and sometimes months when only memory and anticipation sustain you. Midsummer is a cairn on top of the year, and there is a view to be taken from here.

For a start, there are all the temporal measurements that have taken place this week on the pinnacle of the year - summer solstice, the longest day, the middle of the calendar - as though we reach this peak, take a breather, and then trudge down the other side to the unrelieved gloom of the winter solstice. But it is not the garden's summit. That comes later - in this garden, perhaps as late as September, when the vegetable plot is spilling with its harvest and the borders have that rich, late-season intensity. But because there is this sensation of so much more to come, coupled with maximum light, maximum time and freshness, it is a time to celebrate.

Intimacy is at the centre of all good gardening, so your own backyard is always the most interesting, or at least, it should be. Broad horticultural sweeps of the brush make for dull pictures. For a start, you inevitably load certain plants with significance that the casual eye does not share. At this time of year, for me, those plants are the roses. I adore old roses and they never fail to repay that adoration, even in a mildewy, blackspotty, aphid-coated season. Is there anything in the garden more beautiful than the rich pink buds of 'Chapeau de Napoleon' opening from its bright green tricorn? If so, it is probably the sliced-off flowers of the gallica 'Charles de Mills', the white flowers of the damask 'Madame Hardy', the intensity of the gallica 'Tuscany Superb', the alba 'Celestial', the incredible velvety cherry red of 'Scharlachglut' before they bleach pink in the sun... and 50 more. Every day in June, when I am at home, I go and cut a selection of about a dozen different roses and put them in small vases - just the flowers - on the kitchen table, our desks, bedside tables. If you don't like roses, then you're simply growing the wrong ones.

Sweet peas have to be cut, too. Their season has begun, although it will hit maximum intensity in a month's time. We grow ours on wigwams of six hazel bean sticks, planting a 4in pot with two sweet peas in it to each stick, so each wigwam has 12 plants of the same type.

The Jewel garden has sweet peas with rich single colours, such as 'Black Knight', 'Violet Queen' and 'Hannah Dale' and the walled garden, which is a much softer, gentle place and has most of the old roses, includes Spencer varieties with good scent, such as 'Cream Southborne', 'Lovejoy' and 'Gipsy Queen', as well as the original 'Cupani'. I have written about sweet peas before, but suffice to say that I cannot imagine midsummer without them. A bunch of sweet peas has incredible healing power and seems to combine the inevitable components of nostalgia with a life-affirming intensity of the moment.

The third component of the midsummer flower garden, which seems to form a trinity in my association, is the poppies. The oriental poppies are pretty much done, but the opium, field and shirley poppies are at their best. Field poppies, Papaver rhoeas , lie patiently waiting for their moment for a remarkably long time. Each flower will produce around 17,000 seeds, of which about 3,000 will remain viable and dormant in untilled ground for at least a century before bursting into flower when the ground is disturbed and the seeds are exposed to light. We let these flourish wherever they appear - and they appear everywhere, from cracks paths to the onion bed. They usually get it wrong, poor dolts, but they somehow get an exemption from the degree of colour-ruthlessness we try and apply.

Not solemn enough for heavy August and too fulsome for spring, the frilly silliness of opium poppies against their dusty leaves - also frilled like a 70s dress shirt - is exactly in the spirit of midsummer. There is a particular batch of 'Black peony' opium poppy, P somniferum , that has been popping up in the vegetable garden that would be fabulous in the Jewel garden. Poppies hate being moved once they have got to any size at all, but you can take a clump of seedlings in wet soil and move them. The only time I did this, from the kitchen garden, they turned out to be unacceptably anodyne pink - which would have been fine where they were, in among some main-crop potatoes - but hopelessly jarring among the purples, crimsons and oranges where I'd put them.

The Jewel garden arrives at this end of June, intense without heaviness - a memorable lunch rather than a heavy dinner. It is held together by the combination of, among other things, delphiniums, roses, sweet Williams - of which we have nigricans and another with the most intense, shimmering magenta of any plant I have ever seen and whose seed packet I have lost. Geums, the ligularias 'The Rocket', 'Desdemona' and the unpronounceable Lprzewalksii, the last of the June-flowering clematises, the first of the dahlia 'Bishop of Llandaff' (setting a benchmark for red among all the is-it-red-is-it-pinks?) all lit by the great tracer sprays of Stipa gigantica .

The spring garden has gone dormant and I only walk through it about once a week, but that's fine. It needs the rest. Only a hedge-width away, the foxgloves all along the pleached lime walk are perhaps past their true best, but have another week in them. By which time we shall be in July and, somehow, another season. *

It is now safe to mow long grass without harming the spring flowers that you may have growing in it. But it is essential to collect all the cut grass and remove it if you want the same wildflowers to spread or even return next year. I have found that even very dry hay will compost well enough in a big heap if you leave it for a couple of years and put the sprinkler on to it in dry weather. It also acts as a good mulch for fruit trees. Put it around the trunk straightaway and let it rot down in situ.

By the same token, you can now tidy up the leaves of bulbs such as daffodils and tulips without harming next season's flowers. If you grow them in pots, it is a good idea to take them out, clean the compost off and store them in a cool, dry place before repotting in the autumn.

Lift irises that have been in the same site for the past three years or more, divide them and replant in as sunny a spot as possible, making sure that half the rhizome remains above the surface of the ground.

fields.headline: A hard Raine's gonna fall
fields.standfirst: Craig Raine searches for memories of a lover and a close friend in A la Recherche du Temps Perdu
fields.trailText: Craig Raine searches for memories of a lover and a close friend in A la Recherche du Temps Perdu
fields.body:
A la Recherche du Temps Perdu
Craig Raine
Picador, £8, pp41

Craig Raine's poem A la Recherche du Temps Perdu, written in loosely rhymed and half-rhymed couplets, was originally published in his new journal, Areté in 1999. Picador has just released it in book form, hard cover at that, possibly giving it an importance that it doesn't warrant.

Apart from my problems with the poem itself, sanctification through book publication lends this supposed genre-busting elegy a weight it simply doesn't have. People are what we remember of them. Reconstructing a dead lover and close friend from memory, stimulated by the moment of recognising absence and things past; at the funeral - 'I sentimentalise/and then revise' - we travel with the poet as he attempts to make the dead 'real'. By engaging with the fleshly, the scatological, the effluvia and wastes of love, the persona reawakens the dead. It's a 'warts and all' portrayal, and consequently self-critical and 'unromantic':

Details that make you cringe

will make the reader see,
see the self you showed to me.

There are moments when a concept of how language makes things alive mixes with memory, and the poem does come to life. The opening 17 couplets are quite stunning, and when I began I thought I was in for a treat. At times Baudelaire came to mind. And Auden, of course. And with the evocation of Proust in the title and Shakespeare in the whole concept, this elegiac address to the dead ex-lover struggles with the gulfs between life, inspiration, the process of writing, and production of big-L Literature. But there's something extremely bourgeois and tidy about the details that are supposed to make us cringe. The young man's sexual learning curve is simply uninteresting. And on a more worrying level, the 'black man' lurks as the overwhelming other.

This fits with the tradition from which the poem is coming. The death of the woman being celebrated comes via Aids. Her bi-black ex-lover is already dead, we learn. And there are worrying lines such as: 'The odd white prole, but black boys on the whole.' The removal that persona allows doesn't distance us enough; and if it does, so what.

The persona's recounting of memory is tinged with self-irony. However, the self-mockery comes across as a method of humanising the voice, to create a sense of vulnerability and consequently make the reconstruction seem more authentic. Rather than 'unromantic' it seems like a lusty flow of romanticism with the 'sordid' details as ornamentation. Lines like the following are why Language Poetry came into existence:

I was having the chocolate sponge,
you were having a cold revenge.

1990: the last time I saw you.
A tin sun out in the blue.

I gave you my new book of essays
and asked you what you thought of my play.

Of '1953'? You shook your head a bit.
I think Racine a very, very , very, great poet.

He allows himself to be mocked, and takes it on the chin. But that just encourages us to think he must be telling the truth, that the voice is to be trusted. This poem is elegy as poetics. It's more about a world view and modus operandi as literary figure than about engaging with the trauma of loss. Which is not to say such a loss doesn't inform it. But the light couplets and the 'literati' subject matter drop it into the pit of male 'muse' poetry. Brought to life through memory, but also objectified as muse:

Disjecta membra scattered everywhere,
unrecognisable, through my oeuvre:

complex, trivial, true.
And now I have re-membered you.

The poet is aware of the complexities of the process of evocation and fetishisation. These are good lines of poetry, but as a whole the attitude is unconvincing. The sincerity and the meta-view of self don't quite gel.

The best moments are the least forced, where a moment of sharing is touched. Moments in time:

For breakfast you ate
chocolate fingers, langues de chat,

waffles with maple syrup,
Chamonix biscuits, doughnuts,

or Petit Suisse
with sugar. Anything sweet.

Its familiarity enhances the sense of loss. It's not trying to prove something to itself as much of the poem seems to. Elegy here is about testing the selective qualities of memory. Reconciliation with loss comes out of staging reconstructions, of defining one's continued existence against the nature of memory.

Raine is an accomplished poet who moves comfortably through social and cultural discourse, through history and language. If all of Raine is in this poem, it's not a comfortable mix. Maybe because it strives to be sincere, it loses distance and falls apart. The self-admonition, the sense of caring for one's self more than the person who has died, the reconciliation that follows self-analysis, are all there. It's what a friend of mine recently called 'bloke's poetry pretending to be sensitive'. And it shows.

webTitle: Wilting German Greens elect new leaders to win back voters

fields.headline: Wilting German Greens elect new leaders to win back voters
fields.trailText: It has been dubbed the worst job in Germany, but Renate Künast and Fritz Kuhn oozed optimism yesterday as they took on the task of leading the country's embattled and unruly Greens.
fields.body:
It has been dubbed the worst job in Germany, but Renate Künast and Fritz Kuhn oozed optimism yesterday as they took on the task of leading the country's embattled and unruly Greens.

The neatly groomed duo, both aged 44, represent a sharp contrast to their wild-haired predecessors and promise to transform the public perception of the party. 'We have not yet transformed ourselves from a successful opposition party into an equally successful party of government,' Kuhn said.

The leaders were elected unopposed at a party conference in the western city of Münster after the Greens voted overwhelmingly to support a deal with power companies for a phased shutdown of Germany's 19 nuclear power stations.

Opponents of the deal argued that the 32-year phasing-out period was too long and feared the plan could be reversed. But Green Ministers persuaded delegates the deal was a victory for the party, which has campaigned against nuclear energy for 30 years.

The neo-liberal Free Democrats (FDP) have been outperforming the Greens in recent state elections and would like to supplant them as Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's coalition partners.

Kuhn and Künast, who have the support of the party's leading figure, Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, hope to reverse the party's loss of popularity by trumpeting Green achievements and professionalising the party organisation.

Künast made her name in Berlin campaigning for civil rights and sexual equality and enjoys the support of many on the Left of the party. Kuhn specialises in financial policy and leads the party in the state parliament of Baden-Württemberg. They were elected according to the Greens' complex quota system that ensures proportionate representation in the leadership of men and women and activists from East and West.

Reforms in immigration and citizenship law, gay rights and environmental issues have been initiated by the Greens, but Schröder has claimed credit for popular measures while blaming his partners for the government's mistakes.

An opinion poll yesterday showed most voters believe the Greens have outlived their usefulness but the party's parliamentary leader, Rezzo Schlauch, insists: 'We are the think-tank of the coalition. All the reform measures came from us. We are the real modernisers.'
Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times.

The leaders were elected unopposed at a party conference in the western city of Münster after the Greens voted overwhelmingly to support a deal with power companies for a phased shutdown of Germany's 19 nuclear power stations. Opponents of the deal argued that the 32-year phasing-out period was too long and feared the plan could be reversed. But Green Ministers persuaded delegates the deal was a victory for the party, which has campaigned against nuclear energy for 30 years. The neo-liberal Free Democrats (FDP) have been outperforming the Greens in recent state elections and would like to supplant them as Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's coalition partners. Kuhn and Künast, who have the support of the party's leading figure, Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, hope to reverse the party's loss of popularity by trumpeting Green achievements and professionalising the party organisation. Künast made her name in Berlin campaigning for civil rights and sexual equality and enjoys the support of many on the Left of the party. Kuhn specialises in financial policy and leads the party in the state parliament of Baden-Württemberg. They were elected according to the Greens' complex quota system that ensures proportionate representation in the leadership of men and women and activists from East and West. Reforms in immigration and citizenship law, gay rights and environmental issues have been initiated by the Greens, but Schröder has claimed credit for popular measures while blaming his partners for the government's mistakes. An opinion poll yesterday showed most voters believe the Greens have outlived their usefulness but the party's parliamentary leader, Rezzo Schlauch, insists: 'We are the think-tank of the coalition. All the reform measures came from us. We are the real modernisers.' Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times.

fields.headline: Phallus in wonderland
fields.standfirst: Ruth Padel analyses the weird and wonderful world of rock'n'roll in I'm A Man
fields.trailText: Ruth Padel analyses the weird and wonderful world of rock'n'roll in I'm A Man
fields.body:
I'm a Man: Sex, Gods and Rock'n'Roll
Ruth Padel
Faber & Faber £.9.99, pp352
Buy it at BOL

Even the chapter headings of Ruth Padel's I'm a Man: Sex, Gods and Rock'n'Roll, a highly personalised, vivid and speculative critique of the history and meaning of popular music, are slightly exhausting. Here are just some of them: 'Power, War and Creativity: the Male Gods Round Desire'; 'When the Guitar Became a Gun: Empowering Violence'; 'Cross Dressing, Castrati, Camp'; 'Dylan: Creativity, Misogyny and Echo' and, my personal favourite,the simple, dramatic 'The Holy Axe'.

It's lovely to imagine Padel sitting around with a bunch of brain-dead musician goons in a hotel room at four o'clock in the morning, a heap of class A drugs on the table between them, discussing this little lot. An earlier breed of rock star - Brian Eno, David Bowie, Brian Jones, Jimmy Page - might have gone for it, maybe strumming sitars and other unusual ethnic instruments, as they mused along with this expressive, passionate and, occasionally, slightly overwrought poet-writer about the darker psychological suburbs of rock'n'roll.

The incessant male validation and misogyny. The theft from black artists. The imagery. The primality. The glory. The sex, drugs and shame. Padel would probably have had to put up with them staring down her top while they were doing it, but she might just have got a semblance of a decent conversation out of them.

Sadly, however, I could tell Padel for nothing that not many of the present crop of male British rock and pop stars would even understand what she was talking about, never mind be able to join in with words of more than two syllables. Pulp's Jarvis Cocker or Primal Scream's Bobby Gillespie at a push. Asian Dub Foundation for the race issues. Paul Weller if you caught him in a good mood running between Winnebagos at Glastonbury.

However, could you imagine Oasis's contribution to the debate 'Heroes Are Violent, Dark, Against - Especially In the Theatre'? Even the Manic Street Preachers would probably slope off, wrapped in a Welsh footie flag, somewhere around the chapter, 'Marine Magic: Saving, Veiling, Faking' . As the great Shane MacGowan, then of the Pogues, once said to an intensely theorising, earnest New Musical Express colleague of mine: 'Jeeshush shut up, you're boring the arsh off me.'

Sometimes, Ruth, you really have to wonder why we bother. Books like I'm A Man are not really for musicians - they're always too drunk or too drugged, sometimes as a disguise for their innate laziness or stupidity, otherwise simply because they were born to be druggy drunks and theories about Sophocles, and his links to modern-day rock make their brain hurt. In a way, you've got to be sympathetic. Music is, by definition, an instinctive rather than intellectual discipline and a beer could go flat in the time it takes Padel to argue through her more intricate theories about men, women, culture, libido, myth and reality.

Saying that, Padel should be congratulated for not having produced the standard fan/critic tome. I'm A Man is basically the evergreen fan lament: 'Rock'n'roll ruined my life!', but it spins around an intellectual axis, vents a polemicised, gender-based spleen and paints a frequently touching subtext of the young Padel coming to terms with the fact that the music she is obsessed by is doomed to let her down on every level - as a thinker, a fan, a humanitarian and a woman.

It starts as it means to go on, with a rant about the correlation of Greek myth to rock'n'roll, splicing rock quotes with history, and Padel's own thoughts. 'How come we do not realise how extremely strange rock culture and its conventions are?' she asks. 'Why the enormous stadia? Why the groupies, the screaming hysteria, crowd surfing and enormous theatricity?'

Padel concludes at this point that our knee-jerk acceptance of standard rock mores is strange and then goes on to find a lot of other things strange. At times, you agree wholeheartedly with her thought processes and her choice of data. As one might expect from a book entitled I'm A Man, Padel is particularly vivid when talking about the coruscating sexism and racism that have burrowed like woodworm through rock from the time the white man decided to claim the 'boogie' as his own big idea, and sideline female musicians as mere glorified groupies.

The chapters on the enduring emphasis on 'cock in rock' are amusing, while the passages on the science and poetry of the rock crowd, and the dissections of the really rather bizarre rituals we all take for granted, are original and beautifully expressed.

I'm A Man isn't a perfect music book, like Greil Marcus's Mystery Train or the Osmonds 1976 annual. For instance, some might take umbrage at the way Padel doesn't work her way methodically through the history; she rather makes the facts squeeze themselves into interesting shapes to adapt to her theories. Then there is the slightly grating way she hops through musical genres like a man rushing around duty free trying to find a last-minute present for his wife.

Most unforgivably, the tone occasionally 'slums it' a little too obviously. At such times, one is reminded of when newspapers send the esteemed, highbrow likes of Vikram Seth, Martin Amis or Salman Rushdie off to do something populist and 'ordinary' (darts; football; pop concerts) and they come back all over-excited about the 'common man' and have to be put to bed early.

Saying that, I'm A Man is a credible, interesting book, written with a mulekick style and researched with obvious passion.

After this, the air-guitar hero will never be able to admire himself strumming away in front of the bedroom mirror with quite the same ill-informed, cock-centric, humourless intensity ever again.

webTitle: Where it all went wrong: 10 key Keegan mistakes

fields.headline: Where it all went wrong
fields.standfirst: How wise is Kevin Keegan? Here are 10 key points on which he, in hindsight, might like to think again
fields.trailText: How wise is Kevin Keegan? Paul Wilson sets out 10 key points on which he, in hindsight, might like to think again.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan asked to be judged on results, and he has been. England took an early flight home after losing two leads, two matches and most of their credibility by playing some of the most gormless football at Euro 2000, but the FA are standing by their man.

Keegan may be an ideal ambassador for English football between fixtures, but as soon as matches begin the bold words and positive outlook are revealed as mere wishful thinking. There is no doubt that Keegan has just presided over the biggest shambles since the Graham Taylor era, or that the gains made by Terry Venables and Glenn Hoddle in realigning English football with the rest of the world have been squandered. From a 20-minute high in the game against Portugal, England went backwards, stripping back the years like time travellers as they did so to arrive at the point where the rest of Europe is once again laughing at us.

Two things appear to be preserving Keegan from a fate similar to Taylor's. The first is that he took over halfway through qualifying, and deserves a modicum of credit for getting England to Euro 2000 at all. The second is the defeat of Germany in Charleroi, that allowed a brief interlude of optimism and saved Keegan and England from the three straight defeats which would surely have made the manager's position untenable. Even so, three straight defeats was all England's football deserved, but luck sent along the worst German team in living memory to make Keegan's side feel a little better about themselves, at least until Portugal's reserves put the hard-fought 1-0 win into perspective.

Perhaps the FA are right and Keegan deserves a chance over the full four years of his contract, although to be around in 2002 the manager needs to steer England through World Cup qualification, which cannot be taken for granted. Opponents like Germany, Greece, Finland and Albania might not appear too daunting, but England do not yet have a single performance in the bank under Keegan to make any of those sides unduly concerned. Based on the evidence of the past 18 months, it is all too easy to imagine England being frustrated in Helsinki or Athens.

'Since I've been in charge, I've never seen us play as well as we can,' Keegan admitted. 'I take responsibility for England never reaching their peak, but I don't see any reason to offer my resignation. We can get through our World Cup qualification.'

The FA still want Keegan, the Press is not yet calling for his head - so it looks as if we will be sticking with gormless football for the foreseeable future. There are two likely outcomes. Either England screw up in qualifying and another manager will be brought in to try and get the 2002 campaign back on the rails, or Keegan's side will stagger into the World Cup finals and make the sort of impression on Japan and Korea they have just made on Belgium and Holland.

'You can doubt me, you can question my suitability for the job, but my life's been about proving people wrong,' Keegan said in that melodramatic way of his. He means his life as a player. He has not proved many people wrong as a manager, either at Newcastle ('I've taken this club as far as I can, I don't know how to go a stage further') or with England ('I wanted to show we were better than our qualifying form suggested, but we never managed to do that'). The question now is whether Keegan can learn from his mistakes, or at least it ought to be. The fact is Keegan is not admitting any mistakes, so don't hold your breath. Nonetheless, here are 10 reasons why Keegan failed at Euro 2000, and will probably continue to fail in the World Cup.

(1) Having too much faith in the ability of Alan Shearer

Keegan clearly expected his captain to be banging in the goals like it was Euro 96 all over again, terrorising the world's best defences and galvanising his own players with clench-fisted exhortations to follow his example. For the past two years this has been pure fantasy. Shearer was of only limited value to England in the last World Cup, and has done little since to warrant the slavish devotion of successive England managers. Hoddle would surely have tried an alternative by now, whereas Keegan would still be picking him for the World Cup qualifiers had not Shearer himself called it a day.

What Shearer knows, but Keegan appears unable to grasp, is that he is a sadly diminished player since his ankle injury three years ago. Every utterance Keegan makes, including the outrageous accusation that press criticism has hounded his captain off the international stage, conveys the impression that Shearer can play for England for at least another two years if he wishes.

(2) Making Shearer captain

All of the above was apparent when Keegan took over from Hoddle in February last year. Shearer's lacklustre performances and defeated body language were already attracting comment, yet the first thing Keegan did on becoming England manager was appoint Shearer his captain even though his form did not warrant a place in the team. That meant England always played more or less the same way, with David Beckham and whoever could be found for the left wing required to supply crosses from wide positions. And with Shearer a constant presence, alternative strikers - Michael Owen, Andy Cole or Robbie Fowler - were only seen in relation to him, and rarely in their own right.

(3) Taking Michael Owen off at half time against Portugal

Had this been a more decisive fixture, rather than the first match of the European Championship, this revealing substitution might have ended up haunting Keegan in a Gary Lineker-Graham Taylor way. The difference is that Owen's career is not over, it must just have felt that way after he was pulled off in favour of Emile Heskey.

Keegan said he wanted a different sort of player up front, one who could hold the ball up. Heskey is certainly different to Owen, whether or not he can hold the ball up. As it happened, against Portugal, he couldn't. Nor, in a month of Sundays, could Heskey produce the sort of alert response and instinctive vision that Owen showed in the first half to find Beckham in the move that created the second goal.

(4) Ignoring birth certificates

Keegan picks players on form, ability and experience, and does not take age into account. This is why Stuart Pearce may yet add to his England caps in World Cup qualifiers this autumn, and why the spine of the England team is being allowed to age together.

In fairness, there are not that many convincing young candidates queueing up to take over from Seaman, Adams, Ince and Shearer, but the downside of coaxing one last tournament out of the old guard is that there is now no time to adapt to the next. Keegan reacted to the suggestion England might use Euro 2000 to prepare for the World Cup as if it were treasonable. 'I'm not going to turn my back on the players who got us here,' he said, disregarding the fact that England had hardly qualified impressively.

But surely now Keegan will usher in the young players and begin to dismantle the team? Don't bank on it. 'This is not the end of the line for Adams, Ince and Seaman, I'd like to double underline that,' Keegan said after elimination. 'You can't look to the future too much when you're trying to qualify for a tournament.'

(5) Believing England could win Euro 2000

'Expectancy is something I've always encouraged,' said Keegan, who reiterated his belief that England could win the event even after defeat by Portugal. 'I don't regret it. That's my job. What do you want me to say? That we won't do very well? We had a chance of winning. Had we faced Italy we would have been two games from the final. That's a chance. I am an optimist. I don't surround myself with people who want to be negative or see the dark side of everything.'

(6) Being so optimistic

There is nothing wrong with positive thinking, but Keegan must be the only person in the world who believed his preferred England team, with its ageing spine, non-existent left wing and predictable tactics, could sweep all before them. Had he never seen France, Holland, or even Portugal? 'We're not like France and Holland, and we can't play like Brazil or Portugal,' he said. 'It's not what we are brought up on, our strengths are different. But if we could learn to play it from the back, keep hold of the ball, and add that to our long ball strengths and our crossing, we could have a combination with a chance.'

Four years ago Venables unashamedly copied Dutch tactics and ended up thrashing Holland 4-1, still the post-1966 high point of English football. The players are mostly still around, indeed some exciting new ones have arrived, but now Keegan admits they can't play a passing game. Evidently there is a limit to his optimism.

(7) Being too conservative in his selection

'Everyone knows the way we play,' Keegan even confessed. 'We like to get down the wings and get in crosses for our front men, and as long as I'm in charge I hope we always will.'

Keegan does not appear worried that hardly anyone else still plays like this, or that England's recent results scarcely justify such unshakeable belief. 'There's no point talking about tactics or formation if you can't even pass the ball,' Keegan said. But England players can pass the ball. As Keegan says, they do it in the Premiership all the time. What they lacked in Euro 2000 was a shape to make life difficult for their opponents and a system to make ball retention easier.

(8) Inability to change things round on the pitch

Perhaps, as Dennis Wise has said, this is as much the players' fault as the manager's. Yet having picked a 4-4-2 formation for the first game and then watched as Portugal's alleged wide players tucked inside to leave the Nevilles with nothing to do and Ince with two or three men at a time to deal with, England's response was slow. 'We want to be playing this game in their half of the pitch,' Keegan had said beforehand. Even before Portugal equalised it was clear this plan was not working. England's outnumbered midfield was in full retreat, and the game was played almost exclusively in England's half. The same thing was allowed to happen again against Romania - entirely predictably - just because Keegan thought the system had worked well enough against Germany.

(9) According senior players too much respect

Keegan is a manager who listens to his senior players, and it is hard to criticise him for that. Perhaps significantly, however, for a manager who constantly harps on about how callously he was dropped by Bobby Robson, Keegan has yet to establish he can deal with the tricky matter of ending an ageing player's England days. Also, in the case of Shearer, he continued to pick the player, even though his decision to terminate his England career left him under no such obligation and his form barely merited it.

The manager would have you believe Shearer is a special case, whose exceptional importance and illustrious contribution to the England cause entitles him to this treatment. Others would offer the less kindly view that Keegan copped out on Shearer all along, surrendered the initiative to his captain and allowed him to do more or less as he pleased. Shearer has gone now, but Keegan has yet to show he can make a difficult decision.

(10) Rating Emile Heskey as a successor to Shearer

Heskey has his good points, though not many of them were easily discernible in this tournament and Liverpool must have had at least half the value wiped off their £11m investment. But post-Shearer we do not need a replacement so much as a rethink. England have just spent two years asking too much of ordinary players like Shearer and Phil Neville, while simultaneously failing to get the best from class acts like Beckham, Scholes and Owen. We might not be as lavishly endowed with talented players as France, Holland and Portugal, but - with the talent we do have - we ought not to be flying home early with the Slovenians and Scandinavians.

A good coach with firm ideas could sort it out, but while the FA continue to persist with a good PR man instead, the best plan might be to ignore the Keegan rhetoric and go into the next World Cup expecting the worst.
