But if we could learn to play it from the back, keep hold of the ball, and add that to our long ball strengths and our crossing, we could have a combination with a chance.' Four years ago Venables unashamedly copied Dutch tactics and ended up thrashing Holland 4-1, still the post-1966 high point of English football. The players are mostly still around, indeed some exciting new ones have arrived, but now Keegan admits they can't play a passing game. Evidently there is a limit to his optimism. (7) Being too conservative in his selection 'Everyone knows the way we play,' Keegan even confessed. 'We like to get down the wings and get in crosses for our front men, and as long as I'm in charge I hope we always will.' Keegan does not appear worried that hardly anyone else still plays like this, or that England's recent results scarcely justify such unshakeable belief. 'There's no point talking about tactics or formation if you can't even pass the ball,' Keegan said. But England players can pass the ball. As Keegan says, they do it in the Premiership all the time. What they lacked in Euro 2000 was a shape to make life difficult for their opponents and a system to make ball retention easier. (8) Inability to change things round on the pitch Perhaps, as Dennis Wise has said, this is as much the players' fault as the manager's. Yet having picked a 4-4-2 formation for the first game and then watched as Portugal's alleged wide players tucked inside to leave the Nevilles with nothing to do and Ince with two or three men at a time to deal with, England's response was slow. 'We want to be playing this game in their half of the pitch,' Keegan had said beforehand. Even before Portugal equalised it was clear this plan was not working. England's outnumbered midfield was in full retreat, and the game was played almost exclusively in England's half. The same thing was allowed to happen again against Romania - entirely predictably - just because Keegan thought the system had worked well enough against Germany. (9) According senior players too much respect Keegan is a manager who listens to his senior players, and it is hard to criticise him for that. Perhaps significantly, however, for a manager who constantly harps on about how callously he was dropped by Bobby Robson, Keegan has yet to establish he can deal with the tricky matter of ending an ageing player's England days. Also, in the case of Shearer, he continued to pick the player, even though his decision to terminate his England career left him under no such obligation and his form barely merited it. The manager would have you believe Shearer is a special case, whose exceptional importance and illustrious contribution to the England cause entitles him to this treatment. Others would offer the less kindly view that Keegan copped out on Shearer all along, surrendered the initiative to his captain and allowed him to do more or less as he pleased. Shearer has gone now, but Keegan has yet to show he can make a difficult decision. (10) Rating Emile Heskey as a successor to Shearer Heskey has his good points, though not many of them were easily discernible in this tournament and Liverpool must have had at least half the value wiped off their £11m investment. But post-Shearer we do not need a replacement so much as a rethink. England have just spent two years asking too much of ordinary players like Shearer and Phil Neville, while simultaneously failing to get the best from class acts like Beckham, Scholes and Owen. We might not be as lavishly endowed with talented players as France, Holland and Portugal, but - with the talent we do have - we ought not to be flying home early with the Slovenians and Scandinavians. A good coach with firm ideas could sort it out, but while the FA continue to persist with a good PR man instead, the best plan might be to ignore the Keegan rhetoric and go into the next World Cup expecting the worst.

webTitle: 'I skidded my way to the car at 6am. Then I dropped my keys'

fields.headline: 'I skidded my way to the car at 6am. Then I dropped my keys'
fields.standfirst: Glastonbury cheer was thin on the ground for  Burhan Wazir
fields.trailText: Glastonbury cheer was thin on the ground for  Burhan Wazir
fields.body:
The first Glastonbury of the new millennium, and my inaugural festival experience isn't going well. The personal injury toll by Saturday afternoon is one missing credit card, several mislaid backstage passes, a dropped car key and nearly all my good cheer. 'That's Glastonbury,' says a friend, profoundly.

It is one way of looking at Michael Eavis's 30-year-old festival, which arrives in June most years to disrupt the tranquility of his dairy herd. Another is via the statistics for what has become the world's most famous and arguably most successful festival which this year has produced a temporary city of 30,000 tents and 100,000 ticket-holders, performers and the freeloaders who have jumped over or burrowed through the fence.

Another way to view Glastonbury is by the notorious toilets. Several Portaloos were closed on Friday, as organisers sought to empty the cabins before Saturday morning. Chaos ensued as queues backed up overnight. 'It's a regular occurrence,' said one organiser.

But for the majority the most accurate way of judging a Glastonbury success is by the quality of the performers on the stages and in the tents dotted around the vast site, tempted there by the festival's legendary atmosphere. This year that means David Bowie, Travis, the Pet Shop Boys, Ocean Colour Scene, Macy Gray, Willie Nelson, Chemical Brothers, Moby and the Asian Dub Foundation.

And in the Green Field - Glastonbury's spiritual centre - new age herbal remedies and mysticism are a cornerstone of the festival experience.

In one tent, high above the music stages, The Great Divine is performing an exorcism. Samantha, 25, a traveller, wails and tries to rip off her clothes as The Great Divine chants computer programming language. 'We once used Latin for exorcisms,' he says. 'But the demons better under stand programming code - they're more scared of logic.' On Friday night, US soul singer Macy Gray proved the top draw. Flamboyantly dressed in a white fur, wrap-around shades and disco hotpants, Gray and her group prowled like Baptist preachers ear-bashing an unruly flock.

Like any similar-sized town, Glastonbury is never free of crime. This year, police reported 141 arrests for the three day festival, largely for drug-related crime and petty theft, although they pointed out that many 'stolen' items had now been found.

I even found my keys. On Friday, while navigating a route back to parking zone W21, I became completely lost. I asked a Glastonbury handler: 'Sorry mate,' he said. I slipped and skidded my way to W21 finally finding my car by the flame of my lighter at 6am. That was also the time I dropped my car key. It was eventually found by parking attendants in a tractor trail an hour later.
